### [1] [Randomized-MLP Regularization Improves Domain Adaptation and Interpretability in DINOv2](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.05509)
*Joel Valdivia Ortega,Lorenz Lamm,Franziska Eckardt,Benedikt Schworm,Marion Jasnin,Tingying Peng*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: Introduces Randomized-MLP (RMLP) regularization for ViTs (e.g., DINOv2) that, via contrastive learning on randomized MLP tokens, yields more semantically aligned representations and more interpretable attention without sacrificing downstream performance across medical and natural images; supported by a mathematical analysis of RMLP.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: ViTs often repurpose low-informative patch tokens, reducing attention and feature-map interpretability. This is aggravated by domain shifts in medical imaging. There is a need for regularization techniques that improve semantic alignment and transparency without harming accuracy.

Method: Propose Randomized-MLP (RMLP) regularization, a contrastive-learning-based approach. Integrate RMLPs during fine-tuning of DINOv2 on both medical and natural image modalities to encourage semantically aligned representations. Provide a mathematical analysis of RMLPs to elucidate its effect on ViT representations and the role of contrastive learning.

Result: Demonstrates improved or unchanged downstream performance while yielding more interpretable attention maps across modalities. The study also contributes a mathematical analysis that offers theoretical insight into how RMLPs enhance ViT-based models and advances understanding of contrastive learning.

Conclusion: RMLP regularization can enhance ViT interpretability and robustness to domain shifts without sacrificing accuracy. The work deepens theoretical understanding of contrastive learning in vision transformers and suggests practical benefits for medical imaging and cross-domain applications.

Abstract: Vision Transformers (ViTs), such as DINOv2, achieve strong performance across domains but often repurpose low-informative patch tokens in ways that reduce the interpretability of attention and feature maps. This challenge is especially evident in medical imaging, where domain shifts can degrade both performance and transparency. In this paper, we introduce Randomized-MLP (RMLP) regularization, a contrastive learning-based method that encourages more semantically aligned representations. We use RMLPs when fine-tuning DINOv2 to both medical and natural image modalities, showing that it improves or maintains downstream performance while producing more interpretable attention maps. We also provide a mathematical analysis of RMLPs, offering insights into its role in enhancing ViT-based models and advancing our understanding of contrastive learning.

</details>


### [2] [Token Is All You Need: Cognitive Planning through Sparse Intent Alignment](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.05540)
*Shiyao Sang*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: A token-based, minimal semantic representation suffices for planning in end-to-end autonomous driving, achieving competitive ADE without full future scene generation; conditioning on predicted future tokens improves performance; explicit reconstruction loss may harm; temporal fuzziness suggests planning via flexible semantics rather than fixed timestamps.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Question the necessity of exhaustive world modeling and Markov-based vision-language-action systems for high-performance E2E driving; propose a cognitively inspired approach where planning occurs through imagination over a sparse token set.

Method: Evaluate on the nuPlan benchmark (720 scenarios, >11k samples) using perception-informed BEV representations. Compare (1) baseline sparse token representation without future prediction, (2) token-conditioned trajectory decoding on predicted future tokens, and (3) inclusion of explicit reconstruction loss. Assess performance via ADE and analyze emergent temporal fuzziness where the model attends to task-relevant semantics rather than fixed timestamps.

Result: Baseline ADE: 0.548 m; with predicted future tokens: 0.479 m (≈12.6% improvement over baselines). Reconstruction loss offers no benefit and may degrade performance given reliable perception. Notable emergence of temporal fuzziness: model attends to semantics rather than rigid timestamps, enabling planning under uncertainty.

Conclusion: Supports a paradigm shift from world reconstruction to semantic understanding through tokens. The ‘token is all you need’ principle suggests planning via imagination is feasible and potentially advantageous for cognitively inspired E2E systems, with implications for robustness and scalability.

Abstract: We challenge the long-standing assumption that exhaustive scene modeling is required for high-performance end-to-end autonomous driving (E2EAD). Unlike world-model approaches that rely on computationally intensive future scene generation or vision-language-action (VLA) systems constrained by Markov assumptions, we show that a minimal set of semantically rich tokens is sufficient for effective planning. Experiments on the nuPlan benchmark (720 scenarios, over 11,000 samples) using perception-informed BEV representations yield three key findings: (1) even without future prediction, our sparse representation achieves 0.548 m ADE, comparable to or surpassing prior methods reporting around 0.75 m on nuScenes; (2) conditioning trajectory decoding on predicted future tokens reduces ADE to 0.479 m, a 12.6% improvement over current-state baselines; and (3) explicit reconstruction loss offers no benefit and may degrade performance under reliable perception inputs. Notably, we observe the emergence of temporal fuzziness, where the model adaptively attends to task-relevant semantics rather than aligning rigidly to fixed timestamps, providing a cognitive advantage for planning under uncertainty. Our "token is all you need" principle marks a paradigm shift from reconstructing the world to understanding it, laying a foundation for cognitively inspired systems that plan through imagination rather than reaction.

</details>


### [3] [Automated Invoice Data Extraction: Using LLM and OCR](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.05547)
*Advait Thakur,Khushi Khanchandani,Akshita Shetty,Chaitravi Reddy,Ritisa Behera*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: A holistic AI platform that integrates OCR, deep learning (CNNs/Transformers), LLMs, and graph analytics to achieve unprecedented extraction quality and consistency in invoice data extraction across diverse layouts and low-quality scans.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Invoices exhibit highly variable layouts, handwriting, and poor scan quality, and template-based OCR struggles to generalize. There is a need for scalable, accurate, low-maintenance extraction by combining modern DL, LLMs, and contextual graph-based methods.

Method: Hybrid architecture that blends OCR with CNN/Transformer-based layout analysis, visual NER, and LLM-driven extraction, augmented by graph analytics to map relationships and ensure consistency across document sections. The approach emphasizes a unified AI platform for end-to-end extraction.

Result: The authors claim unprecedented extraction quality and consistency across invoice types, driven by the integrated platform and advanced entity recognition.

Conclusion: A unified AI platform integrating OCR, deep learning, LLMs, and graph analytics can significantly improve invoice data extraction accuracy and scalability while reducing human intervention.

Abstract: Conventional Optical Character Recognition (OCR) systems are challenged by
variant invoice layouts, handwritten text, and low- quality scans, which are
often caused by strong template dependencies that restrict their flexibility
across different document structures and layouts. Newer solutions utilize
advanced deep learning models such as Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) as
well as Transformers, and domain-specific models for better layout analysis and
accuracy across various sections over varied document types. Large Language
Models (LLMs) have revolutionized extraction pipelines at their core with
sophisticated entity recognition and semantic comprehension to support complex
contextual relationship mapping without direct programming specification.
Visual Named Entity Recognition (NER) capabilities permit extraction from
invoice images with greater contextual sensitivity and much higher accuracy
rates than older approaches. Existing industry best practices utilize hybrid
architectures that blend OCR technology and LLM for maximum scalability and
minimal human intervention. This work introduces a holistic Artificial
Intelligence (AI) platform combining OCR, deep learning, LLMs, and graph
analytics to achieve unprecedented extraction quality and consistency.

</details>


### [4] [EVLP:Learning Unified Embodied Vision-Language Planner with Reinforced Supervised Fine-Tuning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.05553)
*Xinyan Cai,Shiguang Wu,Dafeng Chi,Yuzheng Zhuang,Xingyue Quan,Jianye Hao,Qiang Guan*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: EVLP introduces a unified multimodal generation framework for embodied long-horizon tasks, combining language-based reasoning with visual generation via dynamic perception pretraining and reinforced fine-tuning to align spatial logic with generated imagery.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Current multimodal planning methods lack a unified generation framework, leading to inconsistencies between linguistic reasoning and visual planning in complex, long-horizon manipulation tasks.

Method: Proposes Unified Multimodal Generation Framework that learns the joint distribution of discrete images for one-step visual synthesis with cross-modal attention; Dynamic Perception Pretraining using bidirectional alignment through inverse and forward dynamics tasks; Reinforced Supervised Fine-Tuning with a reinforce loss to align spatial logic between textual actions and generated images, fostering spatio-aware multimodal planning.

Result: Demonstrates multimodal planning for long-horizon tasks via a novel training pipeline, achieving improved coordination between textual and visual modalities and stronger intra-model multimodal correlations through the dynamic pretraining and reinforced fine-tuning.

Conclusion: EVLP provides a cohesive framework that fuses semantic and spatial perception to enable joint language-vision planning for embodied tasks, driven by dynamic pretraining and reinforced alignment to achieve robust multimodal planning.

Abstract: In complex embodied long-horizon manipulation tasks, effective task
decomposition and execution require synergistic integration of textual logical
reasoning and visual-spatial imagination to ensure efficient and accurate
operation. Current methods fail to adopt a unified generation framework for
multimodal planning, lead to inconsistent in multimodal planning. To address
this challenge, we present \textbf{EVLP (Embodied Vision-Language Planner)}, an
innovative multimodal unified generation framework that jointly models
linguistic reasoning and visual generation. Our approach achieves multimodal
planning for long-horizon tasks through a novel training pipeline incorporating
dynamic pretraining and reinforced alignment. Our core innovations consist of
three key components: \textbf{1) Unified Multimodal Generation Framework}: For
understanding, We integrate semantic information with spatial features to
provide comprehensive visual perception. For generation, we directly learn the
joint distribution of discrete images for one-step visual synthesis, enabling
coordinated language-visual modeling through learnable cross-modal attention
mechanisms. \textbf{2) Dynamic Perception Pretraining}: We propose a
bidirectional dynamic alignment strategy employing inverse dynamics tasks and
forward dynamics tasks, effectively strengthening multimodal correlations
within a unified feature space. \textbf{3) Reinforced Supervised Fine-Tuning}:
While conducting instruction-based fine-tuning in the unified generation space,
we construct a reinforce loss to align the spatial logic between textual
actions and generated images, enabling the model to acquire spatio-awared
multimodal planning capabilities.

</details>


### [5] [MCFCN: Multi-View Clustering via a Fusion-Consensus Graph Convolutional Network](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.05554)
*Chenping Pei,Fadi Dornaika,Jingjun Bi*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: MCFCN introduces a fusion-consensus graph convolutional network for multi-view clustering that learns a unified consensus graph and representations end-to-end, using SMAL and FRAL losses, achieving state-of-the-art on eight datasets with available code.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Existing multi-view clustering methods focus on consensus representation learning via subspace methods and even graph-based MVC suffers from noisy input graphs and insufficient cross-view consistency. Multi-view graph refinement methods fail to handle hard-to-distinguish samples and often rely on disjoint graph construction steps, hindering joint optimization.

Method: Propose MCFCN with end-to-end learning of a consensus graph guided by a Unified Graph Structure Adapter (UGA), a view feature fusion model, and two alignment losses: Similarity Matrix Alignment Loss (SMAL) and Feature Representation Alignment Loss (FRAL). The framework optimizes view-specific graphs under consensus guidance to preserve cross-view topology, promote intra-class edges, and learn robust consensus representations via Graph Convolutional Networks (GCN).

Result: Demonstrates state-of-the-art clustering performance on eight multi-view benchmark datasets; extensive qualitative and quantitative experiments validate the effectiveness of the proposed approach. The authors also provide code at the project repository.

Conclusion: By learning a unified consensus graph and aligning both similarity structures and feature representations across views, MCFCN achieves robust consensus representations and improved clustering, addressing topological noise, cross-view inconsistency, and hard samples in MVC.

Abstract: Existing Multi-view Clustering (MVC) methods based on subspace learning focus on consensus representation learning while neglecting the inherent topological structure of data. Despite the integration of Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) into MVC, their input graph structures remain susceptible to noise interference. Methods based on Multi-view Graph Refinement (MGRC) also have limitations such as insufficient consideration of cross-view consistency, difficulty in handling hard-to-distinguish samples in the feature space, and disjointed optimization processes caused by graph construction algorithms. To address these issues, a Multi-View Clustering method via a Fusion-Consensus Graph Convolutional Network (MCFCN) is proposed. The network learns the consensus graph of multi-view data in an end-to-end manner and learns effective consensus representations through a view feature fusion model and a Unified Graph Structure Adapter (UGA). It designs Similarity Matrix Alignment Loss (SMAL) and Feature Representation Alignment Loss (FRAL). With the guidance of consensus, it optimizes view-specific graphs, preserves cross-view topological consistency, promotes the construction of intra-class edges, and realizes effective consensus representation learning with the help of GCN to improve clustering performance. MCFCN demonstrates state-of-the-art performance on eight multi-view benchmark datasets, and its effectiveness is verified by extensive qualitative and quantitative implementations. The code will be provided at https://github.com/texttao/MCFCN.

</details>


### [6] [Compressing Multi-Task Model for Autonomous Driving via Pruning and Knowledge Distillation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.05557)
*Jiayuan Wang,Q. M. Jonathan Wu,Ning Zhang,Katsuya Suto,Lei Zhong*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: A multi-task panoptic perception model is compressed via safe pruning and feature distillation, achieving substantial parameter reduction with minimal performance loss and real-time speed on BDD100K.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Deploying multi-task panoptic perception on on-board devices is challenging due to growing model size; there is a need to reduce parameters while preserving segmentation and detection performance.

Method: Introduce a multi-task model compression framework: task-aware safe pruning that combines Taylor-based channel importance with gradient conflict penalty to prune channels, plus a task head-agnostic knowledge distillation transferring intermediate backbone/encoder features from teacher to student.

Result: On BDD100K: 32.7% parameter reduction; segmentation performance with negligible accuracy loss; detection declines of -1.2% recall and -1.8% mAP50; runs at 32.7 FPS in real-time.

Conclusion: Pruning plus knowledge distillation effectively compresses multi-task panoptic perception with preserved performance and real-time inference, offering a practical solution for autonomous driving systems.

Abstract: Autonomous driving systems rely on panoptic perception to jointly handle object detection, drivable area segmentation, and lane line segmentation. Although multi-task learning is an effective way to integrate these tasks, its increasing model parameters and complexity make deployment on on-board devices difficult. To address this challenge, we propose a multi-task model compression framework that combines task-aware safe pruning with feature-level knowledge distillation. Our safe pruning strategy integrates Taylor-based channel importance with gradient conflict penalty to keep important channels while removing redundant and conflicting channels. To mitigate performance degradation after pruning, we further design a task head-agnostic distillation method that transfers intermediate backbone and encoder features from a teacher to a student model as guidance. Experiments on the BDD100K dataset demonstrate that our compressed model achieves a 32.7% reduction in parameters while segmentation performance shows negligible accuracy loss and only a minor decrease in detection (-1.2% for Recall and -1.8% for mAP50) compared to the teacher. The compressed model still runs at 32.7 FPS in real-time. These results show that combining pruning and knowledge distillation provides an effective compression solution for multi-task panoptic perception.

</details>


### [7] [FilletRec: A Lightweight Graph Neural Network with Intrinsic Features for Automated Fillet Recognition](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.05561)
*Jiali Gao,Taoran Liu,Hongfei Ye,Jianjun Chen*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: A data-driven, end-to-end framework named FilletRec for automatic recognition and simplification of fillet features in CAD models, featuring a lightweight graph neural network that uses pose-invariant geometric features (e.g., curvature) and a large-scale fillet dataset to improve accuracy and generalization while being highly parameter-efficient.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Existing rule-based methods lack robustness and deep learning models struggle with generalization and accuracy on complex fillets due to generic designs and limited training data. There is a need for a specialized, robust approach and a large, diverse dataset to support learning.

Method: Introduce FilletRec, a lightweight graph neural network that leverages pose-invariant intrinsic geometric features (such as curvature) to capture fundamental geometric patterns of fillets. The approach includes constructing and releasing a large-scale diverse benchmark dataset for fillet recognition and integrates an efficient geometric simplification algorithm to complete the automated workflow from recognition to simplification.

Result: FilletRec achieves higher accuracy and better generalization than state-of-the-art methods while using only 0.2% to 5.4% of the parameters of baseline models, demonstrating high efficiency. It surpasses competitors on complex fillet topology recognition and enables end-to-end automated simplification.

Conclusion: The proposed end-to-end framework advances fillet feature recognition and simplification in CAD models by combining a data-driven, geometry-aware neural model with a large-scale dataset, achieving robust performance and substantial model efficiency.

Abstract: Automated recognition and simplification of fillet features in CAD models is critical for CAE analysis, yet it remains an open challenge. Traditional rule-based methods lack robustness, while existing deep learning models suffer from poor generalization and low accuracy on complex fillets due to their generic design and inadequate training data. To address these issues, this paper proposes an end-to-end, data-driven framework specifically for fillet features. We first construct and release a large-scale, diverse benchmark dataset for fillet recognition to address the inadequacy of existing data. Based on it, we propose FilletRec, a lightweight graph neural network. The core innovation of this network is its use of pose-invariant intrinsic geometric features, such as curvature, enabling it to learn more fundamental geometric patterns and thereby achieve high-precision recognition of complex geometric topologies. Experiments show that FilletRec surpasses state-of-the-art methods in both accuracy and generalization, while using only 0.2\%-5.4\% of the parameters of baseline models, demonstrating high model efficiency. Finally, the framework completes the automated workflow from recognition to simplification by integrating an effective geometric simplification algorithm.

</details>


### [8] [M2S2L: Mamba-based Multi-Scale Spatial-temporal Learning for Video Anomaly Detection](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.05564)
*Yang Liu,Boan Chen,Xiaoguang Zhu,Jing Liu,Peng Sun,Wei Zhou*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: Introduces M2S2L, a Mamba-based multi-scale spatial-temporal learning framework for video anomaly detection that combines hierarchical spatial encoders, multi-temporal motion encoders, and a feature decomposition mechanism to optimize appearance and motion reconstruction; achieves strong accuracy with real-time efficiency on standard benchmarks.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Video anomaly detection requires robust spatial-temporal modeling while maintaining computational efficiency for real-time surveillance; existing approaches struggle to balance accuracy and efficiency across diverse contexts.

Method: M2S2L uses hierarchical spatial encoders at multiple granularities and multi-temporal encoders to capture motion dynamics across different time scales, coupled with a feature decomposition mechanism to enable task-specific optimization for appearance and motion reconstruction, yielding better behavioral modeling and quality-aware anomaly assessment.

Result: On UCSD Ped2, CUHK Avenue, and ShanghaiTech datasets, the method achieves 98.5%, 92.1%, and 77.9% frame-level AUC, respectively, with 20.1G FLOPs and 45 FPS inference, indicating strong performance with practical efficiency.

Conclusion: M2S2L provides robust, scalable spatial-temporal modeling for video anomaly detection with real-time capable performance, suitable for deployment in practical surveillance systems.

Abstract: Video anomaly detection (VAD) is an essential task in the image processing
community with prospects in video surveillance, which faces fundamental
challenges in balancing detection accuracy with computational efficiency. As
video content becomes increasingly complex with diverse behavioral patterns and
contextual scenarios, traditional VAD approaches struggle to provide robust
assessment for modern surveillance systems. Existing methods either lack
comprehensive spatial-temporal modeling or require excessive computational
resources for real-time applications. In this regard, we present a Mamba-based
multi-scale spatial-temporal learning (M2S2L) framework in this paper. The
proposed method employs hierarchical spatial encoders operating at multiple
granularities and multi-temporal encoders capturing motion dynamics across
different time scales. We also introduce a feature decomposition mechanism to
enable task-specific optimization for appearance and motion reconstruction,
facilitating more nuanced behavioral modeling and quality-aware anomaly
assessment. Experiments on three benchmark datasets demonstrate that M2S2L
framework achieves 98.5%, 92.1%, and 77.9% frame-level AUCs on UCSD Ped2, CUHK
Avenue, and ShanghaiTech respectively, while maintaining efficiency with 20.1G
FLOPs and 45 FPS inference speed, making it suitable for practical surveillance
deployment.

</details>


### [9] [In-Context Adaptation of VLMs for Few-Shot Cell Detection in Optical Microscopy](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.05565)
*Shreyan Ganguly,Angona Biswas,Jaydeep Rade,Md Hasibul Hasan Hasib,Nabila Masud,Nitish Singla,Abhipsa Dash,Ushashi Bhattacharjee,Aditya Balu,Anwesha Sarkar,Adarsh Krishnamurthy,Soumik Sarkar*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: Open-vocabulary few-shot object detection for biomedical microscopy using in-context learning; introduces Micro-OD benchmark (252 images, 11 cell types) and a hybrid FSOD pipeline; zero-shot is weak, few-shot helps with diminishing gains after ~6 shots; reasoning tokens aid localization while simpler variants suit crop classification.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Bridge the gap between powerful vision-language models (VLMs) trained on natural images and the data-scarce domain of biomedical microscopy, enabling open-vocabulary detection with few annotated examples.

Method: Create Micro-OD benchmark for in-context learning with 252 images across 11 cell types; evaluate eight VLMs under few-shot regimes with/without test-time reasoning tokens; develop a hybrid Few-Shot Object Detection (FSOD) pipeline combining a detector head and a VLM-based few-shot classifier; analyze end-to-end localization vs pre-localized crop classification.

Result: Zero-shot performance is poor due to domain gap; few-shot support consistently improves detection; gains plateau after about six shots; reasoning tokens boost end-to-end localization while simpler models suit crop classification; the approach provides a practical path for microscopy and the benchmark offers a reproducible testbed for open-vocabulary biomedical detection.

Conclusion: In-context adaptation is a practical and promising route for biomedical microscopy, with Micro-OD serving as a valuable benchmark to advance open-vocabulary detection in biomedical imaging.

Abstract: Foundation vision-language models (VLMs) excel on natural images, but their
utility for biomedical microscopy remains underexplored. In this paper, we
investigate how in-context learning enables state-of-the-art VLMs to perform
few-shot object detection when large annotated datasets are unavailable, as is
often the case with microscopic images. We introduce the Micro-OD benchmark, a
curated collection of 252 images specifically curated for in-context learning,
with bounding-box annotations spanning 11 cell types across four sources,
including two in-lab expert-annotated sets. We systematically evaluate eight
VLMs under few-shot conditions and compare variants with and without implicit
test-time reasoning tokens. We further implement a hybrid Few-Shot Object
Detection (FSOD) pipeline that combines a detection head with a VLM-based
few-shot classifier, which enhances the few-shot performance of recent VLMs on
our benchmark. Across datasets, we observe that zero-shot performance is weak
due to the domain gap; however, few-shot support consistently improves
detection, with marginal gains achieved after six shots. We observe that models
with reasoning tokens are more effective for end-to-end localization, whereas
simpler variants are more suitable for classifying pre-localized crops. Our
results highlight in-context adaptation as a practical path for microscopy, and
our benchmark provides a reproducible testbed for advancing open-vocabulary
detection in biomedical imaging.

</details>


### [10] [Automatic Extraction of Road Networks by using Teacher-Student Adaptive Structural Deep Belief Network and Its Application to Landslide Disaster](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.05567)
*Shin Kamada,Takumi Ichimura*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: Adaptive RBM/DBN with neuron generation-annihilation and layer generation improves RoadTracer for road-network extraction from aerial imagery, using Teacher-Student ensemble; achieves high accuracy and edge-device deployment, with disaster-response capability.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Road network extraction from aerial imagery is challenging due to complex features and variability; an adaptive network structure can tailor capacity to data; shrinking time and deploying on edge devices are desirable for rapid disaster response.

Method: Use adaptive structural learning for RBM/DBN (neuron generation-annihilation in RBM; layer generation in DBN) within the RoadTracer framework; apply a Teacher-Student ensemble learning model of Adaptive DBN; implement a lightweight model on an embedded edge device for fast inference.

Result: Detection accuracy improved from 40.0% to 89.0% on average across seven major cities; extended to detect available roads during landslide/disaster scenarios; deployed a compact model on an edge device; reported satellite-image results before and after rainfall disaster in Japan.

Conclusion: Adaptive structural learning and Teacher-Student ensemble in DBN enhance road-network extraction from aerial imagery, enabling high-accuracy detection and practical deployment on resource-constrained devices, with applicability to disaster-response scenarios.

Abstract: An adaptive structural learning method of Restricted Boltzmann Machine (RBM)
and Deep Belief Network (DBN) has been developed as one of prominent deep
learning models. The neuron generation-annihilation algorithm in RBM and layer
generation algorithm in DBN make an optimal network structure for given input
during the learning. In this paper, our model is applied to an automatic
recognition method of road network system, called RoadTracer. RoadTracer can
generate a road map on the ground surface from aerial photograph data. A novel
method of RoadTracer using the Teacher-Student based ensemble learning model of
Adaptive DBN is proposed, since the road maps contain many complicated features
so that a model with high representation power to detect should be required.
The experimental results showed the detection accuracy of the proposed model
was improved from 40.0\% to 89.0\% on average in the seven major cities among
the test dataset. In addition, we challenged to apply our method to the
detection of available roads when landslide by natural disaster is occurred, in
order to rapidly obtain a way of transportation. For fast inference, a small
size of the trained model was implemented on a small embedded edge device as
lightweight deep learning. We reported the detection results for the satellite
image before and after the rainfall disaster in Japan.

</details>


### [11] [C3-Diff: Super-resolving Spatial Transcriptomics via Cross-modal Cross-content Contrastive Diffusion Modelling](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.05571)
*Xiaofei Wang,Stephen Price,Chao Li*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: C3-Diff is a cross-modal diffusion framework that uses histology guidance to enhance spatial transcriptomics via refined cross-modal contrastive learning, feature hypersphere noising, and dynamic cross-modal imputation, outperforming baselines on four datasets and enabling downstream analyses.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Spatial transcriptomics currently suffers from low resolution and weak modeling of histology–gene interactions. Traditional contrastive learning is insufficient for cross-modal cross-content alignment, and ST data are scarce and noisy, hindering robust enhancement.

Method: Introduce C3-Diff: a cross-modal cross-content contrastive diffusion framework. Analyze deficiencies of traditional contrastive learning and design modal-invariant and content-invariant feature extraction for ST maps and histology images. Apply noising-based information augmentation on the surface of the feature unit hypersphere. Propose a dynamic cross-modal imputation-based training strategy to mitigate ST data scarcity.

Result: Outperforms competing methods on four public datasets. Demonstrates improvements in downstream tasks: cell type localization, gene expression correlation, and single-cell-level gene expression prediction. Code released at GitHub.

Conclusion: C3-Diff demonstrates effective, histology-guided ST enhancement by combining diffusion with refined cross-modal contrastive learning and cross-modal imputation, addressing data scarcity and enabling improved biological insight with potential clinical relevance.

Abstract: The rapid advancement of spatial transcriptomics (ST), i.e., spatial gene
expressions, has made it possible to measure gene expression within original
tissue, enabling us to discover molecular mechanisms. However, current ST
platforms frequently suffer from low resolution, limiting the in-depth
understanding of spatial gene expression. Super-resolution approaches promise
to enhance ST maps by integrating histology images with gene expressions of
profiled tissue spots. However, it remains a challenge to model the
interactions between histology images and gene expressions for effective ST
enhancement. This study presents a cross-modal cross-content contrastive
diffusion framework, called C3-Diff, for ST enhancement with histology images
as guidance. In C3-Diff, we firstly analyze the deficiency of traditional
contrastive learning paradigm, which is then refined to extract both
modal-invariant and content-invariant features of ST maps and histology images.
Further, to overcome the problem of low sequencing sensitivity in ST maps, we
perform nosing-based information augmentation on the surface of feature unit
hypersphere. Finally, we propose a dynamic cross-modal imputation-based
training strategy to mitigate ST data scarcity. We tested C3-Diff by
benchmarking its performance on four public datasets, where it achieves
significant improvements over competing methods. Moreover, we evaluate C3-Diff
on downstream tasks of cell type localization, gene expression correlation and
single-cell-level gene expression prediction, promoting AI-enhanced
biotechnology for biomedical research and clinical applications. Codes are
available at https://github.com/XiaofeiWang2018/C3-Diff.

</details>


### [12] [Video Text Preservation with Synthetic Text-Rich Videos](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.05573)
*Ziyang Liu,Kevin Valencia,Justin Cui*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: Synthetic supervision with T2I-generated text-rich images animated by an I2V model can fine-tune a pre-trained T2V model to improve text readability and temporal coherence without architectural changes.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Textual fidelity in Text-To-Video (T2V) generation remains challenging and costly to fix with existing methods; a lightweight, data-efficient approach is desirable.

Method: Generate text-rich images using a text-to-image (T2I) diffusion model; animate them into short videos with a text-agnostic image-to-video (I2v) model; form synthetic video-prompt pairs; fine-tune Wan2.1 (a pre-trained T2V model) without changing its architecture.

Result: Improved short-text legibility and temporal consistency; emergence of structural priors that could help longer text.

Conclusion: Curated synthetic data and weak supervision offer a practical path to boosting textual fidelity in T2V generation without architectural changes, and with low additional computational cost.

Abstract: While Text-To-Video (T2V) models have advanced rapidly, they continue to
struggle with generating legible and coherent text within videos. In
particular, existing models often fail to render correctly even short phrases
or words and previous attempts to address this problem are computationally
expensive and not suitable for video generation. In this work, we investigate a
lightweight approach to improve T2V diffusion models using synthetic
supervision. We first generate text-rich images using a text-to-image (T2I)
diffusion model, then animate them into short videos using a text-agnostic
image-to-video (I2v) model. These synthetic video-prompt pairs are used to
fine-tune Wan2.1, a pre-trained T2V model, without any architectural changes.
Our results show improvement in short-text legibility and temporal consistency
with emerging structural priors for longer text. These findings suggest that
curated synthetic data and weak supervision offer a practical path toward
improving textual fidelity in T2V generation.

</details>


### [13] [Elements of Active Continuous Learning and Uncertainty Self-Awareness: a Narrow Implementation for Face and Facial Expression Recognition](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.05574)
*Stanislav Selitskiy*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: A supervising neural network monitors a CNN ensemble to detect high uncertainty and trigger active learning with human input, imbuing a form of self-awareness in a face recognition/expressions task.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To enable narrow ML systems to self-monitor and adjust their predictions for reliability, approaching higher-level intelligence by incorporating a trustworthiness assessment and human-in-the-loop in uncertain situations.

Method: A supervising ANN observes activation patterns of an underlying CNN ensemble used for face recognition and expression tasks. It includes a memory region to store past performance and learns by adjusting its parameters to optimize outcomes. When high uncertainty is detected, it issues a trustworthiness verdict that activates active learning, allowing the system to request human assistance.

Result: A conceptual/prototype demonstration showing the feasibility of a self-awareness mechanism that detects uncertainty in a CNN ensemble and triggers active learning with human input in face-related tasks.

Conclusion: The work shows that self-awareness-like monitoring can be modeled at a narrow ML level, with a supervising network that tracks past performance and controls learning via trustworthiness judgments, enabling adaptive agency and potentially guiding toward more robust AI systems.

Abstract: Reflection on one's thought process and making corrections to it if there
exists dissatisfaction in its performance is, perhaps, one of the essential
traits of intelligence. However, such high-level abstract concepts mandatory
for Artificial General Intelligence can be modelled even at the low level of
narrow Machine Learning algorithms. Here, we present the self-awareness
mechanism emulation in the form of a supervising artificial neural network
(ANN) observing patterns in activations of another underlying ANN in a search
for indications of the high uncertainty of the underlying ANN and, therefore,
the trustworthiness of its predictions. The underlying ANN is a convolutional
neural network (CNN) ensemble employed for face recognition and facial
expression tasks. The self-awareness ANN has a memory region where its past
performance information is stored, and its learnable parameters are adjusted
during the training to optimize the performance. The trustworthiness verdict
triggers the active learning mode, giving elements of agency to the machine
learning algorithm that asks for human help in high uncertainty and confusion
conditions.

</details>


### [14] [DiffSwap++: 3D Latent-Controlled Diffusion for Identity-Preserving Face Swapping](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.05575)
*Weston Bondurant,Arkaprava Sinha,Hieu Le,Srijan Das,Stephanie Schuckers*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: DiffSwap++ uses a 3D-aware diffusion-based face-swapping pipeline that conditions denoising on identity embeddings and facial landmarks to improve identity preservation and disentangle pose/expression, achieving state-of-the-art results on CelebA, FFHQ, and CelebV-Text with biometric-style evaluation and user studies; code will be released.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Existing diffusion-based face-swapping methods often produce artifacts and fail to disentangle identity from pose/expression due to underutilization of 3D facial structure. Incorporating 3D latent features is key to geometric consistency and better identity preservation.

Method: Train a diffusion model guided by 3D-aware representations, conditioning the denoising process on identity embeddings and facial landmarks to enable high-fidelity, identity-preserving swaps with explicit 3D guidance.

Result: Empirically outperforms prior methods on CelebA, FFHQ, and CelebV-Text; includes biometric-style evaluation and a user study; code will be publicly available.

Conclusion: Incorporating 3D-aware conditioning into diffusion-based face swapping improves geometry, disentanglement of identity from pose/expression, and overall swap fidelity, representing a new state-of-the-art with practical applicability.

Abstract: Diffusion-based approaches have recently achieved strong results in face swapping, offering improved visual quality over traditional GAN-based methods. However, even state-of-the-art models often suffer from fine-grained artifacts and poor identity preservation, particularly under challenging poses and expressions. A key limitation of existing approaches is their failure to meaningfully leverage 3D facial structure, which is crucial for disentangling identity from pose and expression. In this work, we propose DiffSwap++, a novel diffusion-based face-swapping pipeline that incorporates 3D facial latent features during training. By guiding the generation process with 3D-aware representations, our method enhances geometric consistency and improves the disentanglement of facial identity from appearance attributes. We further design a diffusion architecture that conditions the denoising process on both identity embeddings and facial landmarks, enabling high-fidelity and identity-preserving face swaps. Extensive experiments on CelebA, FFHQ, and CelebV-Text demonstrate that DiffSwap++ outperforms prior methods in preserving source identity while maintaining target pose and expression. Additionally, we introduce a biometric-style evaluation and conduct a user study to further validate the realism and effectiveness of our approach. Code will be made publicly available at https://github.com/WestonBond/DiffSwapPP

</details>


### [15] [Beyond Softmax: Dual-Branch Sigmoid Architecture for Accurate Class Activation Maps](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.05590)
*Yoojin Oh,Junhyug Noh*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: A dual-branch sigmoid head decouples localization from classification in CAM, eliminating additive logit shifts and sign collapse, preserving magnitude and sign of feature contributions without hurting accuracy.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: CAM and its variants rely on a final softmax classifier, which introduces additive logit shifts and sign ambiguity between excitatory/inhibitory features, distorting evidence maps. A model-agnostic way to retain classification power while yielding faithful localization signals is needed.

Method: Clone the existing classification head into a parallel branch that ends in per-class sigmoid outputs. Freeze the original softmax head and fine-tune only the sigmoid branch with class-balanced binary supervision. At inference, use the softmax head for recognition and the sigmoid branch to generate evidence maps that preserve both magnitude and sign of feature contributions. This approach is architecture-agnostic, integrates with existing CAM variants, and incurs negligible overhead.

Result: Empirical results show improved explanation fidelity on fine-grained datasets (CUB-200-2011, Stanford Cars) and WSOL benchmarks (ImageNet-1K, OpenImages30K) with consistent Top-1 Localization gains, and no degradation in classification accuracy.

Conclusion: A simple, integration-friendly enhancement to CAM that decouples localization from classification via a parallel sigmoid head, enabling faithful, signed feature contributions and broad compatibility with CAM methods; code released.

Abstract: Class Activation Mapping (CAM) and its extensions have become indispensable tools for visualizing the evidence behind deep network predictions. However, by relying on a final softmax classifier, these methods suffer from two fundamental distortions: additive logit shifts that arbitrarily bias importance scores, and sign collapse that conflates excitatory and inhibitory features. We propose a simple, architecture-agnostic dual-branch sigmoid head that decouples localization from classification. Given any pretrained model, we clone its classification head into a parallel branch ending in per-class sigmoid outputs, freeze the original softmax head, and fine-tune only the sigmoid branch with class-balanced binary supervision. At inference, softmax retains recognition accuracy, while class evidence maps are generated from the sigmoid branch -- preserving both magnitude and sign of feature contributions. Our method integrates seamlessly with most CAM variants and incurs negligible overhead. Extensive evaluations on fine-grained tasks (CUB-200-2011, Stanford Cars) and WSOL benchmarks (ImageNet-1K, OpenImages30K) show improved explanation fidelity and consistent Top-1 Localization gains -- without any drop in classification accuracy. Code is available at https://github.com/finallyupper/beyond-softmax.

</details>


### [16] [Google-MedGemma Based Abnormality Detection in Musculoskeletal radiographs](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.05600)
*Soumyajit Maity,Pranjal Kamboj,Sneha Maity,Rajat Singh,Sankhadeep Chatterjee*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: A MedGemma-based framework uses a MedGemma foundation model with a SigLIP-inspired vision encoder to classify X-ray images for abnormality detection, outperforming CNN/autoencoder baselines and enabling transfer learning and modular domain adaptation for scalable radiograph triage.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To improve automatic abnormality detection in musculoskeletal radiographs by leveraging modern medical foundation models, aiming for better generalization, scalability, and efficient domain adaptation compared to traditional autoencoder/NN pipelines.

Method: Preprocess X-ray images and encode them into high-dimensional embeddings using the MedGemma vision backbone with a SigLIP-derived encoder pretrained on diverse medical imaging modalities. Feed embeddings into a lightweight multilayer perceptron for binary abnormality classification. Explore transfer learning by selectively unfreezing encoder blocks for domain adaptation.

Result: The MedGemma-driven classifier achieves strong performance, outperforming conventional convolutional and autoencoder-based metrics. Transfer learning enhances generalization and feature engineering capabilities, and the approach supports modular training for domain adaptation, aiding scalable radiograph triage.

Conclusion: MedGemma-powered classification systems can advance clinical radiograph triage and automated medical image analysis, with potential for broader application across medical imaging tasks due to improved representation learning and efficient transfer learning.

Abstract: This paper proposes a MedGemma-based framework for automatic abnormality detection in musculoskeletal radiographs. Departing from conventional autoencoder and neural network pipelines, the proposed method leverages the MedGemma foundation model, incorporating a SigLIP-derived vision encoder pretrained on diverse medical imaging modalities. Preprocessed X-ray images are encoded into high-dimensional embeddings using the MedGemma vision backbone, which are subsequently passed through a lightweight multilayer perceptron for binary classification. Experimental assessment reveals that the MedGemma-driven classifier exhibits strong performance, exceeding conventional convolutional and autoencoder-based metrics. Additionally, the model leverages MedGemma's transfer learning capabilities, enhancing generalization and optimizing feature engineering. The integration of a modern medical foundation model not only enhances representation learning but also facilitates modular training strategies such as selective encoder block unfreezing for efficient domain adaptation. The findings suggest that MedGemma-powered classification systems can advance clinical radiograph triage by providing scalable and accurate abnormality detection, with potential for broader applications in automated medical image analysis.
  Keywords: Google MedGemma, MURA, Medical Image, Classification.

</details>


### [17] [In-process 3D Deviation Mapping and Defect Monitoring (3D-DM2) in High Production-rate Robotic Additive Manufacturing](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.05604)
*Subash Gautam,Alejandro Vargas-Uscategui,Peter King,Hans Lohr,Alireza Bab-Hadiashar,Ivan Cole,Ehsan Asadi*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: Real-time monitoring and deviation detection for high-deposition-rate robotic AM (e.g., CSAM) to enable in-process compensation and maintain part quality.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: HDRRAM processes offer high build speeds but face shape accuracy challenges due to process instabilities; early detection of deviations is essential to prevent error propagation, reduce post-processing, and ensure consistent quality.

Method: A real-time monitoring system acquires and reconstructs the growing part, compares it directly to a near-net reference model to detect shape deviations, and then segments and tracks each deviation region for timely intervention and potential compensation.

Result: Demonstrates feasibility of real-time deviation detection and region-wise tracking during the build, enabling timely interventions and paving the way for in-process compensation to improve part quality.

Conclusion: Real-time monitoring and deviation segmentation provide a pathway to in-process error correction in HDRRAM processes, potentially reducing post-processing and improving consistency of manufactured parts.

Abstract: Additive manufacturing (AM) is an emerging digital manufacturing technology to produce complex and freeform objects through a layer-wise deposition. High deposition rate robotic AM (HDRRAM) processes, such as cold spray additive manufacturing (CSAM), offer significantly increased build speeds by delivering large volumes of material per unit time. However, maintaining shape accuracy remains a critical challenge, particularly due to process instabilities in current open-loop systems. Detecting these deviations as they occur is essential to prevent error propagation, ensure part quality, and minimize post-processing requirements. This study presents a real-time monitoring system to acquire and reconstruct the growing part and directly compares it with a near-net reference model to detect the shape deviation during the manufacturing process. The early identification of shape inconsistencies, followed by segmenting and tracking each deviation region, paves the way for timely intervention and compensation to achieve consistent part quality.

</details>


### [18] [Walking the Schrödinger Bridge: A Direct Trajectory for Text-to-3D Generation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.05609)
*Ziying Li,Xuequan Lu,Xinkui Zhao,Guanjie Cheng,Shuiguang Deng,Jianwei Yin*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: Proposes TraCe, a trajectory-centric distillation for text-to-3D that reframes SDS as a Schrödinger Bridge problem to reduce artifacts and enable lower CFG, using a LoRA-adapted model trained on the trajectory's score dynamics.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address artifacts (over-saturation, over-smoothing) in optimization-based text-to-3D methods that distill diffusion priors from text-to-image models, by formulating generation as an optimal transport along a diffusion trajectory rather than a fixed denoising score.

Method: The paper shows SDS is a reverse Schrödinger Bridge under Gaussian-like conditions and reduces to SDS score. It then builds Trajectory-Centric Distillation (TraCe), which explicitly constructs a diffusion bridge from the current rendering to the text-conditioned, denoised target, and trains a LoRA-adapted model on that trajectory's score dynamics.

Result: Empirical results indicate TraCe achieves superior quality and fidelity compared with state-of-the-art techniques, while enabling smaller Classifier-free Guidance (CFG) values.

Conclusion: TraCe provides a principled, tractable bridge between SDS and Schrödinger Bridge for text-to-3D generation, enabling robust optimization via trajectory-based distillation and LoRA fine-tuning, with strong empirical gains.

Abstract: Recent advancements in optimization-based text-to-3D generation heavily rely on distilling knowledge from pre-trained text-to-image diffusion models using techniques like Score Distillation Sampling (SDS), which often introduce artifacts such as over-saturation and over-smoothing into the generated 3D assets. In this paper, we address this essential problem by formulating the generation process as learning an optimal, direct transport trajectory between the distribution of the current rendering and the desired target distribution, thereby enabling high-quality generation with smaller Classifier-free Guidance (CFG) values. At first, we theoretically establish SDS as a simplified instance of the Schrödinger Bridge framework. We prove that SDS employs the reverse process of an Schrödinger Bridge, which, under specific conditions (e.g., a Gaussian noise as one end), collapses to SDS's score function of the pre-trained diffusion model. Based upon this, we introduce Trajectory-Centric Distillation (TraCe), a novel text-to-3D generation framework, which reformulates the mathematically trackable framework of Schrödinger Bridge to explicitly construct a diffusion bridge from the current rendering to its text-conditioned, denoised target, and trains a LoRA-adapted model on this trajectory's score dynamics for robust 3D optimization. Comprehensive experiments demonstrate that TraCe consistently achieves superior quality and fidelity to state-of-the-art techniques.

</details>


### [19] [Pose-Aware Multi-Level Motion Parsing for Action Quality Assessment](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.05611)
*Shuaikang Zhu,Yang Yang,Chen Sun*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: A multi-level parsing framework for action quality assessment (AQA) using enhanced pose features, featuring an Action-Unit Parser, Motion Parser, Condition Parser, and Weight-Adjust Scoring, achieving state-of-the-art results on diving datasets for both action segmentation and scoring.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: In action quality assessment, subtle spatial-temporal variations in pose and non-body cues (e.g., water splash) drive scores. Existing methods often struggle to jointly model precise local-global pose representations, pose dynamics, and external conditions across diverse action types. A modular framework that decouples pose-driven segmentation, motion dynamics, and auxiliary scoring factors can better capture the nuances that determine excellence.

Method: A multi-level architecture: Level 1 Action-Unit Parser uses pose extraction to achieve precise action segmentation and rich local-global pose representations. Level 2 Motion Parser learns spatial-temporal features to capture pose changes and appearance details for each action-unit. A dedicated Condition Parser models non-body cues influencing scores (e.g., water splash). A Weight-Adjust Scoring Module flexibly scales scores to accommodate different action types and the multi-scale nature of action-units. Evaluated on large-scale diving datasets, the framework achieves state-of-the-art results in segmentation and scoring.

Result: The framework attains state-of-the-art performance in both action segmentation and action scoring on large-scale diving datasets.

Conclusion: The proposed multi-level motion parsing framework effectively leverages enhanced pose features and auxiliary condition cues to improve AQA performance. Its modular design enables robust handling of diverse action types and external conditions, with strong generalization potential to other sports.

Abstract: Human pose serves as a cornerstone of action quality assessment (AQA), where subtle spatial-temporal variations in pose often distinguish excellence from mediocrity. In high-level competitions, these nuanced differences become decisive factors in scoring. In this paper, we propose a novel multi-level motion parsing framework for AQA based on enhanced spatial-temporal pose features. On the first level, the Action-Unit Parser is designed with the help of pose extraction to achieve precise action segmentation and comprehensive local-global pose representations. On the second level, Motion Parser is used by spatial-temporal feature learning to capture pose changes and appearance details for each action-unit. Meanwhile, some special conditions other than body-related will impact action scoring, like water splash in diving. In this work, we design an additional Condition Parser to offer users more flexibility in their choices. Finally, Weight-Adjust Scoring Module is introduced to better accommodate the diverse requirements of various action types and the multi-scale nature of action-units. Extensive evaluations on large-scale diving sports datasets demonstrate that our multi-level motion parsing framework achieves state-of-the-art performance in both action segmentation and action scoring tasks.

</details>


### [20] [Personalized Image Editing in Text-to-Image Diffusion Models via Collaborative Direct Preference Optimization](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.05616)
*Connor Dunlop,Matthew Zheng,Kavana Venkatesh,Pinar Yanardag*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: A diffusion-model editing framework that personalizes edits via Collaborative Direct Preference Optimization (C-DPO) using user-specific embeddings learned through a graph neural network to share signals across users.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Diffusion models are generic and fail to capture individual aesthetic preferences; personalization and leveraging community signals can improve user-aligned edits.

Method: Introduce C-DPO: model user preferences as nodes in a dynamic graph; learn lightweight GNN embeddings to propagate information among users with similar tastes; integrate embeddings into a new DPO objective that optimizes both individual alignment and neighborhood coherence during diffusion-model editing.

Result: Experiments including user studies and quantitative benchmarks show C-DPO consistently outperforms baselines in producing edits aligned with user preferences.

Conclusion: This work is the first to enable personalized image editing in diffusion models, demonstrating that collaborative preference signals can be effectively integrated into DPO to tailor edits to individual and community tastes.

Abstract: Text-to-image (T2I) diffusion models have made remarkable strides in generating and editing high-fidelity images from text. Yet, these models remain fundamentally generic, failing to adapt to the nuanced aesthetic preferences of individual users. In this work, we present the first framework for personalized image editing in diffusion models, introducing Collaborative Direct Preference Optimization (C-DPO), a novel method that aligns image edits with user-specific preferences while leveraging collaborative signals from like-minded individuals. Our approach encodes each user as a node in a dynamic preference graph and learns embeddings via a lightweight graph neural network, enabling information sharing across users with overlapping visual tastes. We enhance a diffusion model's editing capabilities by integrating these personalized embeddings into a novel DPO objective, which jointly optimizes for individual alignment and neighborhood coherence. Comprehensive experiments, including user studies and quantitative benchmarks, demonstrate that our method consistently outperforms baselines in generating edits that are aligned with user preferences.

</details>


### [21] [Convolutional Fully-Connected Capsule Network (CFC-CapsNet): A Novel and Fast Capsule Network](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.05617)
*Pouya Shiri,Amirali Baniasadi*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: CFC-CapsNet uses a Convolutional Fully-Connected (CFC) layer to form capsules, yielding fewer but more powerful capsules, improving efficiency and maintaining competitive accuracy on CIFAR-10, SVHN, and Fashion-MNIST compared to standard CapsNet.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: CapsNet preserves spatial hierarchies and can outperform CNNs on some tasks, but struggles on complex datasets, is slower, and has many parameters. A more scalable, efficient capsule architecture is needed for larger datasets and real applications.

Method: Introduce a new CFC layer to construct capsules, forming a Convolutional Fully-Connected Capsule Network (CFC-CapsNet). Evaluate on CIFAR-10, SVHN, Fashion-MNIST, comparing against conventional CapsNet in terms of accuracy, training/inference speed, and parameter count.

Result: CFC-CapsNet achieves competitive accuracy, faster training and inference, and uses fewer parameters than conventional CapsNet on the tested datasets.

Conclusion: The CFC layer enables creation of more efficient, scalable capsules, addressing CapsNet limitations and offering a practical alternative for larger datasets and real-world tasks.

Abstract: A Capsule Network (CapsNet) is a relatively new classifier and one of the possible successors of Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs). CapsNet maintains the spatial hierarchies between the features and outperforms CNNs at classifying images including overlapping categories. Even though CapsNet works well on small-scale datasets such as MNIST, it fails to achieve a similar level of performance on more complicated datasets and real applications. In addition, CapsNet is slow compared to CNNs when performing the same task and relies on a higher number of parameters. In this work, we introduce Convolutional Fully-Connected Capsule Network (CFC-CapsNet) to address the shortcomings of CapsNet by creating capsules using a different method. We introduce a new layer (CFC layer) as an alternative solution to creating capsules. CFC-CapsNet produces fewer, yet more powerful capsules resulting in higher network accuracy. Our experiments show that CFC-CapsNet achieves competitive accuracy, faster training and inference and uses less number of parameters on the CIFAR-10, SVHN and Fashion-MNIST datasets compared to conventional CapsNet.

</details>


### [22] [Grounding Foundational Vision Models with 3D Human Poses for Robust Action Recognition](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.05622)
*Nicholas Babey,Tiffany Gu,Yiheng Li,Cristian Meo,Kevin Zhu*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: A physically grounded action recognition model fusing predictive world dynamics (V-JEPA 2) with explicit pose data (CoMotion) improves performance, especially under occlusion, tested on InHARD and UCF-19-Y-OCC; underscores spatial understanding over pattern recognition.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Current RGB-based action recognition models rely on superficial correlations and struggle to capture underlying physical interaction dynamics and human poses in complex scenes, particularly with occlusions. There is a need to ground actions in physical space by leveraging world dynamics and pose information.

Method: A fusion-based model architecture that integrates V-JEPA 2's contextual predictive world dynamics with CoMotion's explicit, occlusion-tolerant human pose data to ground action recognition in physical space.

Result: The proposed model outperforms three baselines, especially in complex, occlusive scenes, on the InHARD (general action recognition) and UCF-19-Y-OCC (high-occlusion action recognition) benchmarks.

Conclusion: Action recognition should be grounded in spatial understanding within physical space rather than relying solely on statistical pattern recognition.

Abstract: For embodied agents to effectively understand and interact within the world around them, they require a nuanced comprehension of human actions grounded in physical space. Current action recognition models, often relying on RGB video, learn superficial correlations between patterns and action labels, so they struggle to capture underlying physical interaction dynamics and human poses in complex scenes. We propose a model architecture that grounds action recognition in physical space by fusing two powerful, complementary representations: V-JEPA 2's contextual, predictive world dynamics and CoMotion's explicit, occlusion-tolerant human pose data. Our model is validated on both the InHARD and UCF-19-Y-OCC benchmarks for general action recognition and high-occlusion action recognition, respectively. Our model outperforms three other baselines, especially within complex, occlusive scenes. Our findings emphasize a need for action recognition to be supported by spatial understanding instead of statistical pattern recognition.

</details>


### [23] [Registration-Free Monitoring of Unstructured Point Cloud Data via Intrinsic Geometrical Properties](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.05623)
*Mariafrancesca Patalano,Giovanna Capizzi,Kamran Paynabar*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: Proposes a registration-free, mesh-free monitoring framework for unstructured point clouds of complex shapes, using two intrinsic geometric feature-learning methods (Laplacian and geodesic distances) and a threshold-based monitoring scheme to detect defects.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Registration and mesh reconstruction in PCD monitoring are error-prone, time-consuming, and can introduce artifacts that affect monitoring accuracy; a direct, registration-free monitoring approach is desired.

Method: Two alternative feature-learning methods that capture intrinsic shape geometry via Laplacian operators and geodesic distances, combined with a common monitoring scheme that uses thresholding to select the most indicative features of potential out-of-control conditions.

Result: Numerical experiments and case studies demonstrate the method's effectiveness in identifying various defect types without requiring registration or mesh reconstruction.

Conclusion: A registration-free, mesh-free monitoring framework for PCD of complex shapes can reliably detect defects while avoiding preprocessing steps that may introduce artifacts, reducing time, and broadening applicability across manufacturing processes.

Abstract: Modern sensing technologies have enabled the collection of unstructured point cloud data (PCD) of varying sizes, which are used to monitor the geometric accuracy of 3D objects. PCD are widely applied in advanced manufacturing processes, including additive, subtractive, and hybrid manufacturing. To ensure the consistency of analysis and avoid false alarms, preprocessing steps such as registration and mesh reconstruction are commonly applied prior to monitoring. However, these steps are error-prone, time-consuming and may introduce artifacts, potentially affecting monitoring outcomes. In this paper, we present a novel registration-free approach for monitoring PCD of complex shapes, eliminating the need for both registration and mesh reconstruction. Our proposal consists of two alternative feature learning methods and a common monitoring scheme. Feature learning methods leverage intrinsic geometric properties of the shape, captured via the Laplacian and geodesic distances. In the monitoring scheme, thresholding techniques are used to further select intrinsic features most indicative of potential out-of-control conditions. Numerical experiments and case studies highlight the effectiveness of the proposed approach in identifying different types of defects.

</details>


### [24] [Culture in Action: Evaluating Text-to-Image Models through Social Activities](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.05681)
*Sina Malakouti,Boqing Gong,Adriana Kovashka*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: CULTIVate introduces a cross-cultural benchmark for text-to-image models focusing on activities rather than objects, with 16 countries, 576 prompts, and 19k images. It uses a descriptor-based evaluation across background, attire, objects, and interactions, proposing four metrics: cultural alignment, hallucination, exaggeration, and diversity. Findings show north-centric performance gaps and validation that metrics align with human judgments better than existing metrics.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To address cultural biases in diffusion models that are not captured by object-centric benchmarks, by measuring faithfulness of depictions of everyday cultural activities across countries.

Method: Construct a benchmark (CULTIVate) with prompts spanning cross-cultural activities across 16 countries; develop a descriptor-based evaluation framework across background, attire, objects, and interactions; define four metrics (cultural alignment, hallucination, exaggeration, diversity); validate with human studies to assess correlation with judgments.

Result: Reveals systematic disparities: models perform better for global north than global south and show distinct failure modes across T2I systems; human studies show the proposed metrics correlate more strongly with human judgments than existing text-image metrics.

Conclusion: CULTIVate provides a targeted, explainable toolset for evaluating cross-cultural fidelity in T2I models and highlights persistent biases, guiding future data curation and model alignment toward fairer, more representative image synthesis.

Abstract: Text-to-image (T2I) diffusion models achieve impressive photorealism by training on large-scale web data, but models inherit cultural biases and fail to depict underrepresented regions faithfully. Existing cultural benchmarks focus mainly on object-centric categories (e.g., food, attire, and architecture), overlooking the social and daily activities that more clearly reflect cultural norms. Few metrics exist for measuring cultural faithfulness. We introduce CULTIVate, a benchmark for evaluating T2I models on cross-cultural activities (e.g., greetings, dining, games, traditional dances, and cultural celebrations). CULTIVate spans 16 countries with 576 prompts and more than 19,000 images, and provides an explainable descriptor-based evaluation framework across multiple cultural dimensions, including background, attire, objects, and interactions. We propose four metrics to measure cultural alignment, hallucination, exaggerated elements, and diversity. Our findings reveal systematic disparities: models perform better for global north countries than for the global south, with distinct failure modes across T2I systems. Human studies confirm that our metrics correlate more strongly with human judgments than existing text-image metrics.

</details>


### [25] [VMDT: Decoding the Trustworthiness of Video Foundation Models](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.05682)
*Yujin Potter,Zhun Wang,Nicholas Crispino,Kyle Montgomery,Alexander Xiong,Ethan Y. Chang,Francesco Pinto,Yuqi Chen,Rahul Gupta,Morteza Ziyadi,Christos Christodoulopoulos,Bo Li,Chenguang Wang,Dawn Song*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: Introduces VMDT, a unified benchmark for text-to-video (T2V) and video-to-text (V2T) models across five trustworthiness dimensions (safety, hallucination, fairness, privacy, adversarial robustness); reports systemic issues in open-source T2V models and scale-dependent risks in V2T models; safety does not track with model size; provides code and framework for measuring progress.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Video foundation models lack comprehensive trustworthiness benchmarks across modalities. A unified platform is needed to evaluate T2V and V2T models on safety, fairness, privacy, hallucination, and robustness.

Method: Evaluate 7 T2V and 19 V2T models using the VMDT framework across five trustworthiness dimensions; analyze correlations with model size and other factors; report notable trends and insights.

Result: All evaluated open-source T2V models fail to recognize harmful queries and often generate harmful videos, and show higher unfairness than image-domain models. In V2T models, unfairness and privacy risks increase with scale, while hallucination and adversarial robustness improve, though overall performance remains low. Safety shows no correlation with model size.

Conclusion: VMDT provides a systematic framework to measure and track progress toward more robust and trustworthy video foundation models, highlighting urgent needs for improved benchmarks and models in this domain.

Abstract: As foundation models become more sophisticated, ensuring their trustworthiness becomes increasingly critical; yet, unlike text and image, the video modality still lacks comprehensive trustworthiness benchmarks. We introduce VMDT (Video-Modal DecodingTrust), the first unified platform for evaluating text-to-video (T2V) and video-to-text (V2T) models across five key trustworthiness dimensions: safety, hallucination, fairness, privacy, and adversarial robustness. Through our extensive evaluation of 7 T2V models and 19 V2T models using VMDT, we uncover several significant insights. For instance, all open-source T2V models evaluated fail to recognize harmful queries and often generate harmful videos, while exhibiting higher levels of unfairness compared to image modality models. In V2T models, unfairness and privacy risks rise with scale, whereas hallucination and adversarial robustness improve -- though overall performance remains low. Uniquely, safety shows no correlation with model size, implying that factors other than scale govern current safety levels. Our findings highlight the urgent need for developing more robust and trustworthy video foundation models, and VMDT provides a systematic framework for measuring and tracking progress toward this goal. The code is available at https://sunblaze-ucb.github.io/VMDT-page/.

</details>


### [26] [Pedicle Screw Pairing and Registration for Screw Pose Estimation from Dual C-arm Images Using CAD Models](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.05702)
*Yehyun Suh,Lin Li,Aric Plumley,Chaochao Zhou,Daniel Moyer,Kongbin Kang*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: Accurate dual-view pedicle screw correspondence and pose estimation using screw combination evaluation and 2D-3D alignment with CAD models; improves pairing and registration, reducing projection error.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To solve the challenging problem of establishing screw correspondence and pose, especially in LAT views, to improve surgical accuracy in spinal instrumentation.

Method: Compare potential screw pairings across AP and LAT dual C-arm images; perform 2D-3D alignment using CAD 3D models to estimate screw pose; evaluate correctness of combinations before and after registration.

Result: Correct screw combination consistently outperforms incorrect pairings across all test cases; registration further improves alignment and reduces projection error.

Conclusion: This approach shows promise for enhancing screw positioning feedback and potentially improves surgical outcomes in spinal procedures.

Abstract: Accurate matching of pedicle screws in both anteroposterior (AP) and lateral (LAT) images is critical for successful spinal decompression and stabilization during surgery. However, establishing screw correspondence, especially in LAT views, remains a significant clinical challenge. This paper introduces a method to address pedicle screw correspondence and pose estimation from dual C-arm images. By comparing screw combinations, the approach demonstrates consistent accuracy in both pairing and registration tasks. The method also employs 2D-3D alignment with screw CAD 3D models to accurately pair and estimate screw pose from dual views. Our results show that the correct screw combination consistently outperforms incorrect pairings across all test cases, even prior to registration. After registration, the correct combination further enhances alignment between projections and images, significantly reducing projection error. This approach shows promise for improving surgical outcomes in spinal procedures by providing reliable feedback on screw positioning.

</details>


### [27] [Long Grounded Thoughts: Distilling Compositional Visual Reasoning Chains at Scale](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.05705)
*David Acuna,Chao-Han Huck Yang,Yuntian Deng,Jaehun Jung,Ximing Lu,Prithviraj Ammanabrolu,Hyunwoo Kim,Yuan-Hong Liao,Yejin Choi*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: A scalable two-stage data-generation framework produces 1M+ vision-centric synthetic questions with reasoning traces; finetuned models show strong cross-domain transfer and insights into RL training.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address the lack of transparent, scalable datasets for vision-centric reasoning beyond visual math; explore synthetic data generation, RL prompts, and cross-modality transfer.

Method: Two-stage data synthesis: (1) scale, (2) complexity; generate chain-of-thought traces via VLMs and reasoning LLMs; include preference data and RL prompts for offline/online RL; train with supervised fine-tuning and staged RL; evaluate across vision-centric benchmarks.

Result: Finetuning Qwen2.5-VL-7B on the synthetic data outperforms open-data baselines across vision-centric benchmarks and surpasses MiMo-VL-7B-RL on V* Bench, CV-Bench, and MMStar-V; transfers to text-only (MMLU-Pro) and audio (MMAU) reasoning; gains on NiEH embodied QA; SFT with non-linear reasoning traces is key for online RL; staged offline RL matches online RL with less compute; data quality improves cross-modality transfer.

Conclusion: Synthetic vision-centric data, with careful SFT/RL design, enables strong cross-domain performance and efficient training; provides a scalable path for large datasets and actionable guidance on trace design and RL strategies.

Abstract: Recent progress in multimodal reasoning has been driven largely by undisclosed datasets and proprietary data synthesis recipes, leaving open questions about how to systematically build large-scale, vision-centric reasoning datasets, particularly for tasks that go beyond visual math. In this work, we introduce a new reasoning data generation framework spanning diverse skills and levels of complexity with over 1M high-quality synthetic vision-centric questions. The dataset also includes preference data and instruction prompts supporting both offline and online RL. Our synthesis framework proceeds in two stages: (1) scale; and (2) complexity. Reasoning traces are then synthesized through a two-stage process that leverages VLMs and reasoning LLMs, producing CoT traces for VLMs that capture the richness and diverse cognitive behaviors found in frontier reasoning models. Remarkably, we show that finetuning Qwen2.5-VL-7B on our data outperforms all open-data baselines across all evaluated vision-centric benchmarks, and even surpasses strong closed-data models such as MiMo-VL-7B-RL on V* Bench, CV-Bench and MMStar-V.
