Extensive experiments conducted on three widely used benchmark datasets - PURE, UBFC-rPPG, and MMPD - demonstrate that Reperio-rPPG not only achieves state-of-the-art performance but also exhibits remarkable robustness under various motion (e.g., stationary, rotation, talking, walking) and illumination conditions (e.g., nature, low LED, high LED). The code is publicly available at https://github.com/deconasser/Reperio-rPPG.

</details>


### [54] [U(PM)$^2$:Unsupervised polygon matching with pre-trained models for challenging stereo images](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.05949)
*Chang Li,Xingtao Peng*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: A low-cost unsupervised polygon matching pipeline (U(PM)^2) that combines pre-trained models with handcrafted features to match polygons without training, achieving strong accuracy and generalization on ScanNet/SceneFlow with competitive speed.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Polygon matching is under-explored and faces disparity discontinuities, scale variation, training requirements, and limited generalization. The paper aims to enable accurate polygon matching without supervision by leveraging pre-trained models and a hybrid feature strategy.

Method: A three-stage pipeline: 1) Mask extraction using a pre-trained Segment Anything model to obtain masks; 2) Vectorization converting masks to polygons and their graph structure; 3) Global matching via a bidirectional-pyramid strategy using a pre-trained LoFTR to handle viewpoint/scale changes, followed by a local matching stage that resolves local disparity discontinuities and topology inconsistencies through local-joint geometry and multi-feature matching with the Hungarian algorithm.

Result: On ScanNet and SceneFlow, using a new evaluation metric, the method achieves state-of-the-art accuracy at competitive speed and shows satisfactory generalization at low cost without any training.

Conclusion: The work demonstrates that marrying pre-trained segmentation and feature-based matching with a lightweight, unsupervised polygon matching pipeline can achieve high accuracy and robust generalization, with low computation and no training requirements.

Abstract: Stereo image matching is a fundamental task in computer vision, photogrammetry and remote sensing, but there is an almost unexplored field, i.e., polygon matching, which faces the following challenges: disparity discontinuity, scale variation, training requirement, and generalization. To address the above-mentioned issues, this paper proposes a novel U(PM)$^2$: low-cost unsupervised polygon matching with pre-trained models by uniting automatically learned and handcrafted features, of which pipeline is as follows: firstly, the detector leverages the pre-trained segment anything model to obtain masks; then, the vectorizer converts the masks to polygons and graphic structure; secondly, the global matcher addresses challenges from global viewpoint changes and scale variation based on bidirectional-pyramid strategy with pre-trained LoFTR; finally, the local matcher further overcomes local disparity discontinuity and topology inconsistency of polygon matching by local-joint geometry and multi-feature matching strategy with Hungarian algorithm. We benchmark our U(PM)$^2$ on the ScanNet and SceneFlow datasets using our proposed new metric, which achieved state-of-the-art accuracy at a competitive speed and satisfactory generalization performance at low cost without any training requirement.

</details>


### [55] [CSGaze: Context-aware Social Gaze Prediction](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.05955)
*Surbhi Madan,Shreya Ghosh,Ramanathan Subramanian,Abhinav Dhall,Tom Gedeon*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: CSGaze is a context-aware multimodal model that predicts social gaze patterns by fusing facial cues with scene context and a speaker-focused attention mechanism; it achieves competitive performance and provides explainability and good generalization.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To improve social gaze prediction in multi-person interactions by leveraging contextual cues from the scene and facial information, addressing robustness across diverse social settings.

Method: A multimodal architecture CSGaze that integrates facial and scene features, with a fine-grained attention module centered on the principal speaker; trained and evaluated on GP-Static, UCO-LAEO, AVA-LAEO, and open-set datasets for generalization; produces attention-based explanations.

Result: Competitive with state-of-the-art methods on the benchmark datasets; contextual cues improve prediction; provides initial explainability via attention scores; demonstrates robustness across diverse scenarios on open-set tests.

Conclusion: Contextual cues and speaker-centric attention enhance social gaze prediction; CSGaze offers a robust, explainable framework with good generalizability to new domains.

Abstract: A person's gaze offers valuable insights into their focus of attention, level of social engagement, and confidence. In this work, we investigate how contextual cues combined with visual scene and facial information can be effectively utilized to predict and interpret social gaze patterns during conversational interactions. We introduce CSGaze, a context aware multimodal approach that leverages facial, scene information as complementary inputs to enhance social gaze pattern prediction from multi-person images. The model also incorporates a fine-grained attention mechanism centered on the principal speaker, which helps in better modeling social gaze dynamics. Experimental results show that CSGaze performs competitively with state-of-the-art methods on GP-Static, UCO-LAEO and AVA-LAEO. Our findings highlight the role of contextual cues in improving social gaze prediction. Additionally, we provide initial explainability through generated attention scores, offering insights into the model's decision-making process. We also demonstrate our model's generalizability by testing our model on open set datasets that demonstrating its robustness across diverse scenarios.

</details>


### [56] [Adaptive Agent Selection and Interaction Network for Image-to-point cloud Registration](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.05965)
*Zhixin Cheng,Xiaotian Yin,Jiacheng Deng,Bohao Liao,Yujia Chen,Xu Zhou,Baoqun Yin,Tianzhu Zhang*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: A cross-modal image-to-point cloud registration framework that uses Iterative Agents Selection (IAS) and Reliable Agents Interaction (RAI) to improve robustness under noise, selecting informative representations and guiding cross-modal interactions; achieves state-of-the-art on RGB-D Scenes v2 and 7-Scenes.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Detection-free cross-modal registration methods using transformers struggle under noisy conditions, where noise disturbs similarity computation and incorrect correspondences arise. Without dedicated mechanisms to select informative and correlated representations across modalities, robustness and accuracy are limited.

Method: Proposes two modules: (1) Iterative Agents Selection (IAS) that enhances structural feature awareness with phase maps and uses reinforcement-learning principles to efficiently select reliable agents; (2) Reliable Agents Interaction (RAI) that leverages the selected agents to guide cross-modal interactions and reduce mismatches, improving robustness.

Result: Extensive experiments on RGB-D Scenes v2 and 7-Scenes benchmarks show the method consistently achieves state-of-the-art performance.

Conclusion: The proposed IAS and RAI framework enhances cross-modal registration by reliably selecting informative agents and guiding their interactions, yielding improved robustness and accuracy under noisy conditions.

Abstract: Typical detection-free methods for image-to-point cloud registration leverage transformer-based architectures to aggregate cross-modal features and establish correspondences. However, they often struggle under challenging conditions, where noise disrupts similarity computation and leads to incorrect correspondences. Moreover, without dedicated designs, it remains difficult to effectively select informative and correlated representations across modalities, thereby limiting the robustness and accuracy of registration. To address these challenges, we propose a novel cross-modal registration framework composed of two key modules: the Iterative Agents Selection (IAS) module and the Reliable Agents Interaction (RAI) module. IAS enhances structural feature awareness with phase maps and employs reinforcement learning principles to efficiently select reliable agents. RAI then leverages these selected agents to guide cross-modal interactions, effectively reducing mismatches and improving overall robustness. Extensive experiments on the RGB-D Scenes v2 and 7-Scenes benchmarks demonstrate that our method consistently achieves state-of-the-art performance.

</details>


### [57] [Commonality in Few: Few-Shot Multimodal Anomaly Detection via Hypergraph-Enhanced Memory](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.05966)
*Yuxuan Lin,Hanjing Yan,Xuan Tong,Yang Chang,Huanzhen Wang,Ziheng Zhou,Shuyong Gao,Yan Wang,Wenqiang Zhang*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: A few-shot unsupervised multimodal industrial anomaly detection method CIF (Commonality In Few) uses hypergraph-based intra-class structural commonality and a memory bank to guide detection, with training-free hypergraph message passing and hyperedge-guided memory search, achieving state-of-the-art results on MVTec 3D-AD and Eyecandies in few-shot settings.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Few-shot multimodal industrial anomaly detection is critical yet underexplored. Limited training samples fail to cover diverse test patterns; leveraging intra-class structural commonality from few examples can improve generalization and reduce false positives.

Method: 1) semantic-aware hypergraph construction to extract intra-class common structures from single-semantic industrial images; 2) a memory bank storing intra-class structural priors guided by the semantic hypergraph; 3) a training-free hypergraph message passing module to update test features and narrow the distribution gap to memory features; 4) a hyperedge-guided memory search to leverage structural information and reduce false positives.

Result: Experimental results on MVTec 3D-AD and Eyecandies show the proposed CIF method outperforms state-of-the-art methods in few-shot settings.

Conclusion: CIF demonstrates that exploiting structural commonality via semantic hypergraphs and memory-guided search is effective for few-shot unsupervised multimodal industrial anomaly detection, with code available at the cited repository.

Abstract: Few-shot multimodal industrial anomaly detection is a critical yet underexplored task, offering the ability to quickly adapt to complex industrial scenarios. In few-shot settings, insufficient training samples often fail to cover the diverse patterns present in test samples. This challenge can be mitigated by extracting structural commonality from a small number of training samples. In this paper, we propose a novel few-shot unsupervised multimodal industrial anomaly detection method based on structural commonality, CIF (Commonality In Few). To extract intra-class structural information, we employ hypergraphs, which are capable of modeling higher-order correlations, to capture the structural commonality within training samples, and use a memory bank to store this intra-class structural prior. Firstly, we design a semantic-aware hypergraph construction module tailored for single-semantic industrial images, from which we extract common structures to guide the construction of the memory bank. Secondly, we use a training-free hypergraph message passing module to update the visual features of test samples, reducing the distribution gap between test features and features in the memory bank. We further propose a hyperedge-guided memory search module, which utilizes structural information to assist the memory search process and reduce the false positive rate. Experimental results on the MVTec 3D-AD dataset and the Eyecandies dataset show that our method outperforms the state-of-the-art (SOTA) methods in few-shot settings. Code is available at https://github.com/Sunny5250/CIF.

</details>


### [58] [Adapted Foundation Models for Breast MRI Triaging in Contrast-Enhanced and Non-Contrast Enhanced Protocols](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.05967)
*Tri-Thien Nguyen,Lorenz A. Kapsner,Tobias Hepp,Shirin Heidarikahkesh,Hannes Schreiter,Luise Brock,Dominika Skwierawska,Dominique Hadler,Julian Hossbach,Evelyn Wenkel,Sabine Ohlmeyer,Frederik B. Laun,Andrzej Liebert,Andreas Maier,Michael Uder,Sebastian Bickelhaupt*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: MST using a DINOv2-based Medical Slice Transformer evaluated on abbreviated breast MRI to rule out BI-RADS >=4. It achieves about AUC 0.77; at 97.5% sensitivity specificity ~19% (contrast-enhanced) and ~17% (non-contrast). External validation AUC also ~0.77 with 88% attention maps rated good/moderate. Not yet ready for clinical deployment; further validation needed.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: MRI is highly sensitive for breast cancer but interpretation is time-consuming. The study explores AI-based pre-screening to triage BI-RADS >=4 lesions and potentially reduce radiologist workload.

Method: Retrospective multicenter study. Internal data: 1,847 single-breast MRIs (377 BI-RADS >=4). External validation: 924 exams (Duke). Four abbreviated protocols tested: T1-weighted early subtraction (T1sub), diffusion-weighted imaging with b=1500 s/mm2 (DWI1500), DWI1500+T2w, and T1sub+T2w. Model: DINOv2-based Medical Slice Transformer (MST). Evaluation with five-fold cross-validation; performance reported at 90%, 95%, 97.5% sensitivity; AUC with DeLong test; false negatives characterized; external attention maps rated for quality.

Result: AUC around 0.77 across setups. At 97.5% sensitivity, highest specificity was 19% (T1sub+T2w) and 17% (DWI1500+T2w). Missed lesions tended to be <10 mm, often non-mass enhancements. External validation AUC 0.77; attention maps in external data deemed good/moderate in 88% of cases.

Conclusion: MST can correctly triage cases without BI-RADS >=4 at modest specificity, achieving ~17–19% specificity at high sensitivity. External validation supports generalizability, but more work is required before clinical implementation.

Abstract: Background: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) has high sensitivity for breast cancer detection, but interpretation is time-consuming. Artificial intelligence may aid in pre-screening. Purpose: To evaluate the DINOv2-based Medical Slice Transformer (MST) for ruling out significant findings (Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System [BI-RADS] >=4) in contrast-enhanced and non-contrast-enhanced abbreviated breast MRI. Materials and Methods: This institutional review board approved retrospective study included 1,847 single-breast MRI examinations (377 BI-RADS >=4) from an in-house dataset and 924 from an external validation dataset (Duke). Four abbreviated protocols were tested: T1-weighted early subtraction (T1sub), diffusion-weighted imaging with b=1500 s/mm2 (DWI1500), DWI1500+T2-weighted (T2w), and T1sub+T2w. Performance was assessed at 90%, 95%, and 97.5% sensitivity using five-fold cross-validation and area under the receiver operating characteristic curve (AUC) analysis. AUC differences were compared with the DeLong test. False negatives were characterized, and attention maps of true positives were rated in the external dataset. Results: A total of 1,448 female patients (mean age, 49 +/- 12 years) were included. T1sub+T2w achieved an AUC of 0.77 +/- 0.04; DWI1500+T2w, 0.74 +/- 0.04 (p=0.15). At 97.5% sensitivity, T1sub+T2w had the highest specificity (19% +/- 7%), followed by DWI1500+T2w (17% +/- 11%). Missed lesions had a mean diameter <10 mm at 95% and 97.5% thresholds for both T1sub and DWI1500, predominantly non-mass enhancements. External validation yielded an AUC of 0.77, with 88% of attention maps rated good or moderate. Conclusion: At 97.5% sensitivity, the MST framework correctly triaged cases without BI-RADS >=4, achieving 19% specificity for contrast-enhanced and 17% for non-contrast-enhanced MRI. Further research is warranted before clinical implementation.

</details>


### [59] [DiA-gnostic VLVAE: Disentangled Alignment-Constrained Vision Language Variational AutoEncoder for Robust Radiology Reporting with Missing Modalities](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.05968)
*Nagur Shareef Shaik,Teja Krishna Cherukuri,Adnan Masood,Dong Hye Ye*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: Proposes DiA-gnostic VLVAE for robust radiology reporting by disentangling shared and modality-specific features to handle missing modalities and reduce spurious fusion, enabling a compact decoder to generate reports.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Clinical radiology data often lacks complete context and suffers from entangled modality information, causing unreliable reports; existing approaches rely on heavy LLMs or static graphs and are not resilient to missing data. There is a need for a compact, robust, and faithful reporting framework.

Method: Mixture-of-Experts based Vision-Language Variational Autoencoder (VLVAE) that disentangles shared vs modality-specific features; constrained optimization enforces orthogonality and alignment between latent spaces; a compact LLaMA-X decoder generates reports; evaluated on IU X-Ray and MIMIC-CXR.

Result: BLEU-4 scores of 0.266 (IU X-Ray) and 0.134 (MIMIC-CXR); the method significantly outperforms state-of-the-art models.

Conclusion: Disentangled alignment improves robustness to missing modalities and yields clinically interpretable, faithful radiology reports with efficient decoding; the approach demonstrates strong cross-dataset generalization.

Abstract: The integration of medical images with clinical context is essential for generating accurate and clinically interpretable radiology reports. However, current automated methods often rely on resource-heavy Large Language Models (LLMs) or static knowledge graphs and struggle with two fundamental challenges in real-world clinical data: (1) missing modalities, such as incomplete clinical context , and (2) feature entanglement, where mixed modality-specific and shared information leads to suboptimal fusion and clinically unfaithful hallucinated findings. To address these challenges, we propose the DiA-gnostic VLVAE, which achieves robust radiology reporting through Disentangled Alignment. Our framework is designed to be resilient to missing modalities by disentangling shared and modality-specific features using a Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) based Vision-Language Variational Autoencoder (VLVAE). A constrained optimization objective enforces orthogonality and alignment between these latent representations to prevent suboptimal fusion. A compact LLaMA-X decoder then uses these disentangled representations to generate reports efficiently. On the IU X-Ray and MIMIC-CXR datasets, DiA has achieved competetive BLEU@4 scores of 0.266 and 0.134, respectively. Experimental results show that the proposed method significantly outperforms state-of-the-art models.

</details>


### [60] [Runtime Safety Monitoring of Deep Neural Networks for Perception: A Survey](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.05982)
*Albert Schotschneider,Svetlana Pavlitska,J. Marius Zöllner*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: A comprehensive survey of runtime safety monitoring for DNN-based perception, classifying approaches into input-level, internal-representation, and output monitors, and outlining their strengths, limitations, mappings to safety concerns, and directions for future research.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: DNNs used in safety-critical perception systems are vulnerable to generalization errors, out-of-distribution (OOD) inputs, and adversarial attacks. Runtime monitors operating alongside DNNs during inference can detect these hazards without modifying the DNN.

Method: Systematic literature review and taxonomy. The paper analyzes state-of-the-art within each monitoring category (inputs, internal representations, outputs), assesses strengths/limitations, maps methods to safety concerns, and identifies open challenges and future research directions.

Result: Proposes a taxonomy of runtime safety monitoring approaches, with cross-category mappings to safety concerns, and a synthesis of gaps and opportunities for future research.

Conclusion: Runtime safety monitoring is a viable approach to enhance DNN safety without modifying models, but there are open challenges (e.g., real-time constraints, benchmarks, evaluative metrics, integration across systems). The paper calls for further research to advance monitoring methods and standards.

Abstract: Deep neural networks (DNNs) are widely used in perception systems for safety-critical applications, such as autonomous driving and robotics. However, DNNs remain vulnerable to various safety concerns, including generalization errors, out-of-distribution (OOD) inputs, and adversarial attacks, which can lead to hazardous failures. This survey provides a comprehensive overview of runtime safety monitoring approaches, which operate in parallel to DNNs during inference to detect these safety concerns without modifying the DNN itself. We categorize existing methods into three main groups: Monitoring inputs, internal representations, and outputs. We analyze the state-of-the-art for each category, identify strengths and limitations, and map methods to the safety concerns they address. In addition, we highlight open challenges and future research directions.

</details>


### [61] [A Dual-Mode ViT-Conditioned Diffusion Framework with an Adaptive Conditioning Bridge for Breast Cancer Segmentation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.05989)
*Prateek Singh,Moumita Dholey,P. K. Vinod*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: A conditional denoising diffusion model with ViT encoder and UNet decoder, augmented by Adaptive Conditioning Bridge, Topological Denoising Consistency loss, and a dual-head setup, achieving state-of-the-art breast ultrasound segmentation with high Dice scores and anatomically plausible outputs; validated by ablation studies.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Overcome limitations of standard CNNs in capturing global context, dealing with low-contrast noise in breast ultrasound, and ensuring anatomically plausible segmentations, especially on small datasets.

Method: Integrates a conditional Denoising Diffusion Model with an enhanced UNet-based decoder and ViT encoder. Introduces Adaptive Conditioning Bridge for multi-scale semantic fusion; Topological Denoising Consistency loss to penalize structural inconsistencies during denoising; dual-head architecture with a lightweight auxiliary head and a noise-prediction head trained with the denoising objective as regularizer.

Result: Achieves Dice scores of 0.96 (BUSI), 0.90 (BrEaST), 0.97 (BUS-UCLM). Ablation studies confirm each component's importance and that outputs are accurate and anatomically plausible.

Conclusion: The proposed framework sets a new state-of-the-art in breast ultrasound segmentation, with components contributing to both accuracy and anatomical plausibility, and offers efficient inference on small datasets via the auxiliary head.

Abstract: In breast ultrasound images, precise lesion segmentation is essential for early diagnosis; however, low contrast, speckle noise, and unclear boundaries make this difficult. Even though deep learning models have demonstrated potential, standard convolutional architectures frequently fall short in capturing enough global context, resulting in segmentations that are anatomically inconsistent. To overcome these drawbacks, we suggest a flexible, conditional Denoising Diffusion Model that combines an enhanced UNet-based generative decoder with a Vision Transformer (ViT) encoder for global feature extraction. We introduce three primary innovations: 1) an Adaptive Conditioning Bridge (ACB) for efficient, multi-scale fusion of semantic features; 2) a novel Topological Denoising Consistency (TDC) loss component that regularizes training by penalizing structural inconsistencies during denoising; and 3) a dual-head architecture that leverages the denoising objective as a powerful regularizer, enabling a lightweight auxiliary head to perform rapid and accurate inference on smaller datasets and a noise prediction head. Our framework establishes a new state-of-the-art on public breast ultrasound datasets, achieving Dice scores of 0.96 on BUSI, 0.90 on BrEaST and 0.97 on BUS-UCLM. Comprehensive ablation studies empirically validate that the model components are critical for achieving these results and for producing segmentations that are not only accurate but also anatomically plausible.

</details>


### [62] [Exploring Category-level Articulated Object Pose Tracking on SE(3) Manifolds](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.05996)
*Xianhui Meng,Yukang Huo,Li Zhang,Liu Liu,Haonan Jiang,Yan Zhong,Pingrui Zhang,Cewu Lu,Jun Liu*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: PPF-Tracker introduces a point-pair feature based framework for multi-frame pose tracking of articulated objects, using quasi-canonicalization in SE(3) and SE(3)-invariant PPF-based pose voting, with joint-axis semantic constraints to enforce unified kinematic relations, achieving strong generalization in both synthetic and real data.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Articulated-object pose tracking is underexplored and challenging due to kinematic constraints and complexity of non-rigid parts; existing methods often struggle to generalize across diverse articulations and environments.

Method: The method first quasi-canonicalizes point clouds in SE(3) space, then models articulated objects with Point Pair Features (PPF) to predict pose voting parameters, leveraging SE(3) invariance. It also integrates semantic information of joint axes to impose unified kinematic constraints across all parts.

Result: PPF-Tracker demonstrates strong generalization across synthetic and real datasets, robust multi-frame pose tracking in challenging environments, and improved effectiveness over baselines as reported in the abstract.

Conclusion: This approach advances robotics, embodied intelligence, and augmented reality by providing a principled, invariant, and constraint-consistent framework for articulated-object pose tracking; code is publicly available.

Abstract: Articulated objects are prevalent in daily life and robotic manipulation tasks. However, compared to rigid objects, pose tracking for articulated objects remains an underexplored problem due to their inherent kinematic constraints. To address these challenges, this work proposes a novel point-pair-based pose tracking framework, termed \textbf{PPF-Tracker}. The proposed framework first performs quasi-canonicalization of point clouds in the SE(3) Lie group space, and then models articulated objects using Point Pair Features (PPF) to predict pose voting parameters by leveraging the invariance properties of SE(3). Finally, semantic information of joint axes is incorporated to impose unified kinematic constraints across all parts of the articulated object. PPF-Tracker is systematically evaluated on both synthetic datasets and real-world scenarios, demonstrating strong generalization across diverse and challenging environments. Experimental results highlight the effectiveness and robustness of PPF-Tracker in multi-frame pose tracking of articulated objects. We believe this work can foster advances in robotics, embodied intelligence, and augmented reality. Codes are available at https://github.com/mengxh20/PPFTracker.

</details>


### [63] [On Accurate and Robust Estimation of 3D and 2D Circular Center: Method and Application to Camera-Lidar Calibration](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06611)
*Jiajun Jiang,Xiao Hu,Wancheng Liu,Wei Jiang*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: Proposes a principled LiDAR-camera extrinsic calibration framework for circular targets with two innovations: (1) a robust 3D circle center estimator using conformal geometric algebra and RANSAC; (2) a chord-length variance minimization to recover the true 2D projected center, disambiguated via homography validation or quasi-RANSAC. Demonstrates improved accuracy on synthetic and real data, including natural circular objects, with code forthcoming.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Accurate 3D-2D circle center correspondence is hard due to decoupled 3D circle fitting and 2D ellipse-center estimation, leading to errors in extrinsic calibration; existing methods often fail under diverse targets and sensor configurations.

Method: Two-step geometry-based approach: (i) derive the 3D circle center using conformal geometric algebra (CGA) representations and RANSAC to robustly fit circles to 3D lidar observations; (ii) recover the 2D projected center by minimizing chord-length variance of the projected circle, resolving dual-minima ambiguity with either homography validation or a fallback quasi-RANSAC procedure.

Result: Extensive experiments on synthetic and real datasets show the method significantly outperforms state-of-the-art, reducing extrinsic estimation error and enabling robust calibration across varied sensors and circular targets, including natural circular objects.

Conclusion: Provides a geometrically principled, robust calibration framework with publicly release code, broadening applicability to diverse circular targets and improving 3D-2D correspondences in extrinsic calibration.

Abstract: Circular targets are widely used in LiDAR-camera extrinsic calibration due to their geometric consistency and ease of detection. However, achieving accurate 3D-2D circular center correspondence remains challenging. Existing methods often fail due to decoupled 3D fitting and erroneous 2D ellipse-center estimation. To address this, we propose a geometrically principled framework featuring two innovations: (i) a robust 3D circle center estimator based on conformal geometric algebra and RANSAC; and (ii) a chord-length variance minimization method to recover the true 2D projected center, resolving its dual-minima ambi- guity via homography validation or a quasi-RANSAC fallback. Evaluated on synthetic and real-world datasets, our framework significantly outperforms state-of-the-art approaches. It reduces extrinsic estimation error and enables robust calibration across diverse sensors and target types, including natural circular objects. Our code will be publicly released for reproducibility.

</details>


### [64] [MALeR: Improving Compositional Fidelity in Layout-Guided Generation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06002)
*Shivank Saxena,Dhruv Srivastava,Makarand Tapaswi*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: MALeR improves layout-guided text-to-image generation by preventing subjects from leaving given layouts and by using a masked, attribute-aware binding to avoid attribute leakage, yielding better compositional accuracy and multi-attribute rendering.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Current layout-guided generation struggles with subjects appearing outside layouts, distribution shifts, and attribute bleed in complex scenes with multiple subjects and attributes.

Method: MALeR introduces (i) layout-constrained generation to keep subjects inside specified layouts and in-distribution, and (ii) a masked, attribute-aware binding mechanism to prevent attribute leakage across subjects in compositional scenes.

Result: Qualitative and quantitative experiments show superior compositional accuracy, generation consistency, and attribute binding compared to prior work, especially for scenes with multiple subjects and multiple attributes per subject.

Conclusion: MALeR effectively addresses key challenges in compositional, layout-guided image generation and outperforms previous methods.

Abstract: Recent advances in text-to-image models have enabled a new era of creative and controllable image generation. However, generating compositional scenes with multiple subjects and attributes remains a significant challenge. To enhance user control over subject placement, several layout-guided methods have been proposed. However, these methods face numerous challenges, particularly in compositional scenes. Unintended subjects often appear outside the layouts, generated images can be out-of-distribution and contain unnatural artifacts, or attributes bleed across subjects, leading to incorrect visual outputs. In this work, we propose MALeR, a method that addresses each of these challenges. Given a text prompt and corresponding layouts, our method prevents subjects from appearing outside the given layouts while being in-distribution. Additionally, we propose a masked, attribute-aware binding mechanism that prevents attribute leakage, enabling accurate rendering of subjects with multiple attributes, even in complex compositional scenes. Qualitative and quantitative evaluation demonstrates that our method achieves superior performance in compositional accuracy, generation consistency, and attribute binding compared to previous work. MALeR is particularly adept at generating images of scenes with multiple subjects and multiple attributes per subject.

</details>


### [65] [PanoNav: Mapless Zero-Shot Object Navigation with Panoramic Scene Parsing and Dynamic Memory](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06840)
*Qunchao Jin,Yilin Wu,Changhao Chen*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: PanoNav is an RGB-only, mapless zero-shot object navigation system that adds panoramic scene parsing and a dynamic bounded memory queue to improve decision-making, achieving superior SR and SPL on a public benchmark.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Zero-shot object navigation in unseen environments is hard without depth or prebuilt maps. Mapless approaches often lack historical context, causing local deadlocks. A fully RGB-only method that leverages panoramic perception and memory can unlock better spatial reasoning.

Method: Introduce Panoramic Scene Parsing to extract spatial semantics from panoramic RGB inputs for MLLMs, and a Memory-guided Decision-Making module with a Dynamic Bounded Memory Queue to include exploration history and mitigate deadlocks in mapless ZSON.

Result: On a public navigation benchmark, PanoNav significantly outperforms representative baselines in both Success Rate (SR) and SPL (Trajectory Efficiency).

Conclusion: PanoNav demonstrates that combining panoramic RGB-based spatial parsing with memory-aware decision-making can effectively enhance mapless ZSON, leveraging MLLMs without depth or maps.

Abstract: Zero-shot object navigation (ZSON) in unseen environments remains a challenging problem for household robots, requiring strong perceptual understanding and decision-making capabilities. While recent methods leverage metric maps and Large Language Models (LLMs), they often depend on depth sensors or prebuilt maps, limiting the spatial reasoning ability of Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs). Mapless ZSON approaches have emerged to address this, but they typically make short-sighted decisions, leading to local deadlocks due to a lack of historical context. We propose PanoNav, a fully RGB-only, mapless ZSON framework that integrates a Panoramic Scene Parsing module to unlock the spatial parsing potential of MLLMs from panoramic RGB inputs, and a Memory-guided Decision-Making mechanism enhanced by a Dynamic Bounded Memory Queue to incorporate exploration history and avoid local deadlocks. Experiments on the public navigation benchmark show that PanoNav significantly outperforms representative baselines in both SR and SPL metrics.

</details>


### [66] [How Reasoning Influences Intersectional Biases in Vision Language Models](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06005)
*Adit Desai,Sudipta Roy,Mohna Chakraborty*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: VLMs exhibit biased reasoning when predicting occupations from faces, revealing intersectional disparities; such reasoning diverges from human value-aligned thinking and persists across models, prompts, and data, underscoring the need for alignment before deployment.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To understand how training data biases in Vision-Language Models propagate into their reasoning processes, and how this affects fairness and downstream performance in socially sensitive tasks like occupation prediction.

Method: Analyze five open-source VLMs on the FairFace dataset across 32 occupations and three prompting styles. For each instance, collect both the model’s prediction and its reasoning (chain-of-thought style) to assess how biases manifest in the reasoning process.

Result: Biased reasoning patterns systematically underpin intersectional disparities across models, occupations, and prompts. The reasoning diverges from human-valued interpretations, indicating that VLMs can perpetuate harmful social biases even when predictions seem reasonable.

Conclusion: To ensure safe and fair deployment, there is a critical need to align VLM reasoning with human values or implement robust bias-mitigation and alignment strategies before downstream use.

Abstract: Vision Language Models (VLMs) are increasingly deployed across downstream tasks, yet their training data often encode social biases that surface in outputs. Unlike humans, who interpret images through contextual and social cues, VLMs process them through statistical associations, often leading to reasoning that diverges from human reasoning. By analyzing how a VLM reasons, we can understand how inherent biases are perpetuated and can adversely affect downstream performance. To examine this gap, we systematically analyze social biases in five open-source VLMs for an occupation prediction task, on the FairFace dataset. Across 32 occupations and three different prompting styles, we elicit both predictions and reasoning. Our findings reveal that the biased reasoning patterns systematically underlie intersectional disparities, highlighting the need to align VLM reasoning with human values prior to its downstream deployment.

</details>


### [67] [Aerial Image Stitching Using IMU Data from a UAV](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06841)
*Selim Ahmet Iz,Mustafa Unel*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: A UAV image-stitching method that fuses IMU data with computer vision to estimate motion, correct distortions, and compute a robust homography, yielding improved stitching accuracy and reliability over feature-based methods in challenging UAV scenarios.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Feature-based stitching struggles with detection/matching errors and perspective distortions in UAV imagery; incorporating inertial measurements can provide robust motion estimates and improve alignment in large displacements and pose variations.

Method: Integrate IMU-derived displacement and rotation estimates between consecutive frames with vision-based steps to correct perspective distortion and compute a homography, followed by a standard image-stitching pipeline to align and blend images. The approach aims to be easily integrable into existing UAV workflows.

Result: Experiments show the proposed IMU-assisted approach yields higher accuracy and reliability than some existing feature-based stitching methods, particularly under large displacements, rotations, and camera pose variations.

Conclusion: Leveraging IMU data within the image-stitching pipeline enhances robustness and can be readily integrated into UAV workflows for more reliable large-area stitching.

Abstract: Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) are widely used for aerial photography and remote sensing applications. One of the main challenges is to stitch together multiple images into a single high-resolution image that covers a large area. Featurebased image stitching algorithms are commonly used but can suffer from errors and ambiguities in feature detection and matching. To address this, several approaches have been proposed, including using bundle adjustment techniques or direct image alignment. In this paper, we present a novel method that uses a combination of IMU data and computer vision techniques for stitching images captured by a UAV. Our method involves several steps such as estimating the displacement and rotation of the UAV between consecutive images, correcting for perspective distortion, and computing a homography matrix. We then use a standard image stitching algorithm to align and blend the images together. Our proposed method leverages the additional information provided by the IMU data, corrects for various sources of distortion, and can be easily integrated into existing UAV workflows. Our experiments demonstrate the effectiveness and robustness of our method, outperforming some of the existing feature-based image stitching algorithms in terms of accuracy and reliability, particularly in challenging scenarios such as large displacements, rotations, and variations in camera pose.

</details>


### [68] [Distributed Deep Learning for Medical Image Denoising with Data Obfuscation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06006)
*Sulaimon Oyeniyi Adebayo,Ayaz H. Khan*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: U-Net++ generally outperforms U-Net in denoising chest X-ray images under various noise levels, with competitive PSNR/SSIM and better structural fidelity, while optimized distributed training delivers large speedups with minimal accuracy loss.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address privacy/efficiency concerns in medical imaging by denoising noisy images on large-scale datasets using lightweight obfuscation, and evaluate architectural choices (U-Net vs U-Net++) and distributed training strategies (single-GPU, DataParallel, DDP with AMP).

Method: Dataset: NIH Chest X-ray14; noise: additive Gaussian; models: U-Net and U-Net++; training setups: single-GPU, standard DataParallel, and DistributedDataParallel with Automatic Mixed Precision; evaluation metrics: PSNR, SSIM, LPIPS; compare training time and accuracy; public implementation at: https://github.com/Suadey/medical-image-denoising-ddp.

Result: U-Net++ delivers superior denoising quality in terms of PSNR and SSIM across noise levels, while LPIPS lags behind U-Net at low to moderate noise (indicating slightly lower perceptual similarity). Optimized distributed training reduces training time by >60% versus single-GPU for both models and beats standard DataParallel by >40%, with only a minor drop in accuracy. The study demonstrates that software-level optimization in distributed learning can meaningfully accelerate medical imaging pipelines without sacrificing too much performance, enabling practical deployment with architectural and obfuscation strategies.

Conclusion: Combining architectural design (U-Net++), lightweight obfuscation, and advanced distributed training (DDP + AMP) is viable for fast, accurate medical image denoising on large datasets, offering tangible speedups and robust denoising performance; implementation is publicly available for real-world adoption.

Abstract: Medical image denoising is essential for improving image quality while minimizing the exposure of sensitive information, particularly when working with large-scale clinical datasets. This study explores distributed deep learning for denoising chest X-ray images from the NIH Chest X-ray14 dataset, using additive Gaussian noise as a lightweight obfuscation technique. We implement and evaluate U-Net and U-Net++ architectures under single-GPU, standard multi-GPU (DataParallel), and optimized multi-GPU training configurations using PyTorch's DistributedDataParallel (DDP) and Automatic Mixed Precision (AMP). Our results show that U-Net++ consistently delivers superior denoising performance, achieving competitive Peak Signal to Noise Ratio (PSNR) and Structured Similarity Index Method (SSIM) scores, though with less performance in Learned Perceptual Image Patch Similarity (LPIPS) compared to U-Net under low and moderate noise levels. This indicates U-Net++'s enhanced structural fidelity and low perceptual similarity. Meanwhile, our optimized training pipeline reduces training time by over 60% for both models compared to single-GPU training, and outperforms standard DataParallel by over 40%, with only a minor accuracy drop for both models (trading some accuracy for speed). These findings highlight the effectiveness of software-level optimization in distributed learning for medical imaging. This work demonstrates the practical viability of combining architectural design, lightweight obfuscation, and advanced distributed training strategies to accelerate and enhance medical image processing pipelines in real-world clinical and research environments. The full implementation is publicly available at: https://github.com/Suadey/medical-image-denoising-ddp.

</details>


### [69] [Real-Time LiDAR Super-Resolution via Frequency-Aware Multi-Scale Fusion](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.07377)
*June Moh Goo,Zichao Zeng,Jan Boehm*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: FLASH is a dual-domain LiDAR super-resolution framework that combines frequency-aware window attention with adaptive multi-scale fusion to achieve state-of-the-art results on KITTI using a single forward pass.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To improve LiDAR super-resolution by capturing both fine-grained geometry and global scanning patterns without relying on computationally expensive stochastic inference or purely spatial-domain methods.

Method: Two innovations: (1) Frequency-Aware Window Attention that blends local spatial attention with global frequency-domain analysis via FFT for log-linear complexity; (2) Adaptive Multi-Scale Fusion with learned, position-specific feature aggregation and CBAM-based dynamic feature selection, enabling multi-scale, dual-domain fusion without traditional skip connections.

Result: Achieves state-of-the-art performance on KITTI across evaluation metrics, surpassing uncertainty-enhanced baselines that require multiple forward passes; outperforms TULIP with Monte Carlo Dropout while maintaining single-pass efficiency, enabling real-time deployment.

Conclusion: Dual-domain processing effectively handles uncertainty through architectural design rather than stochastic inference, making FLASH practical for autonomous LiDAR perception.

Abstract: LiDAR super-resolution addresses the challenge of achieving high-quality 3D perception from cost-effective, low-resolution sensors. While recent transformer-based approaches like TULIP show promise, they remain limited to spatial-domain processing with restricted receptive fields. We introduce FLASH (Frequency-aware LiDAR Adaptive Super-resolution with Hierarchical fusion), a novel framework that overcomes these limitations through dual-domain processing. FLASH integrates two key innovations: (i) Frequency-Aware Window Attention that combines local spatial attention with global frequency-domain analysis via FFT, capturing both fine-grained geometry and periodic scanning patterns at log-linear complexity. (ii) Adaptive Multi-Scale Fusion that replaces conventional skip connections with learned position-specific feature aggregation, enhanced by CBAM attention for dynamic feature selection. Extensive experiments on KITTI demonstrate that FLASH achieves state-of-the-art performance across all evaluation metrics, surpassing even uncertainty-enhanced baselines that require multiple forward passes. Notably, FLASH outperforms TULIP with Monte Carlo Dropout while maintaining single-pass efficiency, which enables real-time deployment. The consistent superiority across all distance ranges validates that our dual-domain approach effectively handles uncertainty through architectural design rather than computationally expensive stochastic inference, making it practical for autonomous systems.

</details>


### [70] [One-Shot Knowledge Transfer for Scalable Person Re-Identification](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06016)
*Longhua Li,Lei Qi,Xin Geng*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: OSKT (One-Shot Knowledge Transfer) consolidates a teacher's knowledge into a weight chain to enable expansion to any target model size without extra computation, outperforming existing compression methods.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Edge ReID requires lightweight models to reduce cloud load and protect privacy. Conventional compression needs separate training for each target model, which is inefficient when multiple sizes are needed.

Method: Knowledge is transferred once into an intermediate carrier called a weight chain (the teacher’s knowledge). When a downstream scenario requires a model of a certain size, the weight chain is expanded to that size without additional computations.

Result: OSKT outperforms state-of-the-art compression methods and offers a one-time transfer, eliminating the need for repeated computations for each target model.

Conclusion: OSKT enables efficient, scalable deployment of ReID models on edge devices by enabling size-flexible models with no extra downstream computation.

Abstract: Edge computing in person re-identification (ReID) is crucial for reducing the load on central cloud servers and ensuring user privacy. Conventional compression methods for obtaining compact models require computations for each individual student model. When multiple models of varying sizes are needed to accommodate different resource conditions, this leads to repetitive and cumbersome computations. To address this challenge, we propose a novel knowledge inheritance approach named OSKT (One-Shot Knowledge Transfer), which consolidates the knowledge of the teacher model into an intermediate carrier called a weight chain. When a downstream scenario demands a model that meets specific resource constraints, this weight chain can be expanded to the target model size without additional computation. OSKT significantly outperforms state-of-the-art compression methods, with the added advantage of one-time knowledge transfer that eliminates the need for frequent computations for each target model.

</details>


### [71] [TwinOR: Photorealistic Digital Twins of Dynamic Operating Rooms for Embodied AI Research](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.07412)
*Han Zhang,Yiqing Shen,Roger D. Soberanis-Mukul,Ankita Ghosh,Hao Ding,Lalithkumar Seenivasan,Jose L. Porras,Zhekai Mao,Chenjia Li,Wenjie Xiao,Lonny Yarmus,Angela Christine Argento,Masaru Ishii,Mathias Unberath*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: TwinOR creates photorealistic, dynamic digital twins of operating rooms to safely develop embodied AI. It reconstructs static geometry from pre-scan videos, models dynamic motion via multi-view sensing, and fuses everything into an immersive 3D environment for controllable simulation and benchmarking.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Safe, controllable environments are needed for continual learning and evaluation of embodied AI in ORs, but real-world ORs impose safety and regulatory constraints that limit unrestricted perception and interaction. Digital twins offer high-fidelity, risk-free platforms for exploration and benchmarking.

Method: Reconstruct static OR geometry from pre-scan videos and continuously model human and equipment motion through multi-view perception of OR activities. Fuse static and dynamic components into an immersive 3D environment that supports controllable simulation and embodied exploration.

Result: Achieves centimeter-level geometry accuracy and preserves dynamic interactions across surgical workflows. Enables realistic renderings and a virtual playground for embodied AI. On TwinOR-synthesized data, perception systems like FoundationStereo and ORB-SLAM3 perform comparably to their performance on real indoor datasets, indicating sensor-level realism sufficient for perception and localization tasks.

Conclusion: Establishes a real-to-sim pipeline for dynamic, photorealistic OR digital twins, enabling safe, scalable, and data-efficient development and benchmarking of embodied AI and accelerating sim-to-real deployment.

Abstract: Developing embodied AI for intelligent surgical systems requires safe, controllable environments for continual learning and evaluation. However, safety regulations and operational constraints in operating rooms (ORs) limit embodied agents from freely perceiving and interacting in realistic settings. Digital twins provide high-fidelity, risk-free environments for exploration and training. How we may create photorealistic and dynamic digital representations of ORs that capture relevant spatial, visual, and behavioral complexity remains unclear. We introduce TwinOR, a framework for constructing photorealistic, dynamic digital twins of ORs for embodied AI research. The system reconstructs static geometry from pre-scan videos and continuously models human and equipment motion through multi-view perception of OR activities. The static and dynamic components are fused into an immersive 3D environment that supports controllable simulation and embodied exploration. The proposed framework reconstructs complete OR geometry with centimeter level accuracy while preserving dynamic interaction across surgical workflows, enabling realistic renderings and a virtual playground for embodied AI systems. In our experiments, TwinOR simulates stereo and monocular sensor streams for geometry understanding and visual localization tasks. Models such as FoundationStereo and ORB-SLAM3 on TwinOR-synthesized data achieve performance within their reported accuracy on real indoor datasets, demonstrating that TwinOR provides sensor-level realism sufficient for perception and localization challenges. By establishing a real-to-sim pipeline for constructing dynamic, photorealistic digital twins of OR environments, TwinOR enables the safe, scalable, and data-efficient development and benchmarking of embodied AI, ultimately accelerating the deployment of embodied AI from sim-to-real.

</details>


### [72] [MiVID: Multi-Strategic Self-Supervision for Video Frame Interpolation using Diffusion Model](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06019)
*Priyansh Srivastava,Romit Chatterjee,Abir Sen,Aradhana Behura,Ratnakar Dash*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: MiVID: a lightweight, self-supervised diffusion-based video frame interpolation (VFI) framework that avoids explicit motion estimation by using a 3D U-Net backbone with transformer-style temporal attention and a hybrid masking regime; trained on CPU with 9-frame segments, achieving competitive results after 50 epochs on UCF101-7 and DAVIS-7.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Tackle occlusions, domain shifts, and ambiguous motion in VFI while reducing reliance on dense ground-truth and expensive optical-flow methods. Propose a scalable, low-resource, self-supervised approach using diffusion priors for temporally coherent frame synthesis.

Method: A 3D U-Net backbone augmented with transformer-style temporal attention. Diffusion-based frame synthesis guided by a hybrid masking regime that simulates occlusions and motion uncertainty. Cosine-based progressive masking and adaptive loss scheduling enable robust spatiotemporal representation learning without high-frame-rate supervision. Trained end-to-end on CPU using 9-frame video segments.

Result: MiVID achieves optimal results at 50 epochs and is competitive with several supervised baselines on UCF101-7 and DAVIS-7, demonstrating strong performance under self-supervised diffusion priors for temporally coherent frame synthesis.

Conclusion: This work establishes MiVID as a scalable, accessible VFI system that leverages self-supervised diffusion priors to achieve temporally coherent frame interpolation, enabling generalizable VFI with reduced computational resources.

Abstract: Video Frame Interpolation (VFI) remains a cornerstone in video enhancement, enabling temporal upscaling for tasks like slow-motion rendering, frame rate conversion, and video restoration. While classical methods rely on optical flow and learning-based models assume access to dense ground-truth, both struggle with occlusions, domain shifts, and ambiguous motion. This article introduces MiVID, a lightweight, self-supervised, diffusion-based framework for video interpolation. Our model eliminates the need for explicit motion estimation by combining a 3D U-Net backbone with transformer-style temporal attention, trained under a hybrid masking regime that simulates occlusions and motion uncertainty. The use of cosine-based progressive masking and adaptive loss scheduling allows our network to learn robust spatiotemporal representations without any high-frame-rate supervision. Our framework is evaluated on UCF101-7 and DAVIS-7 datasets. MiVID is trained entirely on CPU using the datasets and 9-frame video segments, making it a low-resource yet highly effective pipeline. Despite these constraints, our model achieves optimal results at just 50 epochs, competitive with several supervised baselines.This work demonstrates the power of self-supervised diffusion priors for temporally coherent frame synthesis and provides a scalable path toward accessible and generalizable VFI systems.

</details>


### [73] [Towards Implicit Aggregation: Robust Image Representation for Place Recognition in the Transformer Era](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06024)
*Feng Lu,Tong Jin,Canming Ye,Yunpeng Liu,Xiangyuan Lan,Chun Yuan*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: A transformer-based VPR approach that uses learnable aggregation tokens inserted into the patch token sequence to implicitly aggregate features, eliminating the need for a separate aggregator; achieves state-of-the-art performance including MSLS, with improved efficiency; provides token insertion and initialization strategies; open-source.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: The backbone-plus-aggregator paradigm dominates visual place recognition (VPR); however, in the transformer era, explicit aggregators may be redundant. The goal is to obtain robust global descriptors using only the backbone by introducing learnable aggregation tokens, and to study where/how to insert them and how to initialize them to maximize performance and efficiency.

Method: Introduce learnable aggregation tokens prepended to patch tokens before a transformer block. All tokens interact via self-attention, implicitly aggregating information into the aggregation tokens. The global descriptor is formed by concatenating the aggregation tokens from the last output. The paper also proposes an optimal token insertion strategy and token initialization method derived from empirical studies.

Result: The proposed method outperforms state-of-the-art methods on multiple VPR datasets, with higher efficiency, and ranks 1st on the MSLS challenge leaderboard. Code is provided at the authors' repository.

Conclusion: Dedicated aggregators are unnecessary in the transformer era; robust global descriptors can be obtained using a backbone with learnable aggregation tokens. The insertion strategy and initialization are crucial. The approach yields superior accuracy and efficiency for VPR, validated on standard benchmarks.

Abstract: Visual place recognition (VPR) is typically regarded as a specific image retrieval task, whose core lies in representing images as global descriptors. Over the past decade, dominant VPR methods (e.g., NetVLAD) have followed a paradigm that first extracts the patch features/tokens of the input image using a backbone, and then aggregates these patch features into a global descriptor via an aggregator. This backbone-plus-aggregator paradigm has achieved overwhelming dominance in the CNN era and remains widely used in transformer-based models. In this paper, however, we argue that a dedicated aggregator is not necessary in the transformer era, that is, we can obtain robust global descriptors only with the backbone. Specifically, we introduce some learnable aggregation tokens, which are prepended to the patch tokens before a particular transformer block. All these tokens will be jointly processed and interact globally via the intrinsic self-attention mechanism, implicitly aggregating useful information within the patch tokens to the aggregation tokens. Finally, we only take these aggregation tokens from the last output tokens and concatenate them as the global representation. Although implicit aggregation can provide robust global descriptors in an extremely simple manner, where and how to insert additional tokens, as well as the initialization of tokens, remains an open issue worthy of further exploration. To this end, we also propose the optimal token insertion strategy and token initialization method derived from empirical studies. Experimental results show that our method outperforms state-of-the-art methods on several VPR datasets with higher efficiency and ranks 1st on the MSLS challenge leaderboard. The code is available at https://github.com/lu-feng/image.

</details>


### [74] [S2ML: Spatio-Spectral Mutual Learning for Depth Completion](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06033)
*Zihui Zhao,Yifei Zhang,Zheng Wang,Yang Li,Kui Jiang,Zihan Geng,Chia-Wen Lin*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: A spatio-spectral mutual learning framework (S2ML) for depth completion that fuses spatial and frequency-domain features, accounting for amplitude and phase spectra, achieving state-of-the-art gains over CFormer on NYU-Depth V2 and SUN RGB-D.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Raw depth images from TOF/structured light often have missing values due to weak reflections, shadows, and artifacts. Existing image-domain depth completion methods ignore the physical characteristics and frequency distribution of raw depth, which can be altered by invalid regions. This work seeks to leverage both spatial and spectral priors to improve depth completion.

Method: Propose Spatio-Spectral Mutual Learning (S2ML) framework. It includes a dedicated spectral fusion module that treats amplitude and phase spectra distinctly, and computes local and global correlations between spatial-domain and frequency-domain features in a unified embedding space. The model uses gradual mutual representation and refinement to enable cross-domain learning and improved depth completion.

Result: Experiments show the method outperforms the state-of-the-art CFormer by 0.828 dB on NYU-Depth V2 and by 0.834 dB on SUN RGB-D.

Conclusion: S2ML effectively harnesses spatio-spectral priors and mutual learning to enhance depth completion for raw depth images, demonstrating notable improvements and highlighting the importance of considering spectral characteristics in depth completion tasks.

Abstract: The raw depth images captured by RGB-D cameras using Time-of-Flight (TOF) or structured light often suffer from incomplete depth values due to weak reflections, boundary shadows, and artifacts, which limit their applications in downstream vision tasks. Existing methods address this problem through depth completion in the image domain, but they overlook the physical characteristics of raw depth images. It has been observed that the presence of invalid depth areas alters the frequency distribution pattern. In this work, we propose a Spatio-Spectral Mutual Learning framework (S2ML) to harmonize the advantages of both spatial and frequency domains for depth completion. Specifically, we consider the distinct properties of amplitude and phase spectra and devise a dedicated spectral fusion module. Meanwhile, the local and global correlations between spatial-domain and frequency-domain features are calculated in a unified embedding space. The gradual mutual representation and refinement encourage the network to fully explore complementary physical characteristics and priors for more accurate depth completion. Extensive experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of our proposed S2ML method, outperforming the state-of-the-art method CFormer by 0.828 dB and 0.834 dB on the NYU-Depth V2 and SUN RGB-D datasets, respectively.

</details>


### [75] [StreamSTGS: Streaming Spatial and Temporal Gaussian Grids for Real-Time Free-Viewpoint Video](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06046)
*Zhihui Ke,Yuyang Liu,Xiaobo Zhou,Tie Qiu*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: StreamSTGS enables real-time streaming of free-viewpoint video by representing dynamic scenes with canonical 3D Gaussians, per-frame 2D encodings, and a deformation field; it achieves high compression (~170 KB/frame) while maintaining competitive quality (≈1 dB PSNR gain) and supports adaptive bitrate without extra training.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Real-time streaming FVV is hindered by heavy storage and bandwidth requirements of 3D Gaussian Splatting methods (up to ~10 MB/frame). There is a need for an efficient representation and training-free adaptive streaming to handle network variability while preserving visual fidelity.

Method: Represent dynamic scenes using canonical 3D Gaussians, temporal features, and a deformation field. Encode canonical Gaussian attributes as 2D images and temporal features as a video for high compression. Introduce a sliding window to aggregate local temporal features for local motion and a transformer-guided auxiliary training module to learn global motions. The design supports adaptive bitrate by network conditions without extra training.

Result: On diverse FVV benchmarks, StreamSTGS is competitive across metrics, improves PSNR by ~1 dB on average, and reduces per-frame size to ~170 KB, enabling real-time streaming. Code is publicly available.

Conclusion: StreamSTGS offers a practical, high-compression, real-time streaming solution for FVV by combining latent 3D Gaussian representations with temporally-encoded features and a deformation field, along with motion-learning mechanisms and adaptive bitrate capability.

Abstract: Streaming free-viewpoint video~(FVV) in real-time still faces significant challenges, particularly in training, rendering, and transmission efficiency. Harnessing superior performance of 3D Gaussian Splatting~(3DGS), recent 3DGS-based FVV methods have achieved notable breakthroughs in both training and rendering. However, the storage requirements of these methods can reach up to $10$MB per frame, making stream FVV in real-time impossible. To address this problem, we propose a novel FVV representation, dubbed StreamSTGS, designed for real-time streaming. StreamSTGS represents a dynamic scene using canonical 3D Gaussians, temporal features, and a deformation field. For high compression efficiency, we encode canonical Gaussian attributes as 2D images and temporal features as a video. This design not only enables real-time streaming, but also inherently supports adaptive bitrate control based on network condition without any extra training. Moreover, we propose a sliding window scheme to aggregate adjacent temporal features to learn local motions, and then introduce a transformer-guided auxiliary training module to learn global motions. On diverse FVV benchmarks, StreamSTGS demonstrates competitive performance on all metrics compared to state-of-the-art methods. Notably, StreamSTGS increases the PSNR by an average of $1$dB while reducing the average frame size to just $170$KB. The code is publicly available on https://github.com/kkkzh/StreamSTGS.

</details>


### [76] [Neodragon: Mobile Video Generation using Diffusion Transformer](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06055)
*Animesh Karnewar,Denis Korzhenkov,Ioannis Lelekas,Adil Karjauv,Noor Fathima,Hanwen Xiong,Vancheeswaran Vaidyanathan,Will Zeng,Rafael Esteves,Tushar Singhal,Fatih Porikli,Mohsen Ghafoorian,Amirhossein Habibian*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: Mobile-optimized text-to-video system (Neodragon) that runs 49-frame videos on-device in 6.7s on a Qualcomm Hexagon NPU, using distillation, pruning, and efficient decoding to achieve high-fidelity video with ~4.95B params and 3.5GB peak RAM.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Enable private, low-latency text-to-video generation on mobile devices, addressing cloud dependency, data privacy, bandwidth costs, and hardware constraints of mobile platforms.

Method: Four technical contributions: (1) Text-Encoder Distillation replacing 4.762B T5xL with 0.2B DistilT5; (2) Asymmetric Decoder Distillation to substitute the native codec-latent-VAE decoder while preserving latent space; (3) Pruning of MMDiT blocks with a two-stage distillation to recover performance; (4) Reducing Neural Functional Evaluations via step distillation with DMD adapted for pyramidal flow-matching. End-to-end pipeline includes an optimized SSD1B first-frame image generator and QuickSRNet 2x upscaling; total ~4.945B parameters, 3.5GB peak RAM, 6.7s end-to-end latency, 81.61 VBench."

Result: Demonstrates that mobile hardware can support efficient, high-fidelity text-to-video generation with end-to-end latency of 6.7s for a 2-second video (49 frames @24fps) at 640x1024, using a compact model and targeted distillation/pruning strategies; achieves on-device private T2V without cloud services; VBench score 81.61.

Conclusion: The work shows the feasibility of on-device T2V on mobile hardware with strong efficiency gains and privacy benefits. It hinges on specialized hardware (Hexagon NPU) and tailored distillation/pruning techniques; public release of code/models will help validate generalizability and enable broader adoption, but device dependence and energy consumption considerations remain areas for further study.

Abstract: We introduce Neodragon, a text-to-video system capable of generating 2s (49 frames @24 fps) videos at the 640x1024 resolution directly on a Qualcomm Hexagon NPU in a record 6.7s (7 FPS). Differing from existing transformer-based offline text-to-video generation models, Neodragon is the first to have been specifically optimised for mobile hardware to achieve efficient and high-fidelity video synthesis. We achieve this through four key technical contributions: (1) Replacing the original large 4.762B T5xxl Text-Encoder with a much smaller 0.2B DT5 (DistilT5) with minimal quality loss, enabled through a novel Text-Encoder Distillation procedure. (2) Proposing an Asymmetric Decoder Distillation approach allowing us to replace the native codec-latent-VAE decoder with a more efficient one, without disturbing the generative latent-space of the generation pipeline. (3) Pruning of MMDiT blocks within the denoiser backbone based on their relative importance, with recovery of original performance through a two-stage distillation process. (4) Reducing the NFE (Neural Functional Evaluation) requirement of the denoiser by performing step distillation using DMD adapted for pyramidal flow-matching, thereby substantially accelerating video generation. When paired with an optimised SSD1B first-frame image generator and QuickSRNet for 2x super-resolution, our end-to-end Neodragon system becomes a highly parameter (4.945B full model), memory (3.5GB peak RAM usage), and runtime (6.7s E2E latency) efficient mobile-friendly model, while achieving a VBench total score of 81.61. By enabling low-cost, private, and on-device text-to-video synthesis, Neodragon democratizes AI-based video content creation, empowering creators to generate high-quality videos without reliance on cloud services. Code and model will be made publicly available at our website: https://qualcomm-ai-research.github.io/neodragon

</details>


### [77] [LoopExpose: An Unsupervised Framework for Arbitrary-Length Exposure Correction](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06066)
*Ao Li,Chen Chen,Zhenyu Wang,Tao Huang,Fangfang Wu,Weisheng Dong*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: LoopExpose is an unsupervised exposure correction framework that uses pseudo-labels and a two-level nested optimization with a feedback loop and a luminance ranking loss, achieving state-of-the-art performance among unsupervised methods.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Labels for exposure correction are scarce; there is a need for robust, generalizable exposure correction under challenging lighting without large labeled datasets.

Method: A two-level loop: upper level trains a correction model using pseudo-labels generated by a lower-level multi-exposure fusion module; corrected images feed back to refine pseudo-labels; incorporates a Luminance Ranking Loss to exploit relative luminance order across the input sequence.

Result: Extensive experiments on benchmark datasets show LoopExpose outperforms existing state-of-the-art unsupervised methods in both exposure correction and fusion performance; code is available online.

Conclusion: Demonstrates that self-reinforcing unsupervised learning with pseudo-labels and luminance-based self-supervision can achieve strong exposure correction without labeled data, suggesting broader applicability to unsupervised image enhancement.

Abstract: Exposure correction is essential for enhancing image quality under challenging lighting conditions. While supervised learning has achieved significant progress in this area, it relies heavily on large-scale labeled datasets, which are difficult to obtain in practical scenarios. To address this limitation, we propose a pseudo label-based unsupervised method called LoopExpose for arbitrary-length exposure correction. A nested loop optimization strategy is proposed to address the exposure correction problem, where the correction model and pseudo-supervised information are jointly optimized in a two-level framework. Specifically, the upper-level trains a correction model using pseudo-labels generated through multi-exposure fusion at the lower level. A feedback mechanism is introduced where corrected images are fed back into the fusion process to refine the pseudo-labels, creating a self-reinforcing learning loop. Considering the dominant role of luminance calibration in exposure correction, a Luminance Ranking Loss is introduced to leverage the relative luminance ordering across the input sequence as a self-supervised constraint. Extensive experiments on different benchmark datasets demonstrate that LoopExpose achieves superior exposure correction and fusion performance, outperforming existing state-of-the-art unsupervised methods. Code is available at https://github.com/FALALAS/LoopExpose.

</details>


### [78] [An Artificial Intelligence-based Assistant for the Visually Impaired](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06080)
*Luis Marquez-Carpintero,Francisco Gomez-Donoso,Zuria Bauer,Bessie Dominguez-Dager,Alvaro Belmonte-Baeza,Mónica Pina-Navarro,Francisco Morillas-Espejo,Felix Escalona,Miguel Cazorla*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: An AI assistant named AIDEN (2023–2024) helps visually impaired users by identifying objects, reading text, and answering environment-related questions using YOLO-based object detection and a Large Language and Vision Assistant, with user-centered interaction methods; user feedback suggests improved autonomy and daily usability.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Visually impaired individuals face object identification, reading, and navigation challenges; existing aids like Braille, audio books, and screen readers are not universally effective.

Method: Integrates YOLO-based object detection and a Large Language and Vision Assistant; includes interaction methods to access textual and visual information in an accessible way.

Result: The system aims to enhance user autonomy and access to information; user feedback indicates improved daily usability.

Conclusion: AIDEN holds promise for increasing independence and information access for visually impaired individuals, demonstrating potential for broader impact.

Abstract: This paper describes an artificial intelligence-based assistant application, AIDEN, developed during 2023 and 2024, aimed at improving the quality of life for visually impaired individuals. Visually impaired individuals face challenges in identifying objects, reading text, and navigating unfamiliar environments, which can limit their independence and reduce their quality of life. Although solutions such as Braille, audio books, and screen readers exist, they may not be effective in all situations. This application leverages state-of-the-art machine learning algorithms to identify and describe objects, read text, and answer questions about the environment. Specifically, it uses You Only Look Once architectures and a Large Language and Vision Assistant. The system incorporates several methods to facilitate the user's interaction with the system and access to textual and visual information in an appropriate manner. AIDEN aims to enhance user autonomy and access to information, contributing to an improved perception of daily usability, as supported by user feedback.

</details>


### [79] [Hybrid CNN-ViT Framework for Motion-Blurred Scene Text Restoration](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06087)
*Umar Rashid,Muhammad Arslan Arshad,Ghulam Ahmad,Muhammad Zeeshan Anjum,Rizwan Khan,Muhammad Akmal*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: A CNN-Transformer hybrid for motion-blur scene text restoration; achieves PSNR 32.20 dB and SSIM 0.934 with 2.83M params and 61 ms inference, trained on synthetic blurred samples derived from TextOCR.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Motion blur severely degrades scene-text readability and hinders CV tasks. Spatially varying blur and the need to model long-range dependencies challenge traditional deblurring; a hybrid CNN-ViT aims to capture both local details and global context.

Method: CNN-based encoder-decoder preserves structural details; a transformer module provides global awareness via self-attention. Training on a TextOCR-derived dataset with synthetic motion-blur kernels of multiple sizes/orientations. Loss combines MAE, MSE, perceptual loss, and SSIM. Model has 2.83M parameters and ~61 ms average inference time.

Result: PSNR 32.20 dB and SSIM 0.934 achieved on evaluated benchmarks; model is lightweight and efficient, suitable for real-time use.

Conclusion: The CNN-ViT hybrid design effectively restores motion-blurred scene text while remaining computationally efficient, making it practical for real-world deployment and downstream tasks in CV pipelines.

Abstract: Motion blur in scene text images severely impairs readability and hinders the reliability of computer vision tasks, including autonomous driving, document digitization, and visual information retrieval. Conventional deblurring approaches are often inadequate in handling spatially varying blur and typically fall short in modeling the long-range dependencies necessary for restoring textual clarity. To overcome these limitations, we introduce a hybrid deep learning framework that combines convolutional neural networks (CNNs) with vision transformers (ViTs), thereby leveraging both local feature extraction and global contextual reasoning. The architecture employs a CNN-based encoder-decoder to preserve structural details, while a transformer module enhances global awareness through self-attention. Training is conducted on a curated dataset derived from TextOCR, where sharp scene-text samples are paired with synthetically blurred versions generated using realistic motion-blur kernels of multiple sizes and orientations. Model optimization is guided by a composite loss that incorporates mean absolute error (MAE), squared error (MSE), perceptual similarity, and structural similarity (SSIM). Quantitative evaluations show that the proposed method attains 32.20 dB in PSNR and 0.934 in SSIM, while remaining lightweight with 2.83 million parameters and an average inference time of 61 ms.
