Departing from the conventional least-squares loss used for Gaussian noise, we introduce a generalized Gaussian scale mixture-based loss, which approximates a wide range of noise distributions and leads to an $\ell_q$-norm ($0<q\leq2$) fidelity term. This optimization problem is addressed using an iteratively reweighted least squares (IRLS) approach, wherein the proximal step involving the generative prior is efficiently performed via a diffusion-based denoiser. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate that the proposed method effectively removes non-Gaussian impulse noise and achieves superior restoration performance.

</details>


### [157] [MUGSQA: Novel Multi-Uncertainty-Based Gaussian Splatting Quality Assessment Method, Dataset, and Benchmarks](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06830)
*Tianang Chen,Jian Jin,Shilv Cai,Zhuangzi Li,Weisi Lin*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: Proposes unified multi-distance perceptual quality assessment for Gaussian Splatting-based 3D reconstructions, plus MUGSQA dataset and two robustness/metrics benchmarks; code to be released.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Perceptual quality assessment of GS-based 3D reconstructions is an open challenge. Existing metrics may not reflect real human viewing experiences, and evaluations should be robust to real-world data uncertainties.

Method: Introduce a unified multi-distance subjective testing protocol that mimics human viewing for GS-based reconstructions; construct the MUGSQA dataset considering uncertainties in input data (quantity and resolution of input views, view distance, initial point cloud accuracy); design two benchmarks: one evaluating robustness of GS-based reconstructions under multiple uncertainties, and another evaluating performance of existing quality assessment metrics.

Result: Presents a perceptual evaluation protocol, the MUGSQA dataset, and two benchmarks to enable standardized perceptual assessment and robust evaluation of GS-based reconstructions; dataset and benchmark code to be released soon.

Conclusion: The work provides standardized perceptual evaluation resources for GS-based reconstructions, enabling fair comparisons across methods under real-world uncertainties and supporting the development of perceptually-guided improvements.

Abstract: Gaussian Splatting (GS) has recently emerged as a promising technique for 3D object reconstruction, delivering high-quality rendering results with significantly improved reconstruction speed. As variants continue to appear, assessing the perceptual quality of 3D objects reconstructed with different GS-based methods remains an open challenge. To address this issue, we first propose a unified multi-distance subjective quality assessment method that closely mimics human viewing behavior for objects reconstructed with GS-based methods in actual applications, thereby better collecting perceptual experiences. Based on it, we also construct a novel GS quality assessment dataset named MUGSQA, which is constructed considering multiple uncertainties of the input data. These uncertainties include the quantity and resolution of input views, the view distance, and the accuracy of the initial point cloud. Moreover, we construct two benchmarks: one to evaluate the robustness of various GS-based reconstruction methods under multiple uncertainties, and the other to evaluate the performance of existing quality assessment metrics. Our dataset and benchmark code will be released soon.

</details>


### [158] [ConsistTalk: Intensity Controllable Temporally Consistent Talking Head Generation with Diffusion Noise Search](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06833)
*Zhenjie Liu,Jianzhang Lu,Renjie Lu,Cong Liang,Shangfei Wang*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: ConsistTalk introduces an intensity-controllable, temporally consistent talking head generation framework using diffusion models, featuring an optical flow-guided temporal module (OFT), an Audio-to-Intensity (A2I) model via multimodal teacher-student distillation, and a diffusion noise initialization strategy (IC-Init) to reduce flicker, preserve identity, and improve audio-visual synchronization.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Current video diffusion-based talking head methods suffer from flicker, identity drift, and poor synchronization due to entangled appearance-motion representations and unstable inference. There is a need for decoupled motion-appearance modeling, controllable dynamics, and stable inference.

Method: Proposes OFT to decouple motion from static appearance using optical flow; A2I model learned via multimodal teacher-student distillation to map audio and facial velocity into a frame-wise intensity sequence for joint modeling; IC-Init diffusion noise initialization strategy to constrain background coherence and motion continuity during inference-time noise search; overall diffusion-noise search inference.

Result: Empirical results show ConsistTalk outperforms prior methods in reducing flicker, preserving identity, and delivering temporally stable, high-fidelity talking head videos across datasets and metrics.

Conclusion: ConsistTalk demonstrates that decoupled motion-appearance representations and controlled diffusion noise can substantially improve audio-driven talking head generation, enabling finer motion control and better synchronization while preserving identity.

Abstract: Recent advancements in video diffusion models have significantly enhanced audio-driven portrait animation. However, current methods still suffer from flickering, identity drift, and poor audio-visual synchronization. These issues primarily stem from entangled appearance-motion representations and unstable inference strategies. In this paper, we introduce \textbf{ConsistTalk}, a novel intensity-controllable and temporally consistent talking head generation framework with diffusion noise search inference. First, we propose \textbf{an optical flow-guided temporal module (OFT)} that decouples motion features from static appearance by leveraging facial optical flow, thereby reducing visual flicker and improving temporal consistency. Second, we present an \textbf{Audio-to-Intensity (A2I) model} obtained through multimodal teacher-student knowledge distillation. By transforming audio and facial velocity features into a frame-wise intensity sequence, the A2I model enables joint modeling of audio and visual motion, resulting in more natural dynamics. This further enables fine-grained, frame-wise control of motion dynamics while maintaining tight audio-visual synchronization. Third, we introduce a \textbf{diffusion noise initialization strategy (IC-Init)}. By enforcing explicit constraints on background coherence and motion continuity during inference-time noise search, we achieve better identity preservation and refine motion dynamics compared to the current autoregressive strategy. Extensive experiments demonstrate that ConsistTalk significantly outperforms prior methods in reducing flicker, preserving identity, and delivering temporally stable, high-fidelity talking head videos.

</details>


### [159] [NeuroBridge: Bio-Inspired Self-Supervised EEG-to-Image Decoding via Cognitive Priors and Bidirectional Semantic Alignment](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06836)
*Wenjiang Zhang,Sifeng Wang,Yuwei Su,Xinyu Li,Chen Zhang,Suyu Zhong*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: A self-supervised cross-modal framework, NeuroBridge, uses Cognitive Prior Augmentation and a Shared Semantic Projector to align EEG and visual stimuli for neural visual decoding, achieving state-of-the-art intra-subject performance on a 200-way zero-shot task.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: There is a scarcity of high-quality stimulus-brain pairs and a semantic mismatch between neural representations and visual content. Biological perceptual variability and co-adaptive processing motivate a robust cross-modal alignment strategy.

Method: Cognitive Prior Augmentation applies asymmetric, modality-specific transformations to EEG and images to simulate perceptual variability, while the Shared Semantic Projector enables a bidirectional, co-adaptive alignment that maps both modalities into a shared semantic space for cross-modal learning.

Result: NeuroBridge surpasses prior state-of-the-art in both intra-subject and inter-subject settings. Intra-subject gains include +12.3% top-1 accuracy and +10.2% top-5 accuracy, reaching 63.2% top-1 and 89.9% top-5 on a 200-way zero-shot retrieval task.

Conclusion: The framework demonstrates effective, robust, and scalable neural visual decoding, with potential impacts on brain-computer interfaces and AI by enabling better cross-modal understanding between brain activity and visual stimuli.

Abstract: Visual neural decoding seeks to reconstruct or infer perceived visual stimuli from brain activity patterns, providing critical insights into human cognition and enabling transformative applications in brain-computer interfaces and artificial intelligence. Current approaches, however, remain constrained by the scarcity of high-quality stimulus-brain response pairs and the inherent semantic mismatch between neural representations and visual content. Inspired by perceptual variability and co-adaptive strategy of the biological systems, we propose a novel self-supervised architecture, named NeuroBridge, which integrates Cognitive Prior Augmentation (CPA) with Shared Semantic Projector (SSP) to promote effective cross-modality alignment. Specifically, CPA simulates perceptual variability by applying asymmetric, modality-specific transformations to both EEG signals and images, enhancing semantic diversity. Unlike previous approaches, SSP establishes a bidirectional alignment process through a co-adaptive strategy, which mutually aligns features from two modalities into a shared semantic space for effective cross-modal learning. NeuroBridge surpasses previous state-of-the-art methods under both intra-subject and inter-subject settings. In the intra-subject scenario, it achieves the improvements of 12.3% in top-1 accuracy and 10.2% in top-5 accuracy, reaching 63.2% and 89.9% respectively on a 200-way zero-shot retrieval task. Extensive experiments demonstrate the effectiveness, robustness, and scalability of the proposed framework for neural visual decoding.

</details>


### [160] [Gaussian-Augmented Physics Simulation and System Identification with Complex Colliders](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06846)
*Federico Vasile,Ri-Zhao Qiu,Lorenzo Natale,Xiaolong Wang*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: AS-DiffMPM proposes a differentiable Material Point Method with differentiable collision handling for arbitrarily shaped colliders, enabling end-to-end optimization and system identification from video, interfacing with novel view synthesis.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Current differentiable MPM methods rely on planar colliders, limiting interaction realism and accuracy for non-planar surfaces in video-based property estimation.

Method: Introduce a differentiable collision mechanism into MPM to handle interaction with complex rigid bodies and integrate with novel view synthesis, enabling end-to-end optimization for estimating physical properties from visual observations.

Result: AS-DiffMPM demonstrates compatibility with various view synthesis methods as a framework for system identification from visual observations and enables physical property estimation with arbitrarily shaped colliders.

Conclusion: Extends differentiable MPM to arbitrarily shaped colliders, enhancing realism and applicability in system identification from videos in robotics and graphics.

Abstract: System identification involving the geometry, appearance, and physical properties from video observations is a challenging task with applications in robotics and graphics. Recent approaches have relied on fully differentiable Material Point Method (MPM) and rendering for simultaneous optimization of these properties. However, they are limited to simplified object-environment interactions with planar colliders and fail in more challenging scenarios where objects collide with non-planar surfaces. We propose AS-DiffMPM, a differentiable MPM framework that enables physical property estimation with arbitrarily shaped colliders. Our approach extends existing methods by incorporating a differentiable collision handling mechanism, allowing the target object to interact with complex rigid bodies while maintaining end-to-end optimization. We show AS-DiffMPM can be easily interfaced with various novel view synthesis methods as a framework for system identification from visual observations.

</details>


### [161] [Distillation Dynamics: Towards Understanding Feature-Based Distillation in Vision Transformers](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06848)
*Huiyuan Tian,Bonan Xu Shijian Li*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: Feature-based distillation can harm ViTs due to a representational mismatch; successful transfer requires strategies beyond naive feature mimicry that respect ViT's frequency and capacity constraints.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Explain why feature-based knowledge distillation fails for Vision Transformers and provide theoretical guidance for designing effective ViT compression methods.

Method: Propose 'distillation dynamics', an analytical framework combining frequency spectrum analysis, information entropy metrics, and activation magnitude tracking to study KD behavior in ViTs; reveal a U-shaped information processing pattern and a mismatch between teacher's high-dimensional encodings and the student's limited channel capacity.

Result: Identify root cause of negative transfer as representational paradigm mismatch; late-layer feature alignment by KD can harm performance; establish that effective transfer requires methods that respect representational constraints; provide source code and logs.

Conclusion: Naive feature mimicry is insufficient for ViT compression; theoretical guidance suggests designing KD methods that align with ViT’s distributed encoding and capacity constraints.

Abstract: While feature-based knowledge distillation has proven highly effective for compressing CNNs, these techniques unexpectedly fail when applied to Vision Transformers (ViTs), often performing worse than simple logit-based distillation. We provide the first comprehensive analysis of this phenomenon through a novel analytical framework termed as ``distillation dynamics", combining frequency spectrum analysis, information entropy metrics, and activation magnitude tracking. Our investigation reveals that ViTs exhibit a distinctive U-shaped information processing pattern: initial compression followed by expansion. We identify the root cause of negative transfer in feature distillation: a fundamental representational paradigm mismatch between teacher and student models. Through frequency-domain analysis, we show that teacher models employ distributed, high-dimensional encoding strategies in later layers that smaller student models cannot replicate due to limited channel capacity. This mismatch causes late-layer feature alignment to actively harm student performance. Our findings reveal that successful knowledge transfer in ViTs requires moving beyond naive feature mimicry to methods that respect these fundamental representational constraints, providing essential theoretical guidance for designing effective ViTs compression strategies. All source code and experimental logs are provided in the supplementary material.

</details>


### [162] [Ambiguity-aware Truncated Flow Matching for Ambiguous Medical Image Segmentation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06857)
*Fanding Li,Xiangyu Li,Xianghe Su,Xingyu Qiu,Suyu Dong,Wei Wang,Kuanquan Wang,Gongning Luo,Shuo Li*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: ATFM presents Ambiguity-aware Truncated Flow Matching for AMIS, introducing Data-Hierarchical Inference, Gaussian Truncation Representation, and Segmentation Flow Matching to improve accuracy and diversity with efficient inference, achieving state-of-the-art metrics on LIDC and ISIC3.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Ambiguous medical image segmentation (AMIS) faces a persistent trade-off between accuracy and prediction diversity. Existing truncated diffusion probabilistic models entangle fidelity and diversity, limiting practical performance. This work proposes a holistic approach to disentangle and enhance both aspects by rethinking inference, modeling, and flow-based segmentation.

Method: Data-Hierarchical Inference redefines AMIS-specific inference to boost data-distribution accuracy and per-sample diversity. Gaussian Truncation Representation models the truncation distribution as a Gaussian at the truncation horizon T_trunc, improving fidelity and truncation reliability over sampling-based methods. Segmentation Flow Matching extends semantic-aware flow transformation from Flow Matching to boost the plausibility of diverse predictions. These components are combined in ATFM and evaluated on LIDC and ISIC3.

Result: ATFM outperforms state-of-the-art methods on AMIS benchmarks LIDC and ISIC3, with improved GED and HM-IoU by up to 12% and 7.3%, respectively, and exhibits more efficient inference.

Conclusion: ATFM provides a cohesive framework for disentangling accuracy and diversity in AMIS, delivering enhanced fidelity, plausibility, and efficiency. The introduced Data-Hierarchical Inference, Gaussian Truncation Representation, and Segmentation Flow Matching collectively advance the state-of-the-art in AMIS.

Abstract: A simultaneous enhancement of accuracy and diversity of predictions remains a challenge in ambiguous medical image segmentation (AMIS) due to the inherent trade-offs. While truncated diffusion probabilistic models (TDPMs) hold strong potential with a paradigm optimization, existing TDPMs suffer from entangled accuracy and diversity of predictions with insufficient fidelity and plausibility. To address the aforementioned challenges, we propose Ambiguity-aware Truncated Flow Matching (ATFM), which introduces a novel inference paradigm and dedicated model components. Firstly, we propose Data-Hierarchical Inference, a redefinition of AMIS-specific inference paradigm, which enhances accuracy and diversity at data-distribution and data-sample level, respectively, for an effective disentanglement. Secondly, Gaussian Truncation Representation (GTR) is introduced to enhance both fidelity of predictions and reliability of truncation distribution, by explicitly modeling it as a Gaussian distribution at $T_{\text{trunc}}$ instead of using sampling-based approximations.Thirdly, Segmentation Flow Matching (SFM) is proposed to enhance the plausibility of diverse predictions by extending semantic-aware flow transformation in Flow Matching (FM). Comprehensive evaluations on LIDC and ISIC3 datasets demonstrate that ATFM outperforms SOTA methods and simultaneously achieves a more efficient inference. ATFM improves GED and HM-IoU by up to $12\%$ and $7.3\%$ compared to advanced methods.

</details>


### [163] [VAEVQ: Enhancing Discrete Visual Tokenization through Variational Modeling](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06863)
*Sicheng Yang,Xing Hu,Qiang Wu,Dawei Yang*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: A new VQ-based generative framework, VAEVQ, improves codeword usage and cross-domain coherence by replacing AE with a VAE for latent quantization, and adding adaptive coherence and distribution regularization.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To address non-smooth latent spaces, misalignment between pre- and post-quantization representations, and poor coherence between continuous and discrete domains in VQ-based pipelines, which lead to unstable codeword learning and underutilized codebooks, hurting reconstruction and generation.

Method: Three components: (1) Variational Latent Quantization (VLQ) replaces AE with a VAE for smoother, structured latent spaces to enhance codeword activation; (2) Representation Coherence Strategy (RCS) adaptively modulates alignment strength between pre- and post-quantization features to improve consistency and avoid overfitting to noise; (3) Distribution Consistency Regularization (DCR) aligns the codebook distribution with the continuous latent distribution to improve codebook utilization.

Result: Extensive experiments on two benchmark datasets show that VAEVQ outperforms state-of-the-art methods in reconstruction and downstream generation tasks.

Conclusion: The proposed VLQ-RCS-DCR framework improves codeword utilization, coherence between domains, and overall generation quality, demonstrating the effectiveness of variational latent quantization and distribution alignment in VQ-based models.

Abstract: Vector quantization (VQ) transforms continuous image features into discrete representations, providing compressed, tokenized inputs for generative models. However, VQ-based frameworks suffer from several issues, such as non-smooth latent spaces, weak alignment between representations before and after quantization, and poor coherence between the continuous and discrete domains. These issues lead to unstable codeword learning and underutilized codebooks, ultimately degrading the performance of both reconstruction and downstream generation tasks. To this end, we propose VAEVQ, which comprises three key components: (1) Variational Latent Quantization (VLQ), replacing the AE with a VAE for quantization to leverage its structured and smooth latent space, thereby facilitating more effective codeword activation; (2) Representation Coherence Strategy (RCS), adaptively modulating the alignment strength between pre- and post-quantization features to enhance consistency and prevent overfitting to noise; and (3) Distribution Consistency Regularization (DCR), aligning the entire codebook distribution with the continuous latent distribution to improve utilization. Extensive experiments on two benchmark datasets demonstrate that VAEVQ outperforms state-of-the-art methods.

</details>


### [164] [Generating an Image From 1,000 Words: Enhancing Text-to-Image With Structured Captions](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06876)
*Eyal Gutflaish,Eliran Kachlon,Hezi Zisman,Tal Hacham,Nimrod Sarid,Alexander Visheratin,Saar Huberman,Gal Davidi,Guy Bukchin,Kfir Goldberg,Ron Mokady*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: Open-source text-to-image model trained on long captions with fine-grained attributes, using DimFusion and TaBR to improve controllability and expressiveness; results show top prompt alignment among open models; weights released.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Current text-to-image systems rely on short prompts, leading to limited controllability and bias toward average preferences. Long, structured captions with consistent attribute annotations promise disjoint control over visual factors and richer outputs, addressing a gap between input and output detail.

Method: Train on long structured captions with uniform attribute annotations; introduce DimFusion to fuse intermediate tokens from a lightweight LLM without increasing token length; propose TaBR evaluation by reconstructing real images via a captioning-generation loop to measure controllability for long captions.

Result: Train the large model FIBO achieving state-of-the-art prompt alignment among open-source models; public release of model weights on HuggingFace.

Conclusion: Long-caption training with controlled attributes and DimFusion/TaBR substantially improves controllability and expressiveness in open-source T2I models, enabling more precise professional use and setting a new evaluation standard.

Abstract: Text-to-image models have rapidly evolved from casual creative tools to professional-grade systems, achieving unprecedented levels of image quality and realism. Yet, most models are trained to map short prompts into detailed images, creating a gap between sparse textual input and rich visual outputs. This mismatch reduces controllability, as models often fill in missing details arbitrarily, biasing toward average user preferences and limiting precision for professional use. We address this limitation by training the first open-source text-to-image model on long structured captions, where every training sample is annotated with the same set of fine-grained attributes. This design maximizes expressive coverage and enables disentangled control over visual factors. To process long captions efficiently, we propose DimFusion, a fusion mechanism that integrates intermediate tokens from a lightweight LLM without increasing token length. We also introduce the Text-as-a-Bottleneck Reconstruction (TaBR) evaluation protocol. By assessing how well real images can be reconstructed through a captioning-generation loop, TaBR directly measures controllability and expressiveness, even for very long captions where existing evaluation methods fail. Finally, we demonstrate our contributions by training the large-scale model FIBO, achieving state-of-the-art prompt alignment among open-source models. Model weights are publicly available at https://huggingface.co/briaai/FIBO

</details>


### [165] [A Two-Stage System for Layout-Controlled Image Generation using Large Language Models and Diffusion Models](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06888)
*Jan-Hendrik Koch,Jonas Krumme,Konrad Gadzicki*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: A decoupled two-stage text-to-image pipeline—LLM-driven layout planning followed by a layout-conditioned diffusion model—enables precise object counts and spatial arrangements in generated images, with object recall dramatically improved (57.2% to 99.9%), and a trade-off between ControlNet (textual control but more hallucination) and GLIGEN (layout fidelity but less prompt controllability) after domain-specific fine-tuning.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Current text-to-image diffusion models struggle to enforce exact object counts and spatial layouts, limiting compositional control. A modular approach could separate spatial planning from image synthesis to improve recall and fidelity.

Method: Stage 1: Use an LLM to generate a structured layout from a list of objects. Stage 2: Use a layout-conditioned diffusion model to synthesize a photorealistic image adhering to the layout. Improve recall by simplifying the initial generation to core objects and completing the layout with rule-based insertion. Compare two conditioning methods—ControlNet and GLIGEN—after domain-specific finetuning on table-setting datasets.

Result: The approach yields high object recall (increasing from 57.2% to 99.9% for complex scenes) and a viable end-to-end system that produces images with specified object counts and plausible spatial arrangements. ControlNet preserves text-based stylistic control but suffers from object hallucination; GLIGEN offers superior layout fidelity but reduced prompt-based controllability.

Conclusion: A decoupled planning-and-synthesis architecture is viable for compositionally controlled image synthesis. The choice between ControlNet and GLIGEN involves a trade-off between prompt controllability and layout fidelity; overall, the method demonstrates robust, controllable generation by separating spatial planning from image synthesis.

Abstract: Text-to-image diffusion models exhibit remarkable generative capabilities, but lack precise control over object counts and spatial arrangements. This work introduces a two-stage system to address these compositional limitations. The first stage employs a Large Language Model (LLM) to generate a structured layout from a list of objects. The second stage uses a layout-conditioned diffusion model to synthesize a photorealistic image adhering to this layout. We find that task decomposition is critical for LLM-based spatial planning; by simplifying the initial generation to core objects and completing the layout with rule-based insertion, we improve object recall from 57.2% to 99.9% for complex scenes. For image synthesis, we compare two leading conditioning methods: ControlNet and GLIGEN. After domain-specific finetuning on table-setting datasets, we identify a key trade-off: ControlNet preserves text-based stylistic control but suffers from object hallucination, while GLIGEN provides superior layout fidelity at the cost of reduced prompt-based controllability. Our end-to-end system successfully generates images with specified object counts and plausible spatial arrangements, demonstrating the viability of a decoupled approach for compositionally controlled synthesis.

</details>


### [166] [Adaptive Morph-Patch Transformer for Arotic Vessel Segmentation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06897)
*Zhenxi Zhang,Fuchen Zheng,Adnan Iltaf,Yifei Han,Zhenyu Cheng,Yue Du,Bin Li,Tianyong Liu,Shoujun Zhou*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: Adaptive Morph Patch Transformer (MPT) for aortic vascular segmentation uses morphology-aware patching and Semantic Clustering Attention to preserve vascular structure and achieve state-of-the-art results on AVT, AortaSeg24, and TBAD.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Fixed-size patches in transformer-based models disrupt complex vascular geometries; morphology-aware partitioning and semantically-guided aggregation are needed to maintain structure integrity and segment vessels of varying sizes.

Method: Proposes adaptive patch partitioning that aligns patches with vascular morphology; introduces Semantic Clustering Attention to dynamically aggregate features from patches with similar semantics; evaluated on three open datasets (AVT, AortaSeg24, TBAD).

Result: Achieves state-of-the-art performance with notable improvements in segmenting intricate vascular structures across datasets.

Conclusion: MPT effectively preserves semantic integrity of vascular structures and improves segmentation accuracy, indicating potential clinical impact for diagnosis and treatment planning.

Abstract: Accurate segmentation of aortic vascular structures is critical for diagnosing and treating cardiovascular diseases.Traditional Transformer-based models have shown promise in this domain by capturing long-range dependencies between vascular features. However, their reliance on fixed-size rectangular patches often influences the integrity of complex vascular structures, leading to suboptimal segmentation accuracy. To address this challenge, we propose the adaptive Morph Patch Transformer (MPT), a novel architecture specifically designed for aortic vascular segmentation. Specifically, MPT introduces an adaptive patch partitioning strategy that dynamically generates morphology-aware patches aligned with complex vascular structures. This strategy can preserve semantic integrity of complex vascular structures within individual patches. Moreover, a Semantic Clustering Attention (SCA) method is proposed to dynamically aggregate features from various patches with similar semantic characteristics. This method enhances the model's capability to segment vessels of varying sizes, preserving the integrity of vascular structures. Extensive experiments on three open-source dataset(AVT, AortaSeg24 and TBAD) demonstrate that MPT achieves state-of-the-art performance, with improvements in segmenting intricate vascular structures.

</details>


### [167] [Classification of Microplastic Particles in Water using Polarized Light Scattering and Machine Learning Methods](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06901)
*Leonard Saur,Marc von Pawlowski,Ulrich Gengenbach,Ingo Sieber,Hossein Shirali,Lorenz Wührl,Rainer Kiko,Christian Pylatiuk*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: Reflection-based, polarization-sensitive in-situ CNN approach classifies colorless microplastics (50–300 μm) in water with ~80% peak mean accuracy across HDPE, LDPE, PP; AOLP robustness and better discrimination for polyethylene types; DOLP excels at PP; method mitigates transmission interference and emphasizes interior texture/polarization patterns.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Need for continuous, large-scale microplastic monitoring in aquatic environments where transmission-based methods fail; overcome interference from water while remaining scalable.

Method: Illumination with linearly polarized laser; capture reflected signals with polarization-sensitive camera; train deep CNN on image data; perform feature hierarchy analysis; compare AOLP vs DOLP polarization signals; test dataset.

Result: 80% peak mean accuracy; AOLP robust to contextual noise; AOLP superior for distinguishing HDPE vs LDPE; DOLP slightly worse overall but better for identifying PP.

Conclusion: Reflection-based polarization sensing is a promising approach for in-situ microplastic monitoring; polarization features capture microstructure/texture; potential for real-world deployment; requires further validation with broader polymer types and real-water conditions.

Abstract: Facing the critical need for continuous, large-scale microplastic monitoring, which is hindered by the limitations of gold-standard methods in aquatic environments, this paper introduces and validates a novel, reflection-based approach for the in-situ classification and identification of microplastics directly in water bodies, which is based on polarized light scattering. In this experiment, we classify colorless microplastic particles (50-300 $μ$m) by illuminating them with linearly polarized laser light and capturing their reflected signals using a polarization-sensitive camera. This reflection-based technique successfully circumvents the transmission-based interference issues that plague many conventional methods when applied in water. Using a deep convolutional neural network (CNN) for image-based classification, we successfully identified three common polymer types, high-density polyethylene, low-density polyethylene, and polypropylene, achieving a peak mean classification accuracy of 80% on the test dataset. A subsequent feature hierarchy analysis demonstrated that the CNN's decision-making process relies mainly on the microstructural integrity and internal texture (polarization patterns) of the particle rather than its macroshape. Critically, we found that the Angle of Linear Polarization (AOLP) signal is significantly more robust against contextual noise than the Degree of Linear Polarization (DOLP) signal. While the AOLP-based classification achieved superior overall performance, its strength lies in distinguishing between the two polyethylene plastics, showing a lower confusion rate between high-density and low-density polyethylene. Conversely, the DOLP signal demonstrated slightly worse overall classification results but excels at accurately identifying the polypropylene class, which it isolated with greater success than AOLP.

</details>


### [168] [Mono3DVG-EnSD: Enhanced Spatial-aware and Dimension-decoupled Text Encoding for Monocular 3D Visual Grounding](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06908)
*Yuzhen Li,Min Liu,Zhaoyang Li,Yuan Bian,Xueping Wang,Erbo Zhai,Yaonan Wang*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: Mono3DVG-EnSD introduces CLIP-LCA and D2M to address two key issues in Mono3DVG: (1) over-reliance on high-certainty keywords and insufficient spatial descriptions, and (2) cross-dimensional interference from generalized textual features. It achieves SOTA on Mono3DRefer, notably +13.54% in Far(Acc@0.5).


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Existing Mono3DVG methods over-emphasize explicit target keywords and neglect spatial cues, while generalized text blends 2D/3D information causing cross-dimensional interference during visual refinement.

Method: (CLIP-LCA) Dynamically masks high-certainty keywords to emphasize implicit spatial descriptions; (D2M) Decouples 2D/3D textual features from generalized text to guide corresponding visual features at the same dimension, reducing cross-dimensional interference.

Result: State-of-the-art performance on Mono3DRefer, with substantial gains in challenging Far(Acc@0.5) metrics (+13.54%).

Conclusion: The proposed CLIP-LCA and D2M components jointly improve spatial reasoning and dimension-consistent cross-modal interactions, yielding robust improvements across metrics.

Abstract: Monocular 3D Visual Grounding (Mono3DVG) is an emerging task that locates 3D objects in RGB images using text descriptions with geometric cues. However, existing methods face two key limitations. Firstly, they often over-rely on high-certainty keywords that explicitly identify the target object while neglecting critical spatial descriptions. Secondly, generalized textual features contain both 2D and 3D descriptive information, thereby capturing an additional dimension of details compared to singular 2D or 3D visual features. This characteristic leads to cross-dimensional interference when refining visual features under text guidance. To overcome these challenges, we propose Mono3DVG-EnSD, a novel framework that integrates two key components: the CLIP-Guided Lexical Certainty Adapter (CLIP-LCA) and the Dimension-Decoupled Module (D2M). The CLIP-LCA dynamically masks high-certainty keywords while retaining low-certainty implicit spatial descriptions, thereby forcing the model to develop a deeper understanding of spatial relationships in captions for object localization. Meanwhile, the D2M decouples dimension-specific (2D/3D) textual features from generalized textual features to guide corresponding visual features at same dimension, which mitigates cross-dimensional interference by ensuring dimensionally-consistent cross-modal interactions. Through comprehensive comparisons and ablation studies on the Mono3DRefer dataset, our method achieves state-of-the-art (SOTA) performance across all metrics. Notably, it improves the challenging Far(Acc@0.5) scenario by a significant +13.54%.

</details>


### [169] [DTTNet: Improving Video Shadow Detection via Dark-Aware Guidance and Tokenized Temporal Modeling](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06925)
*Zhicheng Li,Kunyang Sun,Rui Yao,Hancheng Zhu,Fuyuan Hu,Jiaqi Zhao,Zhiwen Shao,Yong Zhou*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: DTTNet for video shadow detection integrates vision-language priors via a Vision-language Match Module (VMM) and a Dark-aware Semantic Block (DSB) to disambiguate shadows from dark objects, uses adaptive mask reweighting and edge masks for better supervision, and introduces a Tokenized Temporal Block (TTB) to efficiently model cross-frame shadow dynamics; achieves state-of-the-art accuracy with real-time inference; code available.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Shadow-background ambiguity and dynamic shadow deformations under varying illumination are the core challenges in video shadow detection. The authors seek to leverage cross-modal (vision-language) cues to distinguish shadows from dark objects and design an efficient temporal module to model varying shadow shapes across frames.

Method: The approach combines: (1) Vision-language Match Module (VMM) and Dark-aware Semantic Block (DSB) to extract text-guided features to separate shadows from dark objects; (2) adaptive mask reweighting to downweight penumbra regions during training; (3) edge masks applied at the final decoder stage for stronger supervision; (4) Tokenized Temporal Block (TTB) that decouples spatiotemporal learning by summarizing cross-frame shadow semantics into learnable temporal tokens for efficient sequence encoding.

Result: Comprehensive experiments on multiple benchmark datasets report state-of-the-art accuracy and real-time inference efficiency.

Conclusion: The proposed DTTNet effectively addresses both spatial shadow-background ambiguity and temporal deformation of shadows, achieving superior performance with efficient computation; code is publicly available.

Abstract: Video shadow detection confronts two entwined difficulties: distinguishing shadows from complex backgrounds and modeling dynamic shadow deformations under varying illumination. To address shadow-background ambiguity, we leverage linguistic priors through the proposed Vision-language Match Module (VMM) and a Dark-aware Semantic Block (DSB), extracting text-guided features to explicitly differentiate shadows from dark objects. Furthermore, we introduce adaptive mask reweighting to downweight penumbra regions during training and apply edge masks at the final decoder stage for better supervision. For temporal modeling of variable shadow shapes, we propose a Tokenized Temporal Block (TTB) that decouples spatiotemporal learning. TTB summarizes cross-frame shadow semantics into learnable temporal tokens, enabling efficient sequence encoding with minimal computation overhead. Comprehensive Experiments on multiple benchmark datasets demonstrate state-of-the-art accuracy and real-time inference efficiency. Codes are available at https://github.com/city-cheng/DTTNet.

</details>


### [170] [PlantTraitNet: An Uncertainty-Aware Multimodal Framework for Global-Scale Plant Trait Inference from Citizen Science Data](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06943)
*Ayushi Sharma,Johanna Trost,Daniel Lusk,Johannes Dollinger,Julian Schrader,Christian Rossi,Javier Lopatin,Etienne Laliberté,Simon Haberstroh,Jana Eichel,Daniel Mederer,Jose Miguel Cerda-Paredes,Shyam S. Phartyal,Lisa-Maricia Schwarz,Anja Linstädter,Maria Conceição Caldeira,Teja Kattenborn*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: A multi-modal, uncertainty-aware deep learning framework called PlantTraitNet uses citizen-science plant photos to predict four plant traits (height, leaf area, specific leaf area, nitrogen content) and produce global trait maps, outperforming existing products and validated against independent surveys.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To overcome the limitations of field-based trait measurements (cost and sparse coverage) by leveraging the vast, geotagged citizen-science image datasets to generate scalable global trait maps for ecosystem and Earth system modeling.

Method: A multi-modal, multi-task uncertainty-aware deep learning framework (PlantTraitNet) that uses weak supervision to predict four traits from citizen-science images, aggregates predictions spatially to generate global trait maps, and validates against independent data (sPlotOpen) and benchmarks against leading global trait products.

Result: PlantTraitNet consistently outperforms existing global trait maps for all four traits, yielding more accurate, scalable global trait distributions that align with independent survey data.

Conclusion: Citizen science imagery, when integrated with computer vision and geospatial AI, enables scalable and more accurate global trait mapping, offering a powerful new pathway for ecological research and Earth system modeling.

Abstract: Global plant maps of plant traits, such as leaf nitrogen or plant height, are essential for understanding ecosystem processes, including the carbon and energy cycles of the Earth system. However, existing trait maps remain limited by the high cost and sparse geographic coverage of field-based measurements. Citizen science initiatives offer a largely untapped resource to overcome these limitations, with over 50 million geotagged plant photographs worldwide capturing valuable visual information on plant morphology and physiology. In this study, we introduce PlantTraitNet, a multi-modal, multi-task uncertainty-aware deep learning framework that predictsfour key plant traits (plant height, leaf area, specific leaf area, and nitrogen content) from citizen science photos using weak supervision. By aggregating individual trait predictions across space, we generate global maps of trait distributions. We validate these maps against independent vegetation survey data (sPlotOpen) and benchmark them against leading global trait products. Our results show that PlantTraitNet consistently outperforms existing trait maps across all evaluated traits, demonstrating that citizen science imagery, when integrated with computer vision and geospatial AI, enables not only scalable but also more accurate global trait mapping. This approach offers a powerful new pathway for ecological research and Earth system modeling.

</details>


### [171] [From Attribution to Action: Jointly ALIGNing Predictions and Explanations](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06944)
*Dongsheng Hong,Chao Chen,Yanhui Chen,Shanshan Lin,Zhihao Chen,Xiangwen Liao*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: ALIGN jointly trains a classifier and a masker to generate soft, task-relevant masks and align saliency with masks, using high-quality mask guidance to improve accuracy and explanations across domain generalization benchmarks.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: External or heuristic explanations are often noisy and hard to scale; low-quality supervision can degrade performance. There is a need for high-quality, scalable guidance to improve interpretability and generalization.

Method: Iterative joint training of a classifier and a masker. The masker learns soft masks highlighting informative regions; the classifier is optimized for both predictive accuracy and alignment between its saliency maps and the learned masks. High-quality masks guide the process to improve explanation quality and generalization.

Result: ALIGN outperforms six strong baselines on VLCS and Terra Incognita in both in-distribution and out-of-distribution settings, and yields superior explanation quality in terms of sufficiency and comprehensiveness.

Conclusion: ALIGN demonstrates that high-quality guidance for explanation-guided learning can enhance both predictive performance and interpretability, offering a scalable approach for domain generalization.

Abstract: Explanation-guided learning (EGL) has shown promise in aligning model predictions with interpretable reasoning, particularly in computer vision tasks. However, most approaches rely on external annotations or heuristic-based segmentation to supervise model explanations, which can be noisy, imprecise and difficult to scale. In this work, we provide both empirical and theoretical evidence that low-quality supervision signals can degrade model performance rather than improve it. In response, we propose ALIGN, a novel framework that jointly trains a classifier and a masker in an iterative manner. The masker learns to produce soft, task-relevant masks that highlight informative regions, while the classifier is optimized for both prediction accuracy and alignment between its saliency maps and the learned masks. By leveraging high-quality masks as guidance, ALIGN improves both interpretability and generalizability, showing its superiority across various settings. Experiments on the two domain generalization benchmarks, VLCS and Terra Incognita, show that ALIGN consistently outperforms six strong baselines in both in-distribution and out-of-distribution settings. Besides, ALIGN also yields superior explanation quality concerning sufficiency and comprehensiveness, highlighting its effectiveness in producing accurate and interpretable models.

</details>


### [172] [FoCLIP: A Feature-Space Misalignment Framework for CLIP-Based Image Manipulation and Detection](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06947)
*Yulin Chen,Zeyuan Wang,Tianyuan Yu,Yingmei Wei,Liang Bai*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: FoCLIP introduces a feature-space misalignment framework to fool CLIP-based image quality metrics, using feature alignment, score distribution balance, and pixel-guard regularization; it achieves higher CLIPscore with preserved visual fidelity, reveals grayscale as a vulnerability, and proposes a color-channel tampering detector with ~91% accuracy; highlights vulnerability and a defense path for CLIP multimodal systems.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: CLIP-based metrics rely on cross-modal alignment and may be vulnerable to feature-space misalignment; understanding attack surfaces is crucial for the reliability of multimodal image quality assessment and for developing defenses.

Method: Stochastic gradient descent-based optimization with three modules: (1) feature alignment core to reduce image-text modality gaps, (2) score distribution balance to harmonize outputs across prompts, and (3) pixel-guard regularization to constrain perturbations; experiments include ten artistic masterpiece prompts and ImageNet subsets; also analyzes grayscale conversion effects and proposes a color-channel sensitivity-based tampering detector.

Result: Optimized images show significant CLIPscore gains while maintaining high visual fidelity; grayscale conversion causes notable feature degradation and CLIPscore drop despite preserved statistical similarity; the proposed tampering detector based on color-channel sensitivity achieves 91% accuracy on standard benchmarks.

Conclusion: Demonstrates a practical pathway for feature misalignment in CLIP-based multimodal systems and presents a defense method; suggests the need for robust evaluation and defenses against multimodal adversarial tactics.

Abstract: The well-aligned attribute of CLIP-based models enables its effective application like CLIPscore as a widely adopted image quality assessment metric. However, such a CLIP-based metric is vulnerable for its delicate multimodal alignment. In this work, we propose \textbf{FoCLIP}, a feature-space misalignment framework for fooling CLIP-based image quality metric. Based on the stochastic gradient descent technique, FoCLIP integrates three key components to construct fooling examples: feature alignment as the core module to reduce image-text modality gaps, the score distribution balance module and pixel-guard regularization, which collectively optimize multimodal output equilibrium between CLIPscore performance and image quality. Such a design can be engineered to maximize the CLIPscore predictions across diverse input prompts, despite exhibiting either visual unrecognizability or semantic incongruence with the corresponding adversarial prompts from human perceptual perspectives. Experiments on ten artistic masterpiece prompts and ImageNet subsets demonstrate that optimized images can achieve significant improvement in CLIPscore while preserving high visual fidelity. In addition, we found that grayscale conversion induces significant feature degradation in fooling images, exhibiting noticeable CLIPscore reduction while preserving statistical consistency with original images. Inspired by this phenomenon, we propose a color channel sensitivity-driven tampering detection mechanism that achieves 91% accuracy on standard benchmarks. In conclusion, this work establishes a practical pathway for feature misalignment in CLIP-based multimodal systems and the corresponding defense method.

</details>


### [173] [PADM: A Physics-aware Diffusion Model for Attenuation Correction](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06948)
*Trung Kien Pham,Hoang Minh Vu,Anh Duc Chu,Dac Thai Nguyen,Trung Thanh Nguyen,Thao Nguyen Truong,Mai Hong Son,Thanh Trung Nguyen,Phi Le Nguyen*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: CT-free attenuation correction for cardiac SPECT using a diffusion model with physics priors (PADM) and teacher-student distillation; trained on NAC inputs; introduces CardiAC dataset (424 studies) with NAC, AC reconstructions, and CT-based attenuation maps; shows improved fidelity over baselines.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: CT-based attenuation correction reduces artifacts but introduces cost, radiation, and accessibility barriers. A CT-free solution could democratize attenuation correction in myocardial perfusion imaging.

Method: Propose Physics-aware Attenuation Correction Diffusion Model (PADM), a diffusion-based generative model incorporating physics priors via a teacher–student distillation framework. Train with NAC inputs while leveraging physics-informed supervision from AC maps; at inference, operate solely on NAC data. Introduce CardiAC dataset with 424 patient studies containing paired NAC and AC reconstructions plus high-res CT maps.

Result: PADM outperforms state-of-the-art generative models, achieving superior reconstruction fidelity across quantitative metrics and qualitative visual assessments.

Conclusion: A feasible, CT-free attenuation correction approach for cardiac SPECT that can enhance diagnostic interpretability and accessibility. The CardiAC dataset supports broader research and benchmarking in CT-free attenuation correction for MPI.

Abstract: Attenuation artifacts remain a significant challenge in cardiac Myocardial Perfusion Imaging (MPI) using Single-Photon Emission Computed Tomography (SPECT), often compromising diagnostic accuracy and reducing clinical interpretability. While hybrid SPECT/CT systems mitigate these artifacts through CT-derived attenuation maps, their high cost, limited accessibility, and added radiation exposure hinder widespread clinical adoption. In this study, we propose a novel CT-free solution to attenuation correction in cardiac SPECT. Specifically, we introduce Physics-aware Attenuation Correction Diffusion Model (PADM), a diffusion-based generative method that incorporates explicit physics priors via a teacher--student distillation mechanism. This approach enables attenuation artifact correction using only Non-Attenuation-Corrected (NAC) input, while still benefiting from physics-informed supervision during training. To support this work, we also introduce CardiAC, a comprehensive dataset comprising 424 patient studies with paired NAC and Attenuation-Corrected (AC) reconstructions, alongside high-resolution CT-based attenuation maps. Extensive experiments demonstrate that PADM outperforms state-of-the-art generative models, delivering superior reconstruction fidelity across both quantitative metrics and visual assessment.

</details>


### [174] [GFix: Perceptually Enhanced Gaussian Splatting Video Compression](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06953)
*Siyue Teng,Ge Gao,Duolikun Danier,Yuxuan Jiang,Fan Zhang,Thomas Davis,Zoe Liu,David Bull*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: Proposes GFix, a content-adaptive diffusion-based enhancer for 3D Gaussian Splatting (3DGS) video compression. Uses a single-step diffusion model as an off-the-shelf enhancer and a modulated LoRA to efficiently adapt the backbone, achieving notable perceptual improvements and better compression.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: 3DGS-based video codecs show artifacts and limited compression ratios; perceptual quality is crucial. The work aims to mitigate artifacts and boost compression efficiency by treating rendering/quantization artifacts as noisy latents from diffusion training.

Method: A streamlined, single-step diffusion model acts as an off-the-shelf neural enhancer. Introduces a modulated LoRA scheme that freezes low-rank decompositions and modulates intermediate hidden states to enable efficient adaptation with compressible updates.

Result: GFix achieves strong perceptual quality improvements, outperforming GSVC with up to 72.1% BD-rate savings in LPIPS and 21.4% in FID.

Conclusion: Content-adaptive diffusion-based enhancement with a compact, efficiently adaptable backbone can substantially improve perceptual quality and compression efficiency in 3DGS-based video codecs.

Abstract: 3D Gaussian Splatting (3DGS) enhances 3D scene reconstruction through explicit representation and fast rendering, demonstrating potential benefits for various low-level vision tasks, including video compression. However, existing 3DGS-based video codecs generally exhibit more noticeable visual artifacts and relatively low compression ratios. In this paper, we specifically target the perceptual enhancement of 3DGS-based video compression, based on the assumption that artifacts from 3DGS rendering and quantization resemble noisy latents sampled during diffusion training. Building on this premise, we propose a content-adaptive framework, GFix, comprising a streamlined, single-step diffusion model that serves as an off-the-shelf neural enhancer. Moreover, to increase compression efficiency, We propose a modulated LoRA scheme that freezes the low-rank decompositions and modulates the intermediate hidden states, thereby achieving efficient adaptation of the diffusion backbone with highly compressible updates. Experimental results show that GFix delivers strong perceptual quality enhancement, outperforming GSVC with up to 72.1% BD-rate savings in LPIPS and 21.4% in FID.

</details>


### [175] [Learning from the Right Patches: A Two-Stage Wavelet-Driven Masked Autoencoder for Histopathology Representation Learning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06958)
*Raneen Younis,Louay Hamdi,Lukas Chavez,Zahra Ahmadi*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: A wavelet-informed, two-stage patch selection for MAE pretraining on whole-slide images (WISE-MAE) improves structure-aware representations with efficient, weakly-supervised learning.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Conventional MAE pretraining on whole-slide images often samples noisy or irrelevant patches due to the extreme size and limited annotations. There is a need for a guided, domain-adapted sampling strategy that emphasizes tissue structure and mirrors pathologist workflows to improve representation quality.

Method: WISE-MAE uses a two-step coarse-to-fine approach. First, at low magnification, wavelet-based screening identifies structurally rich regions. Then, high-resolution patches are extracted from these regions for MAE pretraining with a Vision Transformer backbone. The framework is lightweight and domain-adapted to histopathology, aiming to improve meaningful pattern capture while maintaining efficiency under weak supervision.

Result: Evaluations across multiple cancer datasets (lung, renal, colorectal) show that WISE-MAE achieves competitive representation quality and downstream classification performance while remaining efficient under weak supervision.

Conclusion: WISE-MAE demonstrates that incorporating wavelet-based, structure-aware patch selection into MAE pretraining yields more biologically meaningful representations, improves efficiency, and aligns with the diagnostic workflow. This approach offers a promising direction for self-supervised learning on whole-slide histopathology images, with potential for broader generalization and future refinements.

Abstract: Whole-slide images are central to digital pathology, yet their extreme size and scarce annotations make self-supervised learning essential. Masked Autoencoders (MAEs) with Vision Transformer backbones have recently shown strong potential for histopathology representation learning. However, conventional random patch sampling during MAE pretraining often includes irrelevant or noisy regions, limiting the model's ability to capture meaningful tissue patterns. In this paper, we present a lightweight and domain-adapted framework that brings structure and biological relevance into MAE-based learning through a wavelet-informed patch selection strategy. WISE-MAE applies a two-step coarse-to-fine process: wavelet-based screening at low magnification to locate structurally rich regions, followed by high-resolution extraction for detailed modeling. This approach mirrors the diagnostic workflow of pathologists and improves the quality of learned representations. Evaluations across multiple cancer datasets, including lung, renal, and colorectal tissues, show that WISE-MAE achieves competitive representation quality and downstream classification performance while maintaining efficiency under weak supervision.

</details>


### [176] [Exploring the "Great Unseen" in Medieval Manuscripts: Instance-Level Labeling of Legacy Image Collections with Zero-Shot Models](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.07004)
*Christofer Meinecke,Estelle Guéville,David Joseph Wrisley*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: Proposes a holistic folio-level theory and segmentation framework to describe entire medieval manuscript pages, generating richer training data for computer vision (instance segmentation) and multimodal models focused on medieval visuals.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Addresses the need for comprehensive, high-quality annotations of full manuscript folios to advance computer vision and multimodal understanding of medieval content, enabling more accurate segmentation and richer descriptive models.

Method: Apply state-of-the-art segmentation and descriptive techniques to entire manuscript folios, integrating visual and textual content to create holistic annotations and training data for CV and multimodal tasks.

Result: A framework for holistic folio analysis that yields richer, more usable annotated data for instance segmentation and medieval-content multimodal models; potentially a new dataset or benchmarking approach.

Conclusion: Holistic folio-level analysis and data curation can significantly improve CV and multimodal modeling for medieval manuscripts by capturing the full page content rather than isolated fragments.

Abstract: We aim to theorize the medieval manuscript page and its contents more holistically, using state-of-the-art techniques to segment and describe the entire manuscript folio, for the purpose of creating richer training data for computer vision techniques, namely instance segmentation, and multimodal models for medieval-specific visual content.

</details>


### [177] [TrueCity: Real and Simulated Urban Data for Cross-Domain 3D Scene Understanding](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.07007)
*Duc Nguyen,Yan-Ling Lai,Qilin Zhang,Prabin Gyawali,Benedikt Schwab,Olaf Wysocki,Thomas H. Kolbe*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: Introducing TrueCity, a synchronized real-and-simulated urban 3D semantic segmentation benchmark that quantifies the sim-to-real domain gap and enables evaluation of synthetic data in real-world scene understanding.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Real-world annotated 3D data are scarce and synthetic data, while scalable and perfectly labeled, fails to capture real-world complexity and sensor noise, creating a synthetic-to-real domain gap. There is no benchmark with synchronized real and simulated point clouds for segmentation-domain shift analysis.

Method: Introduce TrueCity: a dataset with cm-accurate real-world point clouds, semantic 3D city models, and matched simulated point clouds of the same city; align segmentation classes with international 3D city modeling standards; perform extensive baselines to quantify domain shift and explore strategies to leverage synthetic data for real-world 3D scene understanding; release data/code/models online.

Result: First urban semantic segmentation benchmark with synchronized real and simulated data, enabling quantified analysis of sim-to-real gaps; baseline experiments quantify domain shift and guide strategies to use synthetic data for real-world understanding.

Conclusion: TrueCity will spur quantification of sim-to-real gaps and support the development of generalizable, data-driven 3D scene understanding models; dataset and resources are publicly available to foster further research.

Abstract: 3D semantic scene understanding remains a long-standing challenge in the 3D computer vision community. One of the key issues pertains to limited real-world annotated data to facilitate generalizable models. The common practice to tackle this issue is to simulate new data. Although synthetic datasets offer scalability and perfect labels, their designer-crafted scenes fail to capture real-world complexity and sensor noise, resulting in a synthetic-to-real domain gap. Moreover, no benchmark provides synchronized real and simulated point clouds for segmentation-oriented domain shift analysis. We introduce TrueCity, the first urban semantic segmentation benchmark with cm-accurate annotated real-world point clouds, semantic 3D city models, and annotated simulated point clouds representing the same city. TrueCity proposes segmentation classes aligned with international 3D city modeling standards, enabling consistent evaluation of synthetic-to-real gap. Our extensive experiments on common baselines quantify domain shift and highlight strategies for exploiting synthetic data to enhance real-world 3D scene understanding. We are convinced that the TrueCity dataset will foster further development of sim-to-real gap quantification and enable generalizable data-driven models. The data, code, and 3D models are available online: https://tum-gis.github.io/TrueCity/

</details>


### [178] [Performance Decay in Deepfake Detection: The Limitations of Training on Outdated Data](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.07009)
*Jack Richings,Margaux Leblanc,Ian Groves,Victoria Nockles*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: A two-stage deepfake detector achieves very high AUROC on current deepfakes but rapidly loses effectiveness to newer generation methods; robust detection requires ongoing data collection and frame-level feature detectors rather than temporal cues.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Deepfake threats are evolving rapidly; detectors trained on current data tend to degrade as generation techniques change, necessitating understanding of decay patterns and robust development directions.

Method: Introduce a simple two-stage detection approach; train on large, diverse datasets; evaluate on contemporary deepfakes and on deepfakes created six months later to assess generalization; analyze whether predictive power comes from static frame-level artifacts vs temporal cues; emphasize rapid data collection and frame-level detectors.

Result: AUROC >99.8% on contemporary deepfakes; recall drops by over 30% when evaluated on six-month-later deepfakes; robustness hinges on continual data curation and frame-level artifacts as the primary drivers of detection.

Conclusion: Sustained deepfake detection performance requires ongoing, diverse data collection and development of advanced frame-level detectors; focusing on frame-level artifacts provides a more robust basis than relying on temporal inconsistencies, with rapid data updates essential to keep pace with evolving threats.

Abstract: The continually advancing quality of deepfake technology exacerbates the threats of disinformation, fraud, and harassment by making maliciously-generated synthetic content increasingly difficult to distinguish from reality. We introduce a simple yet effective two-stage detection method that achieves an AUROC of over 99.8% on contemporary deepfakes. However, this high performance is short-lived. We show that models trained on this data suffer a recall drop of over 30% when evaluated on deepfakes created with generation techniques from just six months later, demonstrating significant decay as threats evolve. Our analysis reveals two key insights for robust detection. Firstly, continued performance requires the ongoing curation of large, diverse datasets. Second, predictive power comes primarily from static, frame-level artifacts, not temporal inconsistencies. The future of effective deepfake detection therefore depends on rapid data collection and the development of advanced frame-level feature detectors.

</details>


### [179] [Certified L2-Norm Robustness of 3D Point Cloud Recognition in the Frequency Domain](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.07029)
*Liang Zhou,Qiming Wang,Tianze Chen*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: FreqCert certifies 3D point cloud classifiers against global L2 perturbations by transforming to the frequency domain with GFT, applying spectral subsampling to create sub-clouds, and majority-voting; it provides a closed-form robust radius bound and shows empirical and certified gains on ModelNet40 and ScanObjectNN.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: 3D point cloud classifiers are vulnerable to structured geometric distortions that preserve individual points but alter the overall structure. Existing defenses focus on point-wise perturbations and overlook these global, structured attacks, motivating a frequency-domain certification approach.

Method: Apply graph Fourier transform (GFT) to input point clouds, perform spectral similarity-based subsampling to generate multiple sub-clouds, classify each sub-cloud with a standard model, and aggregate via majority voting. The partitioning is designed to be stable under L2 perturbations and aligned with intrinsic object structure. Derive a closed-form lower bound on the certified L2 robustness radius and prove its tightness under minimal, interpretable assumptions.

Result: Demonstrates higher certified accuracy and stronger empirical accuracy under perturbations on ModelNet40 and ScanObjectNN, validating the effectiveness of frequency-domain certification for 3D point clouds.

Conclusion: Spectral representations enable effective certifiable robustness for 3D point cloud recognition, offering a principled pathway beyond traditional spatial-domain defenses.

Abstract: 3D point cloud classification is a fundamental task in safety-critical applications such as autonomous driving, robotics, and augmented reality. However, recent studies reveal that point cloud classifiers are vulnerable to structured adversarial perturbations and geometric corruptions, posing risks to their deployment in safety-critical scenarios. Existing certified defenses limit point-wise perturbations but overlook subtle geometric distortions that preserve individual points yet alter the overall structure, potentially leading to misclassification. In this work, we propose FreqCert, a novel certification framework that departs from conventional spatial domain defenses by shifting robustness analysis to the frequency domain, enabling structured certification against global L2-bounded perturbations. FreqCert first transforms the input point cloud via the graph Fourier transform (GFT), then applies structured frequency-aware subsampling to generate multiple sub-point clouds. Each sub-cloud is independently classified by a standard model, and the final prediction is obtained through majority voting, where sub-clouds are constructed based on spectral similarity rather than spatial proximity, making the partitioning more stable under L2 perturbations and better aligned with the object's intrinsic structure. We derive a closed-form lower bound on the certified L2 robustness radius and prove its tightness under minimal and interpretable assumptions, establishing a theoretical foundation for frequency domain certification. Extensive experiments on the ModelNet40 and ScanObjectNN datasets demonstrate that FreqCert consistently achieves higher certified accuracy and empirical accuracy under strong perturbations. Our results suggest that spectral representations provide an effective pathway toward certifiable robustness in 3D point cloud recognition.

</details>


### [180] [3D-ANC: Adaptive Neural Collapse for Robust 3D Point Cloud Recognition](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.07040)
*Yuanmin Huang,Wenxuan Li,Mi Zhang,Xiaohan Zhang,Xiaoyu You,Min Yang*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: 3D-ANC proposes an ETF-based, Neural Collapse–driven framework to improve robustness of 3D point cloud models against adversarial perturbations by disentangling feature spaces through representation-balanced learning and dynamic feature direction loss, achieving substantial gains (e.g., DGCNN on ModelNet40: 27.2%→80.9%).


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Adversarial attacks exploit entangled feature spaces in 3D point clouds; existing defenses struggle with evolving attack patterns, especially under class imbalance and geometric similarity across categories.

Method: Introduce an ETF-aligned classification module guided by Neural Collapse, and an adaptive training framework combining representation-balanced learning (RBL) with dynamic feature direction loss (FDL) to produce disentangled, maximally separable class prototypes.

Result: The approach yields strong robustness improvements across models and datasets; notable improvement on ModelNet40 (DGCNN: 27.2% to 80.9%), surpassing baselines by a wide margin; tested on two datasets.

Conclusion: Leveraging Neural Collapse to form an ETF-structured feature space enables robust 3D recognition with existing architectures, even under significant data imbalance and geometric similarity.

Abstract: Deep neural networks have recently achieved notable progress in 3D point cloud recognition, yet their vulnerability to adversarial perturbations poses critical security challenges in practical deployments. Conventional defense mechanisms struggle to address the evolving landscape of multifaceted attack patterns. Through systematic analysis of existing defenses, we identify that their unsatisfactory performance primarily originates from an entangled feature space, where adversarial attacks can be performed easily. To this end, we present 3D-ANC, a novel approach that capitalizes on the Neural Collapse (NC) mechanism to orchestrate discriminative feature learning. In particular, NC depicts where last-layer features and classifier weights jointly evolve into a simplex equiangular tight frame (ETF) arrangement, establishing maximally separable class prototypes. However, leveraging this advantage in 3D recognition confronts two substantial challenges: (1) prevalent class imbalance in point cloud datasets, and (2) complex geometric similarities between object categories. To tackle these obstacles, our solution combines an ETF-aligned classification module with an adaptive training framework consisting of representation-balanced learning (RBL) and dynamic feature direction loss (FDL). 3D-ANC seamlessly empowers existing models to develop disentangled feature spaces despite the complexity in 3D data distribution. Comprehensive evaluations state that 3D-ANC significantly improves the robustness of models with various structures on two datasets. For instance, DGCNN's classification accuracy is elevated from 27.2% to 80.9% on ModelNet40 -- a 53.7% absolute gain that surpasses leading baselines by 34.0%.

</details>


### [181] [From Pretrain to Pain: Adversarial Vulnerability of Video Foundation Models Without Task Knowledge](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.07049)
*Hui Lu,Yi Yu,Song Xia,Yiming Yang,Deepu Rajan,Boon Poh Ng,Alex Kot,Xudong Jiang*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: Transferable Video Attack (TVA) is a practical, temporal-aware adversarial attack on open large-scale Video Foundation Models (VFMs) that can compromise downstream models and MLLMs without needing the victim task, data, queries, or architectural access; it uses bidirectional contrastive learning and a temporal consistency loss to craft perturbations, showing efficacy across 24 video tasks.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Open-access VFMs pose security risks because adversaries can exploit their knowledge to attack downstream models without access to the victim task, data, or model internals. Traditional transfer attacks rely on domain-specific surrogates; this work seeks a more practical, data-free attack that leverages the temporal dynamics of VFMs.

Method: Introduce TVA (Transferable Video Attack), a temporal-aware adversarial method that exploits the temporal representation dynamics of VFMs. TVA uses a bidirectional contrastive learning objective to maximize the gap between clean and adversarial features and adds a temporal consistency loss that leverages motion cues to amplify perturbation impact over time. Importantly, TVA does not require training surrogate models or domain-specific data.

Result: Extensive experiments across 24 video-related tasks demonstrate TVA’s effectiveness against downstream models and MLLMs, exposing a previously underexplored security vulnerability in open VFMs.

Conclusion: TVA reveals a practical and efficient attack vector against open Video Foundation Models and their downstream deployments, underscoring the need for robust defenses and prompting future work on mitigation strategies for video-model security.

Abstract: Large-scale Video Foundation Models (VFMs) has significantly advanced various video-related tasks, either through task-specific models or Multi-modal Large Language Models (MLLMs). However, the open accessibility of VFMs also introduces critical security risks, as adversaries can exploit full knowledge of the VFMs to launch potent attacks. This paper investigates a novel and practical adversarial threat scenario: attacking downstream models or MLLMs fine-tuned from open-source VFMs, without requiring access to the victim task, training data, model query, and architecture. In contrast to conventional transfer-based attacks that rely on task-aligned surrogate models, we demonstrate that adversarial vulnerabilities can be exploited directly from the VFMs. To this end, we propose the Transferable Video Attack (TVA), a temporal-aware adversarial attack method that leverages the temporal representation dynamics of VFMs to craft effective perturbations. TVA integrates a bidirectional contrastive learning mechanism to maximize the discrepancy between the clean and adversarial features, and introduces a temporal consistency loss that exploits motion cues to enhance the sequential impact of perturbations. TVA avoids the need to train expensive surrogate models or access to domain-specific data, thereby offering a more practical and efficient attack strategy. Extensive experiments across 24 video-related tasks demonstrate the efficacy of TVA against downstream models and MLLMs, revealing a previously underexplored security vulnerability in the deployment of video models.

</details>


### [182] [Improving Deepfake Detection with Reinforcement Learning-Based Adaptive Data Augmentation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.07051)
*Yuxuan Zhou,Tao Yu,Wen Huang,Yuheng Zhang,Tao Dai,Shu-Tao Xia*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: CRDA introduces a curriculum reinforcement-learning data augmentation framework for deepfake detectors that dynamically crafts adversarial, diverse, and causally-informed augmentations, improving cross-domain generalization over static policies.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Deepfake detectors struggle to generalize due to evolving, multi-domain forgery patterns. Fixed augmentation strategies fail to mimic real-world complexity and can embed task-irrelevant biases.

Method: An RL agent selects augmentation actions from a configurable pool of forgery operations based on the detector's performance, creating adversarial and heterogeneous patterns. It integrates causal inference to suppress spurious correlations, guiding the augmentation toward causally invariant features and employing a curriculum from simple to complex forgeries.

Result: Extensive experiments show substantial gains in cross-domain generalization, beating state-of-the-art methods across multiple datasets.

Conclusion: Dynamic, curriculum-based augmentation that combines RL and causal inference yields robust detector generalization by exploring diverse, task-relevant forgery patterns while mitigating biases.

Abstract: The generalization capability of deepfake detectors is critical for real-world use. Data augmentation via synthetic fake face generation effectively enhances generalization, yet current SoTA methods rely on fixed strategies-raising a key question: Is a single static augmentation sufficient, or does the diversity of forgery features demand dynamic approaches? We argue existing methods overlook the evolving complexity of real-world forgeries (e.g., facial warping, expression manipulation), which fixed policies cannot fully simulate. To address this, we propose CRDA (Curriculum Reinforcement-Learning Data Augmentation), a novel framework guiding detectors to progressively master multi-domain forgery features from simple to complex. CRDA synthesizes augmented samples via a configurable pool of forgery operations and dynamically generates adversarial samples tailored to the detector's current learning state.
