Using synthetic and real-world datasets, we demonstrate that our proposed evaluation approach consistently yields better model selection than the standard approach, which ignores data from the treatment group, across various intervention effect and sample size settings. Our contribution represents a meaningful step towards more efficient model evaluation in real-world contexts.

</details>


### [237] [MOSS: Efficient and Accurate FP8 LLM Training with Microscaling and Automatic Scaling](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.05811)
*Yu Zhang,Hui-Ling Zhen,Mingxuan Yuan,Bei Yu*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: MOSS provides efficient FP8 training by combining a two-level microscaling strategy for activations with automatic weight scaling in linear layers, achieving BF16-like stability and up to 34% throughput gain on a 7B model.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: FP8 offers memory and compute efficiency but suffers from instability and accuracy issues due to low precision. Existing mixed-precision approaches (per-group activations, per-tensor/block weights) incur dequantization overhead and rely on online scaling, which adds memory traffic and reduces FP8 benefits during training.

Method: Introduce two-level microscaling: a high-precision global scale paired with compact, power-of-two local scales for activations; automatic scaling for weights in linear layers that predicts and adjusts scales during training, removing the need for costly max-reduction operations.

Result: Demonstrates training of a 7B parameter model with FP8 that matches BF16 baseline accuracy while delivering up to 34% higher training throughput.

Conclusion: MOSS enables efficient, stable FP8 training for large models by reducing dequantization overhead and eliminating online scaling costs through hierarchical microscaling and predictive weight scaling.

Abstract: Training large language models with FP8 formats offers significant efficiency gains. However, the reduced numerical precision of FP8 poses challenges for stable and accurate training. Current frameworks preserve training performance using mixed-granularity quantization, i.e., applying per-group quantization for activations and per-tensor/block quantization for weights. While effective, per-group quantization requires scaling along the inner dimension of matrix multiplication, introducing additional dequantization overhead. Moreover, these frameworks often rely on just-in-time scaling to dynamically adjust scaling factors based on the current data distribution. However, this online quantization is inefficient for FP8 training, as it involves multiple memory reads and writes that negate the performance benefits of FP8. To overcome these limitations, we propose MOSS, a novel FP8 training framework that ensures both efficiency and numerical stability. MOSS introduces two key innovations: (1) a two-level microscaling strategy for quantizing sensitive activations, which balances precision and dequantization cost by combining a high-precision global scale with compact, power-of-two local scales; and (2) automatic scaling for weights in linear layers, which eliminates the need for costly max-reduction operations by predicting and adjusting scaling factors during training. Leveraging these techniques, MOSS enables efficient FP8 training of a 7B parameter model, achieving performance comparable to the BF16 baseline while achieving up to 34% higher training throughput.

</details>


### [238] [In-depth Analysis on Caching and Pre-fetching in Mixture of Experts Offloading](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.05814)
*Shuning Lin,Yifan He,Yitong Chen*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A study on MoE offloading with caching and prefetching; analyzes expert activation and caching; introduces LFU caching; demonstrates speculative prefetching; discusses gating/experts for interpretability and pruning.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Enable deployment of Mixture of Experts (MoE) on memory-constrained devices by efficient offloading. Understand activation and caching patterns to inform pruning and robust inference.

Method: Trace-based analysis of expert activation and LRU caching; develop LFU caching optimization; implement speculative expert pre-fetching; provide detailed traces; examine behavior of gating network and experts.

Result: LFU caching improves efficiency over LRU; speculative pre-fetching shows substantial potential based on traces; rich insights into MoE gating and expert dynamics.

Conclusion: Offers a comprehensive characterization of MoE offloading, guiding pruning with minimal performance loss and aiding deployment on edge devices; provides data-driven insights for future interpretability and optimization studies.

Abstract: In today's landscape, Mixture of Experts (MoE) is a crucial architecture that has been used by many of the most advanced models. One of the major challenges of MoE models is that they usually require much more memory than their dense counterparts due to their unique architecture, and hence are harder to deploy in environments with limited GPU memory, such as edge devices. MoE offloading is a promising technique proposed to overcome this challenge, especially if it is enhanced with caching and pre-fetching, but prior work stopped at suboptimal caching algorithm and offered limited insights. In this work, we study MoE offloading in depth and make the following contributions: 1. We analyze the expert activation and LRU caching behavior in detail and provide traces. 2. We propose LFU caching optimization based on our analysis and obtain strong improvements from LRU. 3. We implement and experiment speculative expert pre-fetching, providing detailed trace showing its huge potential . 4. In addition, our study extensively covers the behavior of the MoE architecture itself, offering information on the characteristic of the gating network and experts. This can inspire future work on the interpretation of MoE models and the development of pruning techniques for MoE architecture with minimal performance loss.

</details>


### [239] [Predicting the Future by Retrieving the Past](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.05859)
*Dazhao Du,Tao Han,Song Guo*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: PFRP introduces a Global Memory Bank and retrieval mechanism to inject global historical patterns into univariate forecasting, adaptively combining global predictions with local models to improve accuracy.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Standard univariate forecasting models compress history into parameters and rely on local context, missing explicit access to global historical patterns. There is a need to leverage global knowledge to improve forecast accuracy and interpretability.

Method: Construct a Global Memory Bank (GMB) to store global historical patterns. Use a retrieval mechanism to fetch similar patterns from the GMB during inference, generating global predictions. Adaptively combine these global predictions with outputs from any local prediction model to produce forecasts.

Result: Experiments on seven real-world datasets show that PFRP substantially improves the average performance of advanced univariate forecasting models by about 8.4%.

Conclusion: Explicitly leveraging global historical knowledge via memory retrieval enhances accuracy and interpretability of univariate forecasts, with code available for replication.

Abstract: Deep learning models such as MLP, Transformer, and TCN have achieved remarkable success in univariate time series forecasting, typically relying on sliding window samples from historical data for training. However, while these models implicitly compress historical information into their parameters during training, they are unable to explicitly and dynamically access this global knowledge during inference, relying only on the local context within the lookback window. This results in an underutilization of rich patterns from the global history. To bridge this gap, we propose Predicting the Future by Retrieving the Past (PFRP), a novel approach that explicitly integrates global historical data to enhance forecasting accuracy. Specifically, we construct a Global Memory Bank (GMB) to effectively store and manage global historical patterns. A retrieval mechanism is then employed to extract similar patterns from the GMB, enabling the generation of global predictions. By adaptively combining these global predictions with the outputs of any local prediction model, PFRP produces more accurate and interpretable forecasts. Extensive experiments conducted on seven real-world datasets demonstrate that PFRP significantly enhances the average performance of advanced univariate forecasting models by 8.4\%. Codes can be found in https://github.com/ddz16/PFRP.

</details>


### [240] [EMOD: A Unified EEG Emotion Representation Framework Leveraging V-A Guided Contrastive Learning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.05863)
*Yuning Chen,Sha Zhao,Shijian Li,Gang Pan*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: EMOD introduces a unified EEG emotion representation that aligns discrete and continuous emotion labels in a valence-arousal space, using a soft-weighted contrastive loss and a flexible backbone (Triple-Domain Encoder + Spatial-Temporal Transformer) to bridge semantic and structural gaps across heterogeneous EEG emotion datasets, achieving state-of-the-art generalization.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: The field faces cross-dataset generalization gaps due to heterogeneous annotation schemes and data formats. Existing models are often dataset-specific and lack semantic alignment across emotion labels, hindering transferability.

Method: EMOD projects discrete and continuous emotions into a valence-arousal (V-A) space and uses a soft-weighted supervised contrastive loss to cluster emotionally similar samples. It features a flexible backbone: a Triple-Domain Encoder followed by a Spatial-Temporal Transformer to capture temporal, spectral, and spatial features and handle variable EEG formats. Pretrained on eight public EEG datasets and evaluated on three benchmarks.

Result: EMOD achieves state-of-the-art performance and demonstrates strong adaptability and generalization across diverse EEG-based emotion recognition tasks on the evaluated benchmarks.

Conclusion: EMOD provides transferable, emotion-aware representations that bridge semantic gaps (emotion labels) and structural gaps (data formats) in EEG emotion recognition, enabling robust cross-dataset performance.

Abstract: Emotion recognition from EEG signals is essential for affective computing and has been widely explored using deep learning. While recent deep learning approaches have achieved strong performance on single EEG emotion datasets, their generalization across datasets remains limited due to the heterogeneity in annotation schemes and data formats. Existing models typically require dataset-specific architectures tailored to input structure and lack semantic alignment across diverse emotion labels. To address these challenges, we propose EMOD: A Unified EEG Emotion Representation Framework Leveraging Valence-Arousal (V-A) Guided Contrastive Learning. EMOD learns transferable and emotion-aware representations from heterogeneous datasets by bridging both semantic and structural gaps. Specifically, we project discrete and continuous emotion labels into a unified V-A space and formulate a soft-weighted supervised contrastive loss that encourages emotionally similar samples to cluster in the latent space. To accommodate variable EEG formats, EMOD employs a flexible backbone comprising a Triple-Domain Encoder followed by a Spatial-Temporal Transformer, enabling robust extraction and integration of temporal, spectral, and spatial features. We pretrain EMOD on eight public EEG datasets and evaluate its performance on three benchmark datasets. Experimental results show that EMOD achieves state-of-the-art performance, demonstrating strong adaptability and generalization across diverse EEG-based emotion recognition scenarios.

</details>


### [241] [Adaptation and Fine-tuning with TabPFN for Travelling Salesman Problem](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.05872)
*Nguyen Gia Hien Vu,Yifan Tang,Rey Lim,Yifan Yang,Hang Ma,Ke Wang,G. Gary Wang*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: First application of TabPFN to a combinatorial optimization problem (TSP) showing competitive solution quality with minimal training and rapid adaptation.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Reduce training time/data requirements in combinatorial optimization by applying TabPFN to structured CO problems.

Method: Adapt TabPFN to TSP using a node-based approach and node-predicting strategy to build complete tours; fine-tune with minimal data; evaluate across varying instance sizes; aim for rapid adaptation (minutes).

Result: TabPFN requires minimal training, adapts from a single sample, generalizes across different TSP sizes, and achieves strong solution quality with little or no post-processing, comparable to models with post-processing.

Conclusion: TabPFN is a promising, resource-efficient approach for solving structured combinatorial optimization problems with rapid deployment.

Abstract: Tabular Prior-Data Fitted Network (TabPFN) is a foundation model designed for small to medium-sized tabular data, which has attracted much attention recently. This paper investigates the application of TabPFN in Combinatorial Optimization (CO) problems. The aim is to lessen challenges in time and data-intensive training requirements often observed in using traditional methods including exact and heuristic algorithms, Machine Learning (ML)-based models, to solve CO problems. Proposing possibly the first ever application of TabPFN for such a purpose, we adapt and fine-tune the TabPFN model to solve the Travelling Salesman Problem (TSP), one of the most well-known CO problems. Specifically, we adopt the node-based approach and the node-predicting adaptation strategy to construct the entire TSP route. Our evaluation with varying instance sizes confirms that TabPFN requires minimal training, adapts to TSP using a single sample, performs better generalization across varying TSP instance sizes, and reduces performance degradation. Furthermore, the training process with adaptation and fine-tuning is completed within minutes. The methodology leads to strong solution quality even without post-processing and achieves performance comparable to other models with post-processing refinement. Our findings suggest that the TabPFN model is a promising approach to solve structured and CO problems efficiently under training resource constraints and rapid deployment requirements.

</details>


### [242] [Physics-Informed Neural Networks for Real-Time Gas Crossover Prediction in PEM Electrolyzers: First Application with Multi-Membrane Validation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.05879)
*Yong-Woon Kim,Chulung Kang,Yung-Cheol Byun*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: First application of physics-informed neural networks (PINNs) to predict hydrogen crossover in PEM electrolyzers, achieving real-time, high-accuracy predictions and robust extrapolation, enabling safe, scalable monitoring.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Hydrogen crossover poses safety risks and reduces Faradaic efficiency; traditional physics-based models are computationally heavy and data-driven models lack extrapolation to dynamic operating conditions. Real-time monitoring is essential for gigawatt-scale PEM electrolysis.

Method: Develop a PINN that integrates mass conservation, Fick’s diffusion law, and Henry’s solubility law within a compact network (17,793 parameters). Validated on six membranes across industrially relevant conditions (0.05–5.0 A/cm², 1–200 bar, 25–85°C); achieves sub-millisecond inference suitable for real-time control and hardware-agnostic deployment (desktop to edge devices).

Result: Outstanding predictive performance (R² = 99.84%, RMSE = 0.0348%). Maintains R² > 86% when predicting crossover at 2.5× pressures beyond training range, substantially outperforming pure neural networks (R² = 43.4%).

Conclusion: PINNs offer a physics-grounded, computationally efficient solution for real-time monitoring of hydrogen crossover in PEM electrolyzers, enabling safer, scalable deployment of green hydrogen infrastructure and potentially expediting net-zero targets.

Abstract: Green hydrogen production via polymer electrolyte membrane (PEM) water electrolysis is pivotal for energy transition, yet hydrogen crossover through membranes threatens safety and economic viability-approaching explosive limits (4 mol% H$_2$ in O$_2$) while reducing Faradaic efficiency by 2.5%. Current physics-based models require extensive calibration and computational resources that preclude real-time implementation, while purely data-driven approaches fail to extrapolate beyond training conditions-critical for dynamic electrolyzer operation. Here we present the first application of physics-informed neural networks (PINNs) for hydrogen crossover prediction, integrating mass conservation, Fick's diffusion law, and Henry's solubility law within a compact architecture (17,793 parameters). Validated across six membranes under industrially relevant conditions (0.05-5.0 A/cm$^2$, 1-200 bar, 25-85°C), our PINN achieves exceptional accuracy (R$^2$ = 99.84%, RMSE = 0.0348%) with sub-millisecond inference times suitable for real-time control. Remarkably, the model maintains R$^2$ > 86% when predicting crossover at pressures 2.5x beyond training range-substantially outperforming pure neural networks (R$^2$ = 43.4%). The hardware-agnostic deployment, from desktop CPUs to edge devices (Raspberry Pi 4), enables distributed safety monitoring essential for gigawatt-scale installations. By bridging physical rigor and computational efficiency, this work establishes a new paradigm for real-time electrolyzer monitoring, accelerating deployment of safe, efficient green hydrogen infrastructure crucial for net-zero emissions targets.

</details>


### [243] [Kunlun Anomaly Troubleshooter: Enabling Kernel-Level Anomaly Detection and Causal Reasoning for Large Model Distributed Inference](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.05978)
*Yuyang Liu,Jingjing Cai,Jiayi Ren,Peng Zhou,Danyang Zhang,Yin Du,Shijian Li*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Introduce Kunlun Anomaly Troubleshooter (KAT), a two-stage anomaly troubleshooting framework for large-model distributed inference that uses GPU function trace data for nanosecond-resolution kernel-level anomaly detection and an LLM for causal reasoning and natural-language explanations; evaluated in Alibaba Cloud with high precision and recall.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Anomaly troubleshooting in large-model distributed inference is time-consuming and relies on domain experts, often yielding low accuracy. There is a need for automated, precise, and interpretable detection and diagnosis of anomalies.

Method: Two core innovations: (1) exploit synchronicity and consistency of GPU workers and leverage function trace data to detect kernel-level anomalies at nanosecond resolution; (2) integrate detection results into a domain-adapted large language model to provide systematic causal reasoning and natural-language interpretation of anomaly symptoms.

Result: In Alibaba Cloud production, KAT achieves precision >0.884 and recall 0.936 in anomaly detection, delivering detailed anomaly insights that narrow the diagnostic scope and improve troubleshooting efficiency and success rate.

Conclusion: KAT demonstrates a practical, interpretable anomaly-troubleshooting framework for large-model distributed inference by combining trace-based kernel anomaly detection with LLM-driven reasoning, reducing manual effort and enhancing diagnostic performance.

Abstract: Anomaly troubleshooting for large model distributed inference (LMDI) remains a critical challenge. Resolving anomalies such as inference performance degradation or latency jitter in distributed system demands significant manual efforts from domain experts, resulting in extremely time-consuming diagnosis processes with relatively low accuracy. In this paper, we introduce Kunlun Anomaly Troubleshooter (KAT), the first anomaly troubleshooting framework tailored for LMDI. KAT addresses this problem through two core innovations. First, KAT exploits the synchronicity and consistency of GPU workers, innovatively leverages function trace data to precisely detect kernel-level anomalies and associated hardware components at nanosecond resolution. Second, KAT integrates these detection results into a domain-adapted LLM, delivering systematic causal reasoning and natural language interpretation of complex anomaly symptoms. Evaluations conducted in Alibaba Cloud Service production environment indicate that KAT achieves over 0.884 precision and 0.936 recall in anomaly detection, providing detail anomaly insights that significantly narrow down the diagnostic scope and improve both the efficiency and success rate of troubleshooting.

</details>


### [244] [MoSKA: Mixture of Shared KV Attention for Efficient Long-Sequence LLM Inference](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06010)
*Myunghyun Rhee,Sookyung Choi,Euiseok Kim,Joonseop Sim,Youngpyo Joo,Hoshik Kim*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: MoSKA's Shared KV Attention exploits shared context to convert memory-bound KV operations into a compute-bound GEMM, yielding up to 538.7x throughput gains in high context-sharing workloads, enabled by an MoE-inspired sparse attention mechanism and specialized hardware.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To overcome GPU under-utilization and performance bottlenecks caused by memory-bound KV caches in long-context LLM inference, by leveraging the heterogeneity between per-request unique data and massively reused shared sequences.

Method: Introduce the MoSKA architecture with Shared KV Attention; differentiate between unique per-request and shared data; batch concurrent requests to turn KV attention on shared data into a single compute-bound GEMM; adopt MoE-inspired sparse attention to prune search space; design a disaggregated hardware infrastructure specialized for unique vs shared data.

Result: Demonstrates up to 538.7x throughput gains over baselines in workloads with high context sharing, indicating a scalable architectural path for LLM inference.

Conclusion: MoSKA offers a comprehensive architectural solution that leverages shared data in LLMs to mitigate memory bottlenecks, delivering substantial throughput gains and a clear path toward scalable inference via specialized hardware and sparse attention strategies.

Abstract: The escalating context length in Large Language Models (LLMs) creates a severe performance bottleneck around the Key-Value (KV) cache, whose memory-bound nature leads to significant GPU under-utilization. This paper introduces Mixture of Shared KV Attention (MoSKA), an architecture that addresses this challenge by exploiting the heterogeneity of context data. It differentiates between per-request unique and massively reused shared sequences. The core of MoSKA is a novel Shared KV Attention mechanism that transforms the attention on shared data from a series of memory-bound GEMV operations into a single, compute-bound GEMM by batching concurrent requests. This is supported by an MoE-inspired sparse attention strategy that prunes the search space and a tailored Disaggregated Infrastructure that specializes hardware for unique and shared data. This comprehensive approach demonstrates a throughput increase of up to 538.7x over baselines in workloads with high context sharing, offering a clear architectural path toward scalable LLM inference.

</details>


### [245] [ITPP: Learning Disentangled Event Dynamics in Marked Temporal Point Processes](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06032)
*Wang-Tao Zhou,Zhao Kang,Ke Yan,Ling Tian*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Introduce ITPP, a channel-independent MTPP model with an ODE-based backbone and type-aware inverted self-attention to decouple event-type information, achieving better predictive accuracy and generalization.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Existing MTPP models rely on channel-mixing that encodes all event types into a single fixed-size latent representation, entangling type-specific dynamics and increasing overfitting and degrading performance.

Method: Propose ITPP: an encoder-decoder MTPP framework with an ODE-based backbone and a type-aware inverted self-attention mechanism that explicitly models inter-channel correlations among heterogeneous event types to achieve channel independence.

Result: Empirical evaluations on real-world and synthetic datasets show ITPP consistently outperforms state-of-the-art MTPP models in predictive accuracy and generalization.

Conclusion: Channel-independent decoupling of event-type information via ITPP enhances robustness and reduces overfitting, with strong empirical gains across diverse datasets.

Abstract: Marked Temporal Point Processes (MTPPs) provide a principled framework for modeling asynchronous event sequences by conditioning on the history of past events. However, most existing MTPP models rely on channel-mixing strategies that encode information from different event types into a single, fixed-size latent representation. This entanglement can obscure type-specific dynamics, leading to performance degradation and increased risk of overfitting. In this work, we introduce ITPP, a novel channel-independent architecture for MTPP modeling that decouples event type information using an encoder-decoder framework with an ODE-based backbone. Central to ITPP is a type-aware inverted self-attention mechanism, designed to explicitly model inter-channel correlations among heterogeneous event types. This architecture enhances effectiveness and robustness while reducing overfitting. Comprehensive experiments on multiple real-world and synthetic datasets demonstrate that ITPP consistently outperforms state-of-the-art MTPP models in both predictive accuracy and generalization.

</details>


### [246] [Advancing Ocean State Estimation with efficient and scalable AI](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06041)
*Yanfei Xiang,Yuan Gao,Hao Wu,Quan Zhang,Ruiqi Shu,Xiao Zhou,Xi Wu,Xiaomeng Huang*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: AI-driven Data Assimilation Framework for Ocean (ADAF-Ocean) unifies multi-source observations, uses Neural Processes–inspired continuous mapping, and applies super-resolution to generate high-res fields, boosting forecast skill with modest parameter overhead.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To overcome computational scalability and data fidelity limitations in traditional data assimilation and deep learning approaches for global ocean state estimation.

Method: An Neural Processes–inspired continuous mapping that assimilates heterogeneous, multi-scale observations without interpolation or thinning; AI-driven super-resolution to upscale 1° fields to 0.25° mesoscale dynamics; integrates with a DL forecasting system for real-time, high-resolution monitoring.

Result: Reconstructs 0.25° mesoscale dynamics from coarse 1° fields with only 3.7% more parameters than the 1° configuration; when coupled with DL forecasting, extends global forecast skill by up to ~20 days versus baselines without assimilation.

Conclusion: Demonstrates a computationally viable and scientifically rigorous pathway toward real-time, high-resolution global ocean monitoring by unifying assimilation, super-resolution, and forecasting under an AI framework.

Abstract: Accurate and efficient global ocean state estimation remains a grand challenge for Earth system science, hindered by the dual bottlenecks of computational scalability and degraded data fidelity in traditional data assimilation (DA) and deep learning (DL) approaches. Here we present an AI-driven Data Assimilation Framework for Ocean (ADAF-Ocean) that directly assimilates multi-source and multi-scale observations, ranging from sparse in-situ measurements to 4 km satellite swaths, without any interpolation or data thinning. Inspired by Neural Processes, ADAF-Ocean learns a continuous mapping from heterogeneous inputs to ocean states, preserving native data fidelity. Through AI-driven super-resolution, it reconstructs 0.25$^\circ$ mesoscale dynamics from coarse 1$^\circ$ fields, which ensures both efficiency and scalability, with just 3.7\% more parameters than the 1$^\circ$ configuration. When coupled with a DL forecasting system, ADAF-Ocean extends global forecast skill by up to 20 days compared to baselines without assimilation. This framework establishes a computationally viable and scientifically rigorous pathway toward real-time, high-resolution Earth system monitoring.

</details>


### [247] [How Particle-System Random Batch Methods Enhance Graph Transformer: Memory Efficiency and Parallel Computing Strategy](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06044)
*Hanwen Liu,Yixuan Ma,Shi Jin,Yuguang Wang*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Introduces Random Batch Attention (RBA), a linear-time self-attention that preserves expressivity and supports parallel memory-saving implementation, backed by convergence theory and graph experiments.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Standard self-attention is quadratic in sequence length, limiting practicality. Sparse attention methods exist but often lack theoretical guarantees about expressivity. There is a need for a theoretically grounded, scalable attention mechanism.

Method: Proposes Random Batch Attention, a linear self-attention mechanism. It processes tokens in random batches to achieve O(n) time complexity and enables parallelization on a new dimension. It is framed with theory from Random Batch Methods in numerical computation to explain convergence/expressivity.

Result: The approach theoretically preserves expressivity while achieving linear complexity and memory efficiency. It can improve many existing models by replacing their attention modules. Experiments on large graphs show the claimed advantages.

Conclusion: RBA provides a theoretical framework for self-attention and serves as a practical, scalable replacement for attention mechanisms in transformers, with broad applicability and a basis for future research.

Abstract: Attention mechanism is a significant part of Transformer models. It helps extract features from embedded vectors by adding global information and its expressivity has been proved to be powerful. Nevertheless, the quadratic complexity restricts its practicability. Although several researches have provided attention mechanism in sparse form, they are lack of theoretical analysis about the expressivity of their mechanism while reducing complexity. In this paper, we put forward Random Batch Attention (RBA), a linear self-attention mechanism, which has theoretical support of the ability to maintain its expressivity. Random Batch Attention has several significant strengths as follows: (1) Random Batch Attention has linear time complexity. Other than this, it can be implemented in parallel on a new dimension, which contributes to much memory saving. (2) Random Batch Attention mechanism can improve most of the existing models by replacing their attention mechanisms, even many previously improved attention mechanisms. (3) Random Batch Attention mechanism has theoretical explanation in convergence, as it comes from Random Batch Methods on computation mathematics. Experiments on large graphs have proved advantages mentioned above. Also, the theoretical modeling of self-attention mechanism is a new tool for future research on attention-mechanism analysis.

</details>


### [248] [Adapting Web Agents with Synthetic Supervision](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06101)
*Zhaoyang Wang,Yiming Liang,Xuchao Zhang,Qianhui Wu,Siwei Han,Anson Bastos,Rujia Wang,Chetan Bansal,Baolin Peng,Jianfeng Gao,Saravan Rajmohan,Huaxiu Yao*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: SynthAgent introduces a fully synthetic supervision framework with dual refinement of both tasks and trajectories to improve synthetic data quality for web agent adaptation, and outperforms prior synthetic-data methods.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Web agents struggle to adapt to new websites due to the scarcity of environment-specific tasks and demonstrations. While synthetic data generation helps, it often introduces hallucinated tasks and noisy, misaligned trajectories. This motivates a higher-quality synthetic supervision approach.

Method: 1) Synthesize diverse tasks via categorized exploration of web elements to ensure broad coverage of the target environment. 2) Refine tasks during trajectory collection when conflicts with actual observations are detected to mitigate hallucinations while preserving task consistency. 3) Refine trajectories after collection using global context to reduce noise and misalignment. 4) Fine-tune open-source web agents on the refined synthetic data to adapt them to the target environment.

Result: SynthAgent outperforms existing synthetic data methods in experiments, validating the importance of high-quality synthetic supervision.

Conclusion: High-quality synthetic supervision is crucial for adapting web agents to new environments; dual refinement of tasks and trajectories yields better data and performance, with the code released publicly.

Abstract: Web agents struggle to adapt to new websites due to the scarcity of environment specific tasks and demonstrations. Recent works have explored synthetic data generation to address this challenge, however, they suffer from data quality issues where synthesized tasks contain hallucinations that cannot be executed, and collected trajectories are noisy with redundant or misaligned actions. In this paper, we propose SynthAgent, a fully synthetic supervision framework that aims at improving synthetic data quality via dual refinement of both tasks and trajectories. Our approach begins by synthesizing diverse tasks through categorized exploration of web elements, ensuring efficient coverage of the target environment. During trajectory collection, we refine tasks when conflicts with actual observations are detected, mitigating hallucinations while maintaining task consistency. After collection, we conduct trajectory refinement with a global context to mitigate potential noise or misalignments. Finally, we fine-tune open-source web agents on the refined synthetic data to adapt them to the target environment. Experimental results demonstrate that SynthAgent outperforms existing synthetic data methods, validating the importance of high-quality synthetic supervision. The code will be publicly available at https://github.com/aiming-lab/SynthAgent.

</details>


### [249] [Models Got Talent: Identifying High Performing Wearable Human Activity Recognition Models Without Training](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06157)
*Richard Goldman,Varun Komperla,Thomas Ploetz,Harish Haresamudram*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Zero-cost proxies enable NAS for HAR by evaluating networks with a single forward/backward pass on a random batch, achieving within 5% of fully trained models across six datasets, with substantial computational savings and robustness to noise.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Neural Architecture Search is computationally expensive. For sensor-based HAR, efficient search is crucial. Zero-cost proxies (ZCPs) offer a cheap, correlate-with-performance metric that can be computed with a single pass, enabling rapid discovery of high-performing architectures.

Method: Apply ZCPs to HAR across six benchmark datasets. For each candidate architecture, compute the proxy from a single forward/backward pass on a randomly sampled batch. Use these proxies to select promising architectures, then train and evaluate them fully. Compare the best ZCP-selected architectures to a baseline obtained from 1500 randomly sampled architectures fully trained. Additionally, assess robustness to data noise.

Result: Architectures identified via ZCPs reach within 5% of the performance of fully trained models, while requiring far less computational effort than training 1500 architectures. The approach demonstrates substantial computational savings and robustness to data noise across the six HAR benchmarks.

Conclusion: Zero-cost proxies are effective for sensor-based HAR NAS, enabling near-parity with fully trained models at a fraction of the cost and showing resilience to noisy data. This supports adopting ZCPs for practical HAR deployment and suggests potential applicability to other sensor-based tasks.

Abstract: A promising alternative to the computationally expensive Neural Architecture Search (NAS) involves the development of \textit{Zero Cost Proxies (ZCPs)}, which correlate well to trained performance, but can be computed through a single forward/backward pass on a randomly sampled batch of data. In this paper, we investigate the effectiveness of ZCPs for HAR on six benchmark datasets, and demonstrate that they discover network architectures that obtain within 5\% of performance attained by full scale training involving 1500 randomly sampled architectures. This results in substantial computational savings as high performing architectures can be discovered with minimal training. Our experiments not only introduce ZCPs to sensor-based HAR, but also demonstrate that they are robust to data noise, further showcasing their suitability for practical scenarios.

</details>


### [250] [LLM Attention Transplant for Transfer Learning of Tabular Data Across Disparate Domains](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06161)
*Ibna Kowsar,Kazi F. Akhter,Manar D. Samad*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Transferring attention from a fine-tuned LLM to a tabular-friendly gated transformer enables cross-domain tabular transfer learning (LATTLE) with low-resource data, outperforming baselines.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Tabular data suffer from feature-space heterogeneity across domains; LLM-based transfer learning is hindered by prompts and in-context learning for mixed data types. A low-resource, prompt-free transfer mechanism is needed.

Method: Fine-tune an LLM on source tabular data and transplant its selective key/value projection weights into a gated feature tokenized transformer (gFTT) for tabular data. The gFTT, with cross-domain attention, is then fine-tuned on target data, bypassing shared feature requirements, prompt engineering, and large pretrained models.

Result: Empirical evaluation on ten source-target pairs against 12 baselines shows LATTLE outperforms traditional ML, state-of-the-art deep tabular models, and transfer-learning models trained on vast tabular data.

Conclusion: Attention transfer from LLMs to a tabular-focused transformer provides an effective, low-resource transfer learning approach for learning relationships between data tables; code is publicly available.

Abstract: Transfer learning of tabular data is non-trivial due to heterogeneity in the feature space across disparate domains. The limited success of traditional deep learning in tabular knowledge transfer can be advanced by leveraging large language models (LLMs). However, the efficacy of LLMs often stagnates for mixed data types structured in tables due to the limitations of text prompts and in-context learning. We propose a lightweight transfer learning framework that fine-tunes an LLM using source tabular data and transplants the LLM's selective $key$ and $value$ projection weights into a gated feature tokenized transformer (gFTT) built for tabular data. The gFTT model with cross-domain attention is fine-tuned using target tabular data for transfer learning, eliminating the need for shared features, LLM prompt engineering, and large-scale pretrained models. Our experiments using ten pairs of source-target data sets and 12 baselines demonstrate the superiority of the proposed LLM-attention transplant for transfer learning (LATTLE) method over traditional ML models, state-of-the-art deep tabular architectures, and transfer learning models trained on thousands to billions of tabular samples. The proposed attention transfer demonstrates an effective solution to learning relationships between data tables using an LLM in a low-resource learning environment. The source code for the proposed method is publicly available.

</details>


### [251] [Resilience Inference for Supply Chains with Hypergraph Neural Network](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06208)
*Zetian Shen,Hongjun Wang,Jiyuan Chen,Xuan Song*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Introduces SCRI (Supply Chain Resilience Inference) and the SC-RIHN hypergraph model to predict resilience from hypergraph topology and inventory trajectories without explicit dynamics, showing superior performance on synthetic benchmarks over MLPs, standard GNNs, and ResInf; suggests practical potential for early-warning risk assessment.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Supply chains are vulnerable to disruptions that propagate through networks; existing methods inadequately infer resilience without explicit dynamic equations and fail to capture higher-order, multi-entity interactions. There is a need for a method to infer resilience from observed data alone to guide proactive risk mitigation and robust design.

Method: Propose SCRI problem definition and SC-RIHN, a hypergraph-based network that uses set-based encoding and hypergraph message passing to model multi-party firm-product interactions without explicit system dynamics.

Result: SC-RIHN significantly outperforms traditional MLPs, representative graph neural networks, and ResInf baselines on synthetic benchmarks, indicating strong predictive capability for resilience inference.

Conclusion: SC-RIHN holds promise for practical, early-warning risk assessment in complex supply chain systems and could inform proactive mitigation and robust network design.

Abstract: Supply chains are integral to global economic stability, yet disruptions can swiftly propagate through interconnected networks, resulting in substantial economic impacts. Accurate and timely inference of supply chain resilience the capability to maintain core functions during disruptions is crucial for proactive risk mitigation and robust network design. However, existing approaches lack effective mechanisms to infer supply chain resilience without explicit system dynamics and struggle to represent the higher-order, multi-entity dependencies inherent in supply chain networks. These limitations motivate the definition of a novel problem and the development of targeted modeling solutions. To address these challenges, we formalize a novel problem: Supply Chain Resilience Inference (SCRI), defined as predicting supply chain resilience using hypergraph topology and observed inventory trajectories without explicit dynamic equations. To solve this problem, we propose the Supply Chain Resilience Inference Hypergraph Network (SC-RIHN), a novel hypergraph-based model leveraging set-based encoding and hypergraph message passing to capture multi-party firm-product interactions. Comprehensive experiments demonstrate that SC-RIHN significantly outperforms traditional MLP, representative graph neural network variants, and ResInf baselines across synthetic benchmarks, underscoring its potential for practical, early-warning risk assessment in complex supply chain systems.

</details>


### [252] [Scaling Laws and In-Context Learning: A Unified Theoretical Framework](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06232)
*Sushant Mehta,Ishan Gupta*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A unified theory links in-context learning (ICL) in transformers to scaling laws, showing ICL performance follows power laws in depth L, width d, context length k, and data D, with task-structure-determined exponents. Under certain conditions, forward-pass gradient-based meta-learning emerges with an effective learning rate η_eff ~ 1/√(L d). The paper identifies sharp phase transitions at critical scales and an optimal depth-width allocation under parameter budget N = L d (L* ~ N^{2/3}, d* ~ N^{1/3}). Synthetic-task experiments validate the theory; the work offers necessary and sufficient conditions for ICL emergence and delineates computational limits for what transformers can learn in-context.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To build a principled, scaling-based understanding of when and how in-context learning emerges in transformers, connecting empirical observations with a formal theory and identifying fundamental computational limits and optimal resource allocations.

Method: Develop a unified theoretical framework relating ICL to scaling laws; derive power-law dependencies on model size, context, and data; show conditions under which the forward pass implements gradient-based metalearning with a calculable effective learning rate; analyze phase transitions; optimize depth-width allocation given a fixed parameter budget; validate predictions on synthetic tasks with controlled experiments.

Result: Derives power-law relationships for ICL performance with exponents determined by task structure; demonstrates forward-pass gradient-based meta-learning with η_eff ~ 1/√(L d); identifies phase transitions at critical scales; provides optimal L*, d* under N = Ld; synthetic experiments corroborate the theory with exponents matching predictions.

Conclusion: Provides necessary and sufficient conditions for the emergence of ICL and maps fundamental computational limits of transformers' ability to learn in-context, including actionable guidelines for resource allocation across depth and width.

Abstract: In-context learning (ICL) enables large language models to adapt to new tasks from demonstrations without parameter updates. Despite extensive empirical studies, a principled understanding of ICL emergence at scale remains more elusive. We present a unified theoretical framework connecting scaling laws to ICL emergence in transformers. Our analysis establishes that ICL performance follows power-law relationships with model depth $L$, width $d$, context length $k$, and training data $D$, with exponents determined by task structure. We show that under specific conditions, transformers implement gradient-based metalearning in their forward pass, with an effective learning rate $η_{\text{eff}} = Θ(1/\sqrt{Ld})$. We demonstrate sharp phase transitions at critical scales and derive optimal depth-width allocations favoring $L^* \propto N^{2/3}$, $d^* \propto N^{1/3}$ for the fixed parameter budget $N = Ld$. Systematic experiments on synthetic tasks validate our predictions, with measured scaling exponents closely matching theory. This work provides both necessary and sufficient conditions for the emergence of ICLs and establishes fundamental computational limits on what transformers can learn in-context.

</details>


### [253] [Mixtures of SubExperts for Large Language Continual Learning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06237)
*Haeyong Kang*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: MoSEs introduce a sparse mixture of sub-experts in transformer layers with a task-specific router to minimize forgetting and enable sublinear growth; it outperforms standard PEFT in continual learning on TRACE, with memory/computation savings.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Continual learning for LLMs with PEFT faces catastrophic forgetting when reusing a single parameter set and inefficiency when allocating new parameters per task. A method that isolates knowledge while enabling transfer is needed.

Method: Integrate a sparse Mixture of SubExperts into transformer layers. A task-specific router selects and combines previously learned sparse parameters, enabling isolation and protection of knowledge in dedicated SubExperts. Capacity grows sublinearly due to sparse, shared usage.

Result: On TRACE benchmark datasets, MoSEs significantly outperform conventional continual learning approaches in knowledge retention and scalability, achieving state-of-the-art performance with notable memory and computational savings.

Conclusion: MoSEs offer an adaptive, scalable PEFT framework for continual learning that minimizes forgetting and facilitates knowledge transfer across tasks, with sublinear growth in model size; promising direction for scalable LLM adaptation.

Abstract: Adapting Large Language Models (LLMs) to a continuous stream of tasks is a critical yet challenging endeavor. While Parameter-Efficient Fine-Tuning (PEFT) methods have become a standard for this, they face a fundamental dilemma in continual learning. Reusing a single set of PEFT parameters for new tasks often leads to catastrophic forgetting of prior knowledge. Conversely, allocating distinct parameters for each task prevents forgetting but results in a linear growth of the model's size and fails to facilitate knowledge transfer between related tasks. To overcome these limitations, we propose a novel adaptive PEFT method referred to as \textit{Mixtures of SubExperts (MoSEs)}, a novel continual learning framework designed for minimal forgetting and efficient scalability. MoSEs integrate a sparse Mixture of SubExperts into the transformer layers, governed by a task-specific routing mechanism. This architecture allows the model to isolate and protect knowledge within dedicated SubExperts, thereby minimizing parameter interference and catastrophic forgetting. Crucially, the router can adaptively select and combine previously learned sparse parameters for new tasks, enabling effective knowledge transfer while ensuring that the model's capacity grows sublinearly. We evaluate MoSEs on the comprehensive TRACE benchmark datasets. Our experiments demonstrate that MoSEs significantly outperform conventional continual learning approaches in both knowledge retention and scalability to new tasks, achieving state-of-the-art performance with substantial memory and computational savings.

</details>


### [254] [Constraint-Informed Active Learning for End-to-End ACOPF Optimization Proxies](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06248)
*Miao Li,Michael Klamkin,Pascal Van Hentenryck,Wenting Li,Russell Bent*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Active sampling for ACOPF ML proxies using active constraint sets to generate diverse, realistic training data; yields better generalization under the same budget.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Training data quality limits ML-based ACOPF proxies; need data reflecting plausible operational conditions and feasible constraint activity.

Method: An active sampling framework that explores varied problem specs and uses optimization-specific quantities (active constraint sets) as features to train proxies.

Result: Demonstrates superior generalization to unseen instances with equal training budget compared to existing sampling methods.

Conclusion: Active, constraint-aware data generation significantly improves trustworthiness and performance of ACOPF optimization proxies.

Abstract: This paper studies optimization proxies, machine learning (ML) models trained to efficiently predict optimal solutions for AC Optimal Power Flow (ACOPF) problems. While promising, optimization proxy performance heavily depends on training data quality. To address this limitation, this paper introduces a novel active sampling framework for ACOPF optimization proxies designed to generate realistic and diverse training data. The framework actively explores varied, flexible problem specifications reflecting plausible operational realities. More importantly, the approach uses optimization-specific quantities (active constraint sets) that better capture the salient features of an ACOPF that lead to the optimal solution. Numerical results show superior generalization over existing sampling methods with an equivalent training budget, significantly advancing the state-of-practice for trustworthy ACOPF optimization proxies.

</details>


### [255] [MrCoM: A Meta-Regularized World-Model Generalizing Across Multi-Scenarios](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06252)
*Xuantang Xiong,Ni Mu,Runpeng Xie,Senhao Yang,Yaqing Wang,Lexiang Wang,Yao Luan,Siyuan Li,Shuang Xu,Yiqin Yang,Bo Xu*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: MrCoM proposes a unified, multi-scenario model-based RL framework that generalizes across scenarios by factoring latent dynamics and using meta-regularization; it provides theoretical generalization bounds and reports empirical gains over state-of-the-art methods.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Generalization across different scenarios remains a key challenge in model-based RL. While many MBRL methods build world models for single tasks, dynamics within a single simulation engine share invariants. A unified world model across scenarios could improve generalization and sample efficiency.

Method: 1) Decompose latent state into components based on dynamic characteristics to improve world-model prediction accuracy. 2) Introduce meta-state regularization to extract a unified representation of scenario-relevant information. 3) Introduce meta-value regularization to align world-model optimization with policy learning across diverse scenario objectives. 4) Provide theoretical analysis of the generalization error upper bound in multi-scenario settings. 5) Empirically evaluate generalization across diverse scenarios, comparing to prior SOTA methods.

Result: The approach yields significantly better generalization performance across diverse scenarios compared with previous state-of-the-art methods, as evidenced by systematic experiments.

Conclusion: A unified, factorized, regularized world model can generalize across multiple scenarios in model-based RL. Theoretical bounds underpin the generalization claims, and empirical results demonstrate practical gains over existing methods.

Abstract: Model-based reinforcement learning (MBRL) is a crucial approach to enhance the generalization capabilities and improve the sample efficiency of RL algorithms. However, current MBRL methods focus primarily on building world models for single tasks and rarely address generalization across different scenarios. Building on the insight that dynamics within the same simulation engine share inherent properties, we attempt to construct a unified world model capable of generalizing across different scenarios, named Meta-Regularized Contextual World-Model (MrCoM). This method first decomposes the latent state space into various components based on the dynamic characteristics, thereby enhancing the accuracy of world-model prediction. Further, MrCoM adopts meta-state regularization to extract unified representation of scenario-relevant information, and meta-value regularization to align world-model optimization with policy learning across diverse scenario objectives. We theoretically analyze the generalization error upper bound of MrCoM in multi-scenario settings. We systematically evaluate our algorithm's generalization ability across diverse scenarios, demonstrating significantly better performance than previous state-of-the-art methods.

</details>


### [256] [Breaking the Modality Barrier: Generative Modeling for Accurate Molecule Retrieval from Mass Spectra](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06259)
*Yiwen Zhang,Keyan Ding,Yihang Wu,Xiang Zhuang,Yi Yang,Qiang Zhang,Huajun Chen*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: GLMR is a two-stage generative retrieval framework for MS/MS spectra that uses a contrastive pre-retrieval step to propose candidates and a generative stage to refine and re-rank via molecular similarity, achieving large gains (over 40% top-1) and strong generalization.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address limited spectral library coverage and cross-modal misalignment between mass spectra and molecular structures in retrieval tasks.

Method: Two-stage process: (1) pre-retrieval contrastive model selects top candidate molecules as contextual priors; (2) generative retrieval integrates these candidates with the input spectrum to generate refined structures, which are used to re-rank candidates by molecular similarity.

Result: GLMR outperforms existing methods, with over 40% improvement in top-1 accuracy, and demonstrates strong generalizability on MassSpecGym and MassRET-20k datasets.

Conclusion: GLMR effectively mitigates cross-modal misalignment in MS/MS retrieval by combining contrastive pre-retrieval with generative refinement, offering improved accuracy and generalization.

Abstract: Retrieving molecular structures from tandem mass spectra is a crucial step in rapid compound identification. Existing retrieval methods, such as traditional mass spectral library matching, suffer from limited spectral library coverage, while recent cross-modal representation learning frameworks often encounter modality misalignment, resulting in suboptimal retrieval accuracy and generalization. To address these limitations, we propose GLMR, a Generative Language Model-based Retrieval framework that mitigates the cross-modal misalignment through a two-stage process. In the pre-retrieval stage, a contrastive learning-based model identifies top candidate molecules as contextual priors for the input mass spectrum. In the generative retrieval stage, these candidate molecules are integrated with the input mass spectrum to guide a generative model in producing refined molecular structures, which are then used to re-rank the candidates based on molecular similarity. Experiments on both MassSpecGym and the proposed MassRET-20k dataset demonstrate that GLMR significantly outperforms existing methods, achieving over 40% improvement in top-1 accuracy and exhibiting strong generalizability.

</details>


### [257] [COTN: A Chaotic Oscillatory Transformer Network for Complex Volatile Systems under Extreme Conditions](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06273)
*Boyan Tang,Yilong Zeng,Xuanhao Ren,Peng Xiao,Yuhan Zhao,Raymond Lee,Jianghua Wu*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Introduces Chaotic Oscillatory Transformer Network (COTN), a Transformer-based model with a novel Lee Oscillator activation, Max-over-Time pooling, and lambda-gating, plus an Autoencoder Self-Regressive (ASR) module for anomaly isolation. Demonstrates robustness to volatility and improved accuracy (up to 17% on Informer, up to 40% on GARCH) in electricity and financial markets.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Financial and electricity markets are highly nonlinear, rapidly fluctuating, and can be chaotic, especially under extreme conditions. Traditional activations (ReLU, GELU) can saturate and fail to capture dynamics, necessitating models that better handle volatility and abrupt pattern changes.

Method: Propose COTN architecture that combines: (1) Transformer backbone, (2) Lee Oscillator activation, (3) Max-over-Time pooling, and (4) lambda-gating mechanism. Includes an Autoencoder Self-Regressive (ASR) module to detect and isolate abnormal market patterns (e.g., spikes/crashes) to prevent corruption of predictions. Evaluate on electricity spot markets and financial markets, comparing against state-of-the-art methods.

Result: COTN demonstrates practical applicability and resilience, outperforming Informer by up to 17% and GARCH by as much as 40%, indicating improved forecasting under real-world market uncertainty and complexity.

Conclusion: COTN effectively navigates highly volatile systems and under duress, offering a robust forecasting tool for markets characterized by nonlinear dynamics and sudden regime shifts.

Abstract: Accurate prediction of financial and electricity markets, especially under extreme conditions, remains a significant challenge due to their intrinsic nonlinearity, rapid fluctuations, and chaotic patterns. To address these limitations, we propose the Chaotic Oscillatory Transformer Network (COTN). COTN innovatively combines a Transformer architecture with a novel Lee Oscillator activation function, processed through Max-over-Time pooling and a lambda-gating mechanism. This design is specifically tailored to effectively capture chaotic dynamics and improve responsiveness during periods of heightened volatility, where conventional activation functions (e.g., ReLU, GELU) tend to saturate. Furthermore, COTN incorporates an Autoencoder Self-Regressive (ASR) module to detect and isolate abnormal market patterns, such as sudden price spikes or crashes, thereby preventing corruption of the core prediction process and enhancing robustness. Extensive experiments across electricity spot markets and financial markets demonstrate the practical applicability and resilience of COTN. Our approach outperforms state-of-the-art deep learning models like Informer by up to 17% and traditional statistical methods like GARCH by as much as 40%. These results underscore COTN's effectiveness in navigating real-world market uncertainty and complexity, offering a powerful tool for forecasting highly volatile systems under duress.

</details>


### [258] [Transolver is a Linear Transformer: Revisiting Physics-Attention through the Lens of Linear Attention](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06294)
*Wenjie Hu,Sidun Liu,Peng Qiao,Zhenglun Sun,Yong Dou*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: LinearNO: reinterpret Physics-Attention as canonical linear attention to remove slice/deslice reliance, achieving state-of-the-art PDE performance with fewer parameters and lower compute.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Reduce the computational burden of Transformer-based Neural Operators for PDEs by moving away from quadratic attention; uncover that slice-attention mechanics are not essential and that linear attention suffices.

Method: Two-step transformation that recasts Physics-Attention into canonical linear attention, producing Linear Attention Neural Operator (LinearNO).

Result: State-of-the-art on six standard PDE benchmarks; parameter count reduced by ~40% and computational cost by ~36.2%; strong performance on industrial datasets AirfRANS and Shape-Net Car.

Conclusion: LinearNO demonstrates that slice/deslice operations are not the key source of performance gains; a canonical linear-attention formulation yields superior accuracy-efficiency trade-offs and generalizes well to real-world industrial PDE problems.

Abstract: Recent advances in Transformer-based Neural Operators have enabled significant progress in data-driven solvers for Partial Differential Equations (PDEs). Most current research has focused on reducing the quadratic complexity of attention to address the resulting low training and inference efficiency. Among these works, Transolver stands out as a representative method that introduces Physics-Attention to reduce computational costs. Physics-Attention projects grid points into slices for slice attention, then maps them back through deslicing. However, we observe that Physics-Attention can be reformulated as a special case of linear attention, and that the slice attention may even hurt the model performance. Based on these observations, we argue that its effectiveness primarily arises from the slice and deslice operations rather than interactions between slices. Building on this insight, we propose a two-step transformation to redesign Physics-Attention into a canonical linear attention, which we call Linear Attention Neural Operator (LinearNO). Our method achieves state-of-the-art performance on six standard PDE benchmarks, while reducing the number of parameters by an average of 40.0% and computational cost by 36.2%. Additionally, it delivers superior performance on two challenging, industrial-level datasets: AirfRANS and Shape-Net Car.

</details>


### [259] [Kaggle Chronicles: 15 Years of Competitions, Community and Data Science Innovation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06304)
*Kevin Bönisch,Leandro Losaria*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Kaggle's 15-year evolution reveals a growing, diverse data science ecosystem where competitions, notebooks, forums, and meta datasets provide stable evidence of rapid trend adoption and robust model generalization.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To understand how Kaggle's expansion reflects broader data science practices and what meta-data reveals about trends, performance, and real-world impact of Kaggle-driven work.

Method: Meta-analysis of Kaggle Meta Code and Meta Datasets, plus analysis of millions of kernels and discussion threads using longitudinal trend analysis and exploratory data analysis; examine competition winners, problem-solving approaches, and real-world applicability; synthesize quantitative trends with qualitative insights; reference accompanying video and Kaggle write-ups.

Result: Kaggle shows steady growth and increasingly diverse use cases; participants quickly adapt to new techniques and apply them to real-world challenges; models tend to generalize well across tasks; the platform's history and technological evolution are documented.

Conclusion: Kaggle functions as a microcosm of data science practice, offering insights for platform design, education, and community dynamics; meta resources (code and datasets) enable richer, data-driven understandings of the field.

Abstract: Since 2010, Kaggle has been a platform where data scientists from around the world come together to compete, collaborate, and push the boundaries of Data Science. Over these 15 years, it has grown from a purely competition-focused site into a broader ecosystem with forums, notebooks, models, datasets, and more. With the release of the Kaggle Meta Code and Kaggle Meta Datasets, we now have a unique opportunity to explore these competitions, technologies, and real-world applications of Machine Learning and AI. And so in this study, we take a closer look at 15 years of data science on Kaggle - through metadata, shared code, community discussions, and the competitions themselves. We explore Kaggle's growth, its impact on the data science community, uncover hidden technological trends, analyze competition winners, how Kagglers approach problems in general, and more. We do this by analyzing millions of kernels and discussion threads to perform both longitudinal trend analysis and standard exploratory data analysis. Our findings show that Kaggle is a steadily growing platform with increasingly diverse use cases, and that Kagglers are quick to adapt to new trends and apply them to real-world challenges, while producing - on average - models with solid generalization capabilities. We also offer a snapshot of the platform as a whole, highlighting its history and technological evolution. Finally, this study is accompanied by a video (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YVOV9bIUNrM) and a Kaggle write-up (https://kaggle.com/competitions/meta-kaggle-hackathon/writeups/kaggle-chronicles-15-years-of-competitions-communi) for your convenience.

</details>


### [260] [Reaction Prediction via Interaction Modeling of Symmetric Difference Shingle Sets](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06356)
*Runhan Shi,Letian Chen,Gufeng Yu,Yang Yang*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: ReaDISH is a permutation-invariant reaction predictor that uses symmetric difference shingle encoding and geometry-structure interaction attention to model substructural interactions, achieving improved robustness under permutation perturbations.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Current ML models for reaction prediction are sensitive to input permutations (molecule/atom orderings) and fail to capture substructural interactions governing reactivity, leading to unstable predictions and poor generalization.

Method: Introduce symmetric difference shingle encoding to capture reaction-specific structural changes while removing order dependence; implement geometry-structure interaction attention to model intra- and inter-molecular interactions at the shingle level.

Result: Extensive experiments across benchmarks show improved performance; robustness improves by about 8.76% on R^2 under permutation perturbations.

Conclusion: ReaDISH offers a robust, permutation-invariant, interaction-aware framework for reaction prediction with improved generalization, demonstrating strong potential for real-world applicability.

Abstract: Chemical reaction prediction remains a fundamental challenge in organic chemistry, where existing machine learning models face two critical limitations: sensitivity to input permutations (molecule/atom orderings) and inadequate modeling of substructural interactions governing reactivity. These shortcomings lead to inconsistent predictions and poor generalization to real-world scenarios. To address these challenges, we propose ReaDISH, a novel reaction prediction model that learns permutation-invariant representations while incorporating interaction-aware features. It introduces two innovations: (1) symmetric difference shingle encoding, which computes molecular shingle differences to capture reaction-specific structural changes while eliminating order sensitivity; and (2) geometry-structure interaction attention, a mechanism that models intra- and inter-molecular interactions at the shingle level. Extensive experiments demonstrate that ReaDISH improves reaction prediction performance across diverse benchmarks. It shows enhanced robustness with an average improvement of 8.76% on R$^2$ under permutation perturbations.

</details>


### [261] [Privacy-Preserving Federated Learning for Fair and Efficient Urban Traffic Optimization](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06363)
*Rathin Chandra Shit,Sharmila Subudhi*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A privacy-preserving federated learning framework (FedFair-Traffic) that jointly optimizes travel efficiency, traffic fairness, and differential privacy using Graph Neural Networks, DP mechanisms, and Gini-based fairness constraints. Demonstrates Pareto-efficient tradeoffs with real-world METR-LA data, achieving lower travel time, improved fairness, strong privacy, and reduced communication overhead.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Urban traffic optimization must balance efficiency, privacy, and equity. Centralized schemes invade user privacy and may worsen disparities; existing federated learning lacks explicit fairness constraints in multi-objective traffic settings.

Method: Propose FedFair-Traffic, a privacy-preserving federated learning framework that combines Graph Neural Networks with differential privacy (via gradient clipping and noise injection) and Gini coefficient-based fairness constraints. Utilizes multi-objective optimization to converge to Pareto-efficient solutions while preserving data locality among vehicles.

Result: On METR-LA data, reduces average travel time by 7% (≈14.2 minutes) versus centralized baselines, improves traffic fairness by 73% (Gini = 0.78), achieves high privacy protection (privacy score = 0.8), and reduces communication overhead by 89%.

Conclusion: This work is the first to integrate efficiency, fairness, and differential privacy in a unified federated framework for urban traffic, showing scalability and potential for real-world deployment in metropolitan traffic control and federated transportation networks.

Abstract: The optimization of urban traffic is threatened by the complexity of achieving a balance between transport efficiency and the maintenance of privacy, as well as the equitable distribution of traffic based on socioeconomically diverse neighborhoods. Current centralized traffic management schemes invade user location privacy and further entrench traffic disparity by offering disadvantaged route suggestions, whereas current federated learning frameworks do not consider fairness constraints in multi-objective traffic settings. This study presents a privacy-preserving federated learning framework, termed FedFair-Traffic, that jointly and simultaneously optimizes travel efficiency, traffic fairness, and differential privacy protection. This is the first attempt to integrate three conflicting objectives to improve urban transportation systems. The proposed methodology enables collaborative learning between related vehicles with data locality by integrating Graph Neural Networks with differential privacy mechanisms ($ε$-privacy guarantees) and Gini coefficient-based fair constraints using multi-objective optimization. The framework uses federated aggregation methods of gradient clipping and noise injection to provide differential privacy and optimize Pareto-efficient solutions for the efficiency-fairness tradeoff. Real-world comprehensive experiments on the METR-LA traffic dataset showed that FedFair-Traffic can reduce the average travel time by 7\% (14.2 minutes) compared with their centralized baselines, promote traffic fairness by 73\% (Gini coefficient, 0.78), and offer high privacy protection (privacy score, 0.8) with an 89\% reduction in communication overhead. These outcomes demonstrate that FedFair-Traffic is a scalable privacy-aware smart city infrastructure with possible use-cases in metropolitan traffic flow control and federated transportation networks.

</details>


### [262] [FLEX: Continuous Agent Evolution via Forward Learning from Experience](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06449)
*Zhicheng Cai,Xinyuan Guo,Yu Pei,JiangTao Feng,Jiangjie Chen,Ya-Qin Zhang,Wei-Ying Ma,Mingxuan Wang,Hao Zhou*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: FLEX introduces a gradient-free, experiential learning paradigm that lets LLM agents continuously evolve via a structured experience library built from ongoing reflection on successes and failures, enabling scalable and inheritable improvement across tasks.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: LLM agents currently stop learning after deployment, hindering growth with experience. FLEX aims to enable lifelong, scalable improvement by leveraging accumulated experience without gradient-based updates.

Method: Construct a structured experience library through continual reflection on interactions with the environment. Use gradient-free updates to evolve capabilities via experience inheritance and scalability across agents, enabling progressive improvement across domains.

Result: Significant performance gains across domains: up to 23% on AIME25 (mathematical reasoning), 10% on USPTO50k (chemical retrosynthesis), and 14% on ProteinGym (protein fitness). Evidence of a scaling law for experiential growth and cross-agent experience inheritance.

Conclusion: FLEX demonstrates scalable, inheritable continuous agent evolution, representing a step toward lifelong learning for LLM-based agents and suggesting new directions for AI systems to grow from experience without gradients.

Abstract: Autonomous agents driven by Large Language Models (LLMs) have revolutionized reasoning and problem-solving but remain static after training, unable to grow with experience as intelligent beings do during deployment. We introduce Forward Learning with EXperience (FLEX), a gradient-free learning paradigm that enables LLM agents to continuously evolve through accumulated experience. Specifically, FLEX cultivates scalable and inheritable evolution by constructing a structured experience library through continual reflection on successes and failures during interaction with the environment. FLEX delivers substantial improvements on mathematical reasoning, chemical retrosynthesis, and protein fitness prediction (up to 23% on AIME25, 10% on USPTO50k, and 14% on ProteinGym). We further identify a clear scaling law of experiential growth and the phenomenon of experience inheritance across agents, marking a step toward scalable and inheritable continuous agent evolution. Project Page: https://flex-gensi-thuair.github.io.

</details>


### [263] [Explainable AI For Early Detection Of Sepsis](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06492)
*Atharva Thakur,Shruti Dhumal*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Interpretable AI for sepsis prediction that combines ML with clinical knowledge to improve accuracy while preserving explainability and clinical trust.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Sepsis requires rapid detection but ML models are often black-box; there is a need for models that are accurate and interpretable, aligning with medical expertise.

Method: An interpretable AI framework that integrates machine learning with clinical knowledge, producing predictions that clinicians can understand, validate, and align with established expertise.

Result: The approach yields accurate predictions of sepsis onset and outputs that are interpretable and align with clinical reasoning, enhancing trust and potential adoption.

Conclusion: An interpretable AI approach for sepsis analysis that bridges ML power and clinical knowledge, potentially improving decision support and clinician trust.

Abstract: Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that requires rapid detection and treatment to prevent progression to severe sepsis, septic shock, or multi-organ failure. Despite advances in medical technology, it remains a major challenge for clinicians. While recent machine learning models have shown promise in predicting sepsis onset, their black-box nature limits interpretability and clinical trust. In this study, we present an interpretable AI approach for sepsis analysis that integrates machine learning with clinical knowledge. Our method not only delivers accurate predictions of sepsis onset but also enables clinicians to understand, validate, and align model outputs with established medical expertise.

</details>


### [264] [Route Experts by Sequence, not by Token](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06494)
*Tiansheng Wen,Yifei Wang,Aosong Feng,Long Ma,Xinyang Liu,Yifan Wang,Lixuan Guo,Bo Chen,Stefanie Jegelka,Chenyu You*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: SeqTopK redefines expert routing by selecting the top T*K experts across the entire token sequence, moving the budget from per-token to sequence-level. This enables end-to-end learned allocation, keeps total compute unchanged, requires minimal code, and improves performance—especially under high sparsity.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Standard TopK fixes the number of active experts per token, ignoring token difficulty. Prior adaptive routing methods add modules and hyperparameters and often require retraining from scratch. The goal is a simple, compatible, and scalable routing improvement that dynamically allocates compute according to token complexity without heavy overhead.

Method: Move the budget from token-level to sequence-level by selecting the top T*K experts across all T tokens in a sequence. This yields a global allocation that increases experts for hard tokens and reduces for easy ones, while preserving the overall budget. The approach is implemented with only a few lines of code and minor overhead, and remains compatible with pretrained MoE models.

Result: Empirical evaluations across math, coding, law, and writing show SeqTopK consistently outperforms standard TopK and prior parameter-free adaptive methods. Gains escalate with higher sparsity, reaching up to 16.9% in performance improvements.

Conclusion: SeqTopK is a simple, efficient, and scalable routing strategy well-suited for extreme sparsity regimes in next-generation LLMs. It maintains compatibility with existing MoE models while delivering notable gains with minimal code changes and overhead.

Abstract: Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) architectures scale large language models (LLMs) by activating only a subset of experts per token, but the standard TopK routing assigns the same fixed number of experts to all tokens, ignoring their varying complexity. Prior adaptive routing methods introduce additional modules and hyperparameters, often requiring costly retraining from scratch. We propose Sequence-level TopK (SeqTopK), a minimal modification that shifts the expert budget from the token level to the sequence level.
