By selecting the top $T \cdot K$ experts across all $T$ tokens, SeqTopK enables end-to-end learned dynamic allocation -- assigning more experts to difficult tokens and fewer to easy ones -- while preserving the same overall budget. SeqTopK requires only a few lines of code, adds less than 1% overhead, and remains fully compatible with pretrained MoE models. Experiments across math, coding, law, and writing show consistent improvements over TopK and prior parameter-free adaptive methods, with gains that become substantially larger under higher sparsity (up to 16.9%). These results highlight SeqTopK as a simple, efficient, and scalable routing strategy, particularly well-suited for the extreme sparsity regimes of next-generation LLMs. Code is available at https://github.com/Y-Research-SBU/SeqTopK.

</details>


### [265] [TriShGAN: Enhancing Sparsity and Robustness in Multivariate Time Series Counterfactuals Explanation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06529)
*Hongnan Ma,Yiwei Shi,Guanxiong Sun,Mengyue Yang,Weiru Liu*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: TriShGAN enhances counterfactual explanations for multivariate time series by combining CounteRGAN with triplet loss and a Shapelet Extractor to improve robustness and sparsity.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Generate robust, realistic counterfactuals for multivariate time series that remain near the queried instance and align with the desired outcome distribution, addressing limitations of substitution-based methods and residual GANs that ignore decision boundary distance.

Method: An unsupervised learning framework (TriShGAN) within CounteRGAN augmented by triplet loss to enforce a distance metric learning objective. A Shapelet Extractor identifies discriminative subsequences to promote sparsity and training efficiency, enabling the model to focus on key features while generating counterfactuals.

Result: The approach aims to yield counterfactual explanations that balance minimal deviation from the queried time series with robustness to model perturbations and realism by capturing the feature distribution of the target outcome, achieving sparser and potentially more robust explanations.

Conclusion: TriShGAN offers a robust, efficient method for producing counterfactual explanations in multivariate time series by integrating triplet-distance learning and shapelet-based sparsity into the CounteRGAN framework, potentially improving applicability in real-world decision tasks.

Abstract: In decision-making processes, stakeholders often rely on counterfactual explanations, which provide suggestions about what should be changed in the queried instance to alter the outcome of an AI system. However, generating these explanations for multivariate time series presents challenges due to their complex, multi-dimensional nature. Traditional Nearest Unlike Neighbor-based methods typically substitute subsequences in a queried time series with influential subsequences from an NUN, which is not always realistic in real-world scenarios due to the rigid direct substitution. Counterfactual with Residual Generative Adversarial Networks-based methods aim to address this by learning from the distribution of observed data to generate synthetic counterfactual explanations. However, these methods primarily focus on minimizing the cost from the queried time series to the counterfactual explanations and often neglect the importance of distancing the counterfactual explanation from the decision boundary. This oversight can result in explanations that no longer qualify as counterfactual if minor changes occur within the model. To generate a more robust counterfactual explanation, we introduce TriShGAN, under the CounteRGAN framework enhanced by the incorporation of triplet loss. This unsupervised learning approach uses distance metric learning to encourage the counterfactual explanations not only to remain close to the queried time series but also to capture the feature distribution of the instance with the desired outcome, thereby achieving a better balance between minimal cost and robustness. Additionally, we integrate a Shapelet Extractor that strategically selects the most discriminative parts of the high-dimensional queried time series to enhance the sparsity of counterfactual explanation and efficiency of the training process.

</details>


### [266] [Breaking the Dyadic Barrier: Rethinking Fairness in Link Prediction Beyond Demographic Parity](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06568)
*João Mattos,Debolina Halder Lina,Arlei Silva*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Critiques dyadic fairness in link prediction for hiding subgroup disparities and flawed ranking fairness; offers a more expressive evaluation framework and a lightweight post-processing method with decoupled predictors that improves fairness-utility trade-offs.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Fairness in link prediction is crucial because biased predictions can reinforce social inequalities; dyadic demographic parity is insufficient for ranking tasks and can obscure subgroup disparities.

Method: Formally analyzes limitations of current fairness evaluations, proposes an expressive framework for fairness assessment in ranking-based link prediction, and introduces a lightweight post-processing approach combined with decoupled link predictors to mitigate bias.

Result: The proposed framework enables more accurate fairness assessment; the post-processing method with decoupled predictors achieves state-of-the-art fairness-utility trade-offs by effectively reducing bias while maintaining performance.

Conclusion: Dyadic demographic parity is inadequate for ranking-based link prediction. A more expressive evaluation framework and a simple post-processing method can better detect and mitigate biases, achieving strong fairness-utility performance.

Abstract: Link prediction is a fundamental task in graph machine learning with applications, ranging from social recommendation to knowledge graph completion. Fairness in this setting is critical, as biased predictions can exacerbate societal inequalities. Prior work adopts a dyadic definition of fairness, enforcing fairness through demographic parity between intra-group and inter-group link predictions. However, we show that this dyadic framing can obscure underlying disparities across subgroups, allowing systemic biases to go undetected. Moreover, we argue that demographic parity does not meet desired properties for fairness assessment in ranking-based tasks such as link prediction. We formalize the limitations of existing fairness evaluations and propose a framework that enables a more expressive assessment. Additionally, we propose a lightweight post-processing method combined with decoupled link predictors that effectively mitigates bias and achieves state-of-the-art fairness-utility trade-offs.

</details>


### [267] [Beyond Fixed Depth: Adaptive Graph Neural Networks for Node Classification Under Varying Homophily](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06608)
*Asela Hevapathige,Asiri Wijesinghe,Ahad N. Zehmakan*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Adaptive-depth GNN that assigns per-node aggregation depth using a theoretical framework, improving performance across homophilic and heterophilic graphs.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Traditional fixed-depth GNNs degrade on heterophilic graphs and models often specialize to a single regime; there is a need for a unified, flexible approach that accounts for local structure and label distribution.

Method: Develop a theoretical framework linking local structural and label features to information propagation at the node level; design a node-specific adaptive-depth GNN that selects aggregation depth per node using theory-grounded metrics; unifies performance across both homophily and heterophily.

Result: Empirical results show consistent improvements over standard GNN backbones across diverse benchmarks, indicating benefits of per-node adaptive depth and regime-agnostic design.

Conclusion: An adaptive-depth, unified GNN can handle both homophilic and heterophilic graphs by tailoring propagation depth to local signals, offering a robust, generalizable advancement in GNN design.

Abstract: Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) have achieved significant success in addressing node classification tasks. However, the effectiveness of traditional GNNs degrades on heterophilic graphs, where connected nodes often belong to different labels or properties. While recent work has introduced mechanisms to improve GNN performance under heterophily, certain key limitations still exist. Most existing models apply a fixed aggregation depth across all nodes, overlooking the fact that nodes may require different propagation depths based on their local homophily levels and neighborhood structures. Moreover, many methods are tailored to either homophilic or heterophilic settings, lacking the flexibility to generalize across both regimes. To address these challenges, we develop a theoretical framework that links local structural and label characteristics to information propagation dynamics at the node level. Our analysis shows that optimal aggregation depth varies across nodes and is critical for preserving class-discriminative information. Guided by this insight, we propose a novel adaptive-depth GNN architecture that dynamically selects node-specific aggregation depths using theoretically grounded metrics. Our method seamlessly adapts to both homophilic and heterophilic patterns within a unified model. Extensive experiments demonstrate that our approach consistently enhances the performance of standard GNN backbones across diverse benchmarks.

</details>


### [268] [CaberNet: Causal Representation Learning for Cross-Domain HVAC Energy Prediction](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06634)
*Kaiyuan Zhai,Jiacheng Cui,Zhehao Zhang,Junyu Xue,Yang Deng,Kui Wu,Guoming Tang*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: CaberNet is a data-driven, causal, interpretable deep sequence model for cross-domain HVAC energy prediction that learns invariant representations to improve generalization across climatically diverse buildings; uses a global feature gate with self-supervised Bernoulli regularization and a domain-wise training scheme; achieves 22.9% NMSE improvement and code is released.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To enable scalable cross-domain HVAC energy prediction given scarce labeled data and heterogeneous data across buildings and climates.

Method: CaberNet learns invariant (Markov blanket) representations; global feature gate trained with self-supervised Bernoulli regularization to select causal features; domain-wise training balances domain contributions, reduces cross-domain loss variance, and enforces latent factor independence; fully data-driven without prior knowledge.

Result: Evaluated on three buildings across three climatically diverse cities; outperforms baselines; NMSE reduced by 22.9% relative to best benchmark.

Conclusion: CaberNet provides robust cross-domain HVAC prediction through causal invariant representations, enabling scalable, label-efficient generalization; code available at GitHub.

Abstract: Cross-domain HVAC energy prediction is essential for scalable building energy management, particularly because collecting extensive labeled data for every new building is both costly and impractical. Yet, this task remains highly challenging due to the scarcity and heterogeneity of data across different buildings, climate zones, and seasonal patterns. In particular, buildings situated in distinct climatic regions introduce variability that often leads existing methods to overfit to spurious correlations, rely heavily on expert intervention, or compromise on data diversity. To address these limitations, we propose CaberNet, a causal and interpretable deep sequence model that learns invariant (Markov blanket) representations for robust cross-domain prediction. In a purely data-driven fashion and without requiring any prior knowledge, CaberNet integrates i) a global feature gate trained with a self-supervised Bernoulli regularization to distinguish superior causal features from inferior ones, and ii) a domain-wise training scheme that balances domain contributions, minimizes cross-domain loss variance, and promotes latent factor independence. We evaluate CaberNet on real-world datasets collected from three buildings located in three climatically diverse cities, and it consistently outperforms all baselines, achieving a 22.9\% reduction in normalized mean squared error (NMSE) compared to the best benchmark. Our code is available at https://github.com/rickzky1001/CaberNet-CRL.

</details>


### [269] [ML-EcoLyzer: Quantifying the Environmental Cost of Machine Learning Inference Across Frameworks and Hardware](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06694)
*Jose Marie Antonio Minoza,Rex Gregor Laylo,Christian F Villarin,Sebastian C. Ibanez*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: ML-EcoLyzer is a cross-framework tool that measures the carbon, energy, thermal, and water costs of ML inference, introducing the Environmental Sustainability Score (ESS) and evaluating thousands of configurations.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Quantifying the environmental impact of ML inference at scale, especially on low-resource hardware; a standardized, hardware-aware measurement across models and modalities is needed to guide sustainable model selection.

Method: Develop ML-EcoLyzer to monitor and quantify costs across CPUs, consumer GPUs, and datacenter accelerators for both classical and modern models; uses adaptive monitoring and hardware-aware evaluation; defines ESS as effective parameters served per gram CO2; evaluates 1,900 inference configurations across architectures, modalities, hardware, and precision.

Result: Findings show that quantization improves ESS; large accelerators can be inefficient for lightweight tasks; even small models may incur substantial costs if implemented suboptimally; the approach provides rigorous empirical evaluation.

Conclusion: ML-EcoLyzer sets a standard for sustainability-aware model selection and offers extensive empirical data on inference-time environmental costs.

Abstract: Machine learning inference occurs at a massive scale, yet its environmental impact remains poorly quantified, especially on low-resource hardware. We present ML-EcoLyzer, a cross-framework tool for measuring the carbon, energy, thermal, and water costs of inference across CPUs, consumer GPUs, and datacenter accelerators. The tool supports both classical and modern models, applying adaptive monitoring and hardware-aware evaluation.
  We introduce the Environmental Sustainability Score (ESS), which quantifies the number of effective parameters served per gram of CO$_2$ emitted. Our evaluation covers over 1,900 inference configurations, spanning diverse model architectures, task modalities (text, vision, audio, tabular), hardware types, and precision levels. These rigorous and reliable measurements demonstrate that quantization enhances ESS, huge accelerators can be inefficient for lightweight applications, and even small models may incur significant costs when implemented suboptimally. ML-EcoLyzer sets a standard for sustainability-conscious model selection and offers an extensive empirical evaluation of environmental costs during inference.

</details>


### [270] [Magnitude-Modulated Equivariant Adapter for Parameter-Efficient Fine-Tuning of Equivariant Graph Neural Networks](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06696)
*Dian Jin,Yancheng Yuan,Xiaoming Tao*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: MMEA introduces magnitude-modulated, equivariant adapters that tune feature magnitudes per tensor order and per multiplicity, achieving state-of-the-art energy/force predictions with fewer trainable parameters while preserving equivariance.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Equivariant graph neural networks (EGNNs) based on spherical harmonics are powerful for chemistry, but adapting pretrained models to new tasks or environments requires fine-tuning. Conventional PEFT methods (e.g., Adapters, LoRA) often break symmetry, making them incompatible with equivariant architectures; while existing equivariant PEFT like ELoRA improves efficiency, it retains many degrees of freedom that can perturb feature distributions and hurt performance.

Method: Introduce Magnitude-Modulated Equivariant Adapter (MMEA): a lightweight, scalar gating mechanism applied per tensor order and per multiplicity to modulate feature magnitudes while preserving strict equivariance. This per-order/per-multiplicity modulation reduces trainable parameters and maintains symmetry.

Result: Across multiple benchmarks, MMEA consistently improves energy and force predictions to state-of-the-art levels and does so with fewer trainable parameters than competing approaches.

Conclusion: Magnitude modulation suffices to adapt equivariant models to new chemical environments without breaking symmetry, signaling a new paradigm for equivariant PEFT design and offering practical gains in parameter efficiency and predictive accuracy.

Abstract: Pretrained equivariant graph neural networks based on spherical harmonics offer efficient and accurate alternatives to computationally expensive ab-initio methods, yet adapting them to new tasks and chemical environments still requires fine-tuning. Conventional parameter-efficient fine-tuning (PEFT) techniques, such as Adapters and LoRA, typically break symmetry, making them incompatible with those equivariant architectures. ELoRA, recently proposed, is the first equivariant PEFT method. It achieves improved parameter efficiency and performance on many benchmarks. However, the relatively high degrees of freedom it retains within each tensor order can still perturb pretrained feature distributions and ultimately degrade performance. To address this, we present Magnitude-Modulated Equivariant Adapter (MMEA), a novel equivariant fine-tuning method which employs lightweight scalar gating to modulate feature magnitudes on a per-order and per-multiplicity basis. We demonstrate that MMEA preserves strict equivariance and, across multiple benchmarks, consistently improves energy and force predictions to state-of-the-art levels while training fewer parameters than competing approaches. These results suggest that, in many practical scenarios, modulating channel magnitudes is sufficient to adapt equivariant models to new chemical environments without breaking symmetry, pointing toward a new paradigm for equivariant PEFT design.

</details>


### [271] [Sensor Calibration Model Balancing Accuracy, Real-time, and Efficiency](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06715)
*Jinyong Yun,Hyungjin Kim,Seokho Ahn,Euijong Lee,Young-Duk Seo*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Scare is an ultra-compressed transformer for on-device sensor calibration that achieves eight microscopic requirements by using Sequence Lens Projector, Efficient Bitwise Attention, and a hash optimization strategy, outperforming baselines on air-quality datasets and MCU deployments.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Current evaluation typically uses only three macro metrics (accuracy, real-time, and resource efficiency), which obscures bottlenecks like instantaneous error and worst-case latency. The work argues for eight microscopic requirements to ensure robust, real-time deployment on constrained devices.

Method: Three core components: (1) Sequence Lens Projector (SLP) logarithmically compresses time-series data while preserving boundary information across bins; (2) Efficient Bitwise Attention (EBA) replaces computationally heavy multiplications with bitwise operations via binary hash codes; (3) Hash optimization strategy enables stable training without auxiliary loss terms. The model is designed to be ultra-compressed and MCU-compatible.

Result: Empirically, Scare outperforms existing linear, hybrid, and deep-learning baselines on large-scale air-quality datasets and real microcontroller deployments, and is claimed to be the first model to meet all eight microscopic requirements.

Conclusion: Scare provides a practical, MCU-friendly transformer that balances accuracy, real-time performance, and efficiency across eight microscopic metrics, with potential generalizability to other on-device calibration tasks.

Abstract: Most on-device sensor calibration studies benchmark models only against three macroscopic requirements (i.e., accuracy, real-time, and resource efficiency), thereby hiding deployment bottlenecks such as instantaneous error and worst-case latency. We therefore decompose this triad into eight microscopic requirements and introduce Scare (Sensor Calibration model balancing Accuracy, Real-time, and Efficiency), an ultra-compressed transformer that fulfills them all. SCARE comprises three core components: (1) Sequence Lens Projector (SLP) that logarithmically compresses time-series data while preserving boundary information across bins, (2) Efficient Bitwise Attention (EBA) module that replaces costly multiplications with bitwise operations via binary hash codes, and (3) Hash optimization strategy that ensures stable training without auxiliary loss terms. Together, these components minimize computational overhead while maintaining high accuracy and compatibility with microcontroller units (MCUs). Extensive experiments on large-scale air-quality datasets and real microcontroller deployments demonstrate that Scare outperforms existing linear, hybrid, and deep-learning baselines, making Scare, to the best of our knowledge, the first model to meet all eight microscopic requirements simultaneously.

</details>


### [272] [Rank-1 LoRAs Encode Interpretable Reasoning Signals](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06739)
*Jake Ward,Paul Riechers,Adam Shai*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Rank-1 LoRA adapters can reproduce most reasoning-benchmark gains with minimal parameter changes; activations are interpretable; a sparse autoencoder reveals meaningful features; supports using parameter-efficient training to study LLM reasoning.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To understand what drives improvements in reasoning models and whether small, interpretable parameter changes suffice, offering a lens into LLM reasoning dynamics.

Method: Apply a rank-1 LoRA to Qwen-2.5-32B-Instruct; compare its performance to full fine-tuning on reasoning benchmarks; analyze LoRA activations for interpretability; train a sparse autoencoder on the LoRA activations to extract fine-grained and monosemantic features.

Result: The rank-1 LoRA recovers 73-90% of the full fine-tune performance on reasoning benchmarks; LoRA activations are as interpretable as MLP neurons and fire for reasoning-specific behaviors; the sparse autoencoder identifies fine-grained and monosemantic features.

Conclusion: Reasoning performance can largely arise from minimal parameter changes, and parameter-efficient training methods can serve as a targeted tool to uncover fundamental insights about language model behavior and dynamics.

Abstract: Reasoning models leverage inference-time compute to significantly enhance the performance of language models on difficult logical tasks, and have become a dominating paradigm in frontier LLMs. Despite their wide adoption, the mechanisms underpinning the enhanced performance of these reasoning models are not well understood. In this work, we show that the majority of new capabilities in reasoning models can be elicited by small, single-rank changes to base model parameters, with many of these changes being interpretable. Specifically, we use a rank-1 LoRA to create a minimal parameter adapter for Qwen-2.5-32B-Instruct which recovers 73-90% of reasoning-benchmark performance compared to a full parameter finetune. We find that the activations of this LoRA are as interpretable as MLP neurons, and fire for reasoning-specific behaviors. Finally, we train a sparse autoencoder on the entire activation state of this LoRA and identify fine-grained and monosemantic features. Our findings highlight that reasoning performance can arise largely from minimal changes to base model parameters, and explore what these changes affect. More broadly, our work shows that parameter-efficient training methods can be used as a targeted lens for uncovering fundamental insights about language model behavior and dynamics.

</details>


### [273] [Implicit Federated In-context Learning For Task-Specific LLM Fine-Tuning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06757)
*Dongcheng Li,Junhan Chen,Aoxiang Zhou,Chunpei Li,Youquan Xian,Peng Liu,Xianxian Li*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: IFed-ICL is a novel implicit federated in-context learning framework that enables distributed inference via implicit representations of local context, reducing parameter updates and client computation while using model residual streams to boost performance.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: The growth of large language models relies on vast data, including private organizational data, but public data can deplete. Federated learning helps leverage private data with fewer trainable parameters; however processing high-dimensional features incurs substantial compute and communication cost. A more efficient, privacy-preserving, task-specific adaptation is needed.

Method: Convert client local context examples into implicit vector representations to enable distributed collaborative computation during inference. Inject model residual streams to enhance performance. Operates within a federated learning-inspired setup to minimize parameter updates and data transmission at the client, focusing on text classification tasks.

Result: IFed-ICL achieves outstanding performance on multiple text classification tasks, outperforming traditional fine-tuning by avoiding extensive parameter updates and reducing data transmission and local computation at the client. It enables efficient distributed context learning using local private-domain data, significantly boosting task-specific model performance.

Conclusion: IFed-ICL provides a practical, privacy-preserving approach for leveraging private-domain data in distributed, task-specific contexts. By using implicit representations and residual streams, it reduces communication and computation while maintaining or improving performance, suggesting broader applicability to other NLP tasks and potential directions for future work in privacy, scalability, and robustness.

Abstract: As large language models continue to develop and expand, the extensive public data they rely on faces the risk of depletion. Consequently, leveraging private data within organizations to enhance the performance of large models has emerged as a key challenge. The federated learning paradigm, combined with model fine-tuning techniques, effectively reduces the number of trainable parameters. However,the necessity to process high-dimensional feature spaces results in substantial overall computational overhead. To address this issue, we propose the Implicit Federated In-Context Learning (IFed-ICL) framework. IFed-ICL draws inspiration from federated learning to establish a novel distributed collaborative paradigm, by converting client local context examples into implicit vector representations, it enables distributed collaborative computation during the inference phase and injects model residual streams to enhance model performance. Experiments demonstrate that our proposed method achieves outstanding performance across multiple text classification tasks. Compared to traditional methods, IFed-ICL avoids the extensive parameter updates required by conventional fine-tuning methods while reducing data transmission and local computation at the client level in federated learning. This enables efficient distributed context learning using local private-domain data, significantly improving model performance on specific tasks.

</details>


### [274] [QUARK: Quantization-Enabled Circuit Sharing for Transformer Acceleration by Exploiting Common Patterns in Nonlinear Operations](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06767)
*Zhixiong Zhao,Haomin Li,Fangxin Liu,Yuncheng Lu,Zongwu Wang,Tao Yang,Li Jiang,Haibing Guan*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: QUARK creates an FPGA-based, quantization-enabled accelerator that shares circuits for Transformer nonlinearities, delivering up to 1.96x end-to-end speedup over GPUs and >50% hardware overhead reduction, while preserving— and even boosting— accuracy at ultra-low-bit quantization.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Nonlinear operators in Transformer models are major contributors to inference latency and hardware resource usage. Efficiently accelerating all nonlinearities with shared hardware and quantization could yield substantial speedups and resource savings.

Method: Propose QUARK, a quantization-enabled FPGA framework that exploits common patterns in nonlinear operations to enable circuit sharing. It targets all nonlinear operators in Transformer-based models, delivering high-fidelity approximations and reusing hardware modules to reduce resource usage, aided by quantization-aware optimization.

Result: Experimental evaluation shows up to 1.96x end-to-end speedup over GPU implementations; nonlinear hardware overhead reduced by over 50% versus prior approaches; accuracy preserved and even boosted under ultra-low-bit quantization.

Conclusion: Demonstrates that circuit-sharing combined with quantization can efficiently accelerate Transformer nonlinearities on FPGA, yielding notable speedups and hardware savings without sacrificing accuracy, enabling practical deployment in CV/NLP workloads.

Abstract: Transformer-based models have revolutionized computer vision (CV) and natural language processing (NLP) by achieving state-of-the-art performance across a range of benchmarks. However, nonlinear operations in models significantly contribute to inference latency, presenting unique challenges for efficient hardware acceleration. To this end, we propose QUARK, a quantization-enabled FPGA acceleration framework that leverages common patterns in nonlinear operations to enable efficient circuit sharing, thereby reducing hardware resource requirements. QUARK targets all nonlinear operations within Transformer-based models, achieving high-performance approximation through a novel circuit-sharing design tailored to accelerate these operations. Our evaluation demonstrates that QUARK significantly reduces the computational overhead of nonlinear operators in mainstream Transformer architectures, achieving up to a 1.96 times end-to-end speedup over GPU implementations. Moreover, QUARK lowers the hardware overhead of nonlinear modules by more than 50% compared to prior approaches, all while maintaining high model accuracy -- and even substantially boosting accuracy under ultra-low-bit quantization.

</details>


### [275] [Data Trajectory Alignment for LLM Domain Adaptation: A Two-Phase Synthesis Framework for Telecommunications Mathematics](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06776)
*Zhicheng Zhou,Jing Li,Suming Qiu,Junjie Huang,Linyuan Qiu,Zhijie Sun*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Data Trajectory Alignment (DTA) is a two-phase, model-agnostic data curation framework that treats solution processes as supervision to adapt LLMs to low-resource verticals. Phase I generates diverse teachers’ outputs; Phase II rewrites and selects solution trajectories to align with the target student and perform signal-aware exemplar selection.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Vertical deployment of LLMs (e.g., telecommunications) is limited by scarce, low-information-density data and edge constraints; improving supervision of solution processes can enable better domain adaptation without heavy computational modes.

Method: Phase I: initialize by synthesizing diverse, high-coverage candidates using an ensemble of strong teachers. Phase II: rewrite teacher solutions to align intermediate steps and style with student inductive biases; perform signal-aware exemplar selection via agreement checks and reflection-based judging.

Result: On TELEMATH for telecommunications mathematics (link budgets, SNR/AMC, power-control feasibility), DTA achieves state-of-the-art accuracy: 72.45% pass@1, +17.65 points vs distilled-only training, +2.94 points vs strong baseline with thinking enabled. Token-shift analyses show gains in logical-structural discourse markers. Under edge-like inference, DTA cuts energy per output token by ~42% and end-to-end latency by ~60% compared to baselines.

Conclusion: Aligning not just answers but the generation process yields compact, high-yield supervision that improves accuracy and efficiency for domain adaptation in low-resource verticals beyond telecom.

Abstract: General-purpose large language models (LLMs) are increasingly deployed in verticals such as telecommunications, where adaptation is hindered by scarce, low-information-density corpora and tight mobile/edge constraints. We propose Data Trajectory Alignment (DTA), a two-phase, model-agnostic data curation framework that treats solution processes - not only final answers - as first-class supervision. Phase I (Initializing) synthesizes diverse, high-coverage candidates using an ensemble of strong teachers. Phase II (DTA) rewrites teacher solutions to align intermediate steps and presentation style with the target student's inductive biases and then performs signal-aware exemplar selection via agreement checks and reflection-based judging. Instantiated on telecommunications mathematics (e.g., link budgets, SNR/AMC selection, and power-control feasibility), DTA yields state-of-the-art (SOTA) accuracy on TELEMATH without enabling explicit "thinking" modes: 72.45% pass@1, surpassing distilled-only training by +17.65 points and outperforming a strong baseline (Qwen3-32B with thinking enabled) by +2.94 points. Token-shift analyses indicate that DTA concentrates gains on logical-structural discourse markers rather than merely amplifying domain nouns, indicating improved reasoning scaffolding. Under edge-like inference settings, DTA improves efficiency by reducing reliance on multi-sample voting and disabling expensive reasoning heuristics, cutting energy per output token by ~42% versus Qwen3-32B (thinking mode enabled) and end-to-end latency by ~60% versus Qwen3-32B (thinking mode disabled). These results demonstrate that aligning how solutions are produced enables compact, high-yield supervision that is effective for both accuracy and efficiency, offering a practical recipe for domain adaptation in low-resource verticals beyond telecom.

</details>


### [276] [On the Mechanisms of Collaborative Learning in VAE Recommenders](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06781)
*Tung-Long Vuong,Julien Monteil,Hien Dang,Volodymyr Vaskovych,Trung Le,Vu Nguyen*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: The paper provides a theoretical and empirical framework for VAE-based collaborative filtering, showing that user collaboration is governed by latent proximity and latent Wasserstein distance; it analyzes local vs. global collaboration, compares two global-mixing approaches (β-KL regularization and input masking) with their trade-offs, and introduces an anchor regularizer to stabilize identities during masking and enable cross-user/item sharing; validated on Netflix, MovieLens-20M, Million Song, and deployed online on Amazon.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To understand how collaboration arises in VAE-based CF under masking, quantify when updates transfer across users, and enable stable, global information sharing without collapsing representations; and to provide practical, deployable mechanisms that improve recommendation quality.

Method: Derive a latent sharing radius and show how SGD updates transfer losses as a function of latent Wasserstein distance; analyze the geometry of VAE-based CF with clean inputs to compare local vs global collaboration; evaluate two global-mixing mechanisms—β-KL regularization and input masking—and introduce an anchor regularizer aligning user posteriors with item embeddings; conduct experiments on Netflix, MovieLens-20M, Million Song, and an online Amazon deployment.

Result: Finds that, with clean inputs, collaboration is mainly local (input-similar users). β-KL tightens the information bottleneck, increasing posterior overlap but risks representational collapse if too strong; input masking induces stochastic contractions/expansions that can bring distant users into the same latent neighborhood but may cause neighborhood drift. The anchor regularizer stabilizes users under masking and facilitates cross-item sharing. Empirical results on the three datasets show improved performance, and the online Amazon deployment confirms practical effectiveness.

Conclusion: The work provides a principled view of how latent proximity governs collaboration in VAE-based CF, clarifies trade-offs between local and global mixing mechanisms, and offers a concrete regularizer to preserve user identity while enabling global consistency. It demonstrates practical gains on standard benchmarks and in a real-world deployment.

Abstract: Variational Autoencoders (VAEs) are a powerful alternative to matrix factorization for recommendation. A common technique in VAE-based collaborative filtering (CF) consists in applying binary input masking to user interaction vectors, which improves performance but remains underexplored theoretically. In this work, we analyze how collaboration arises in VAE-based CF and show it is governed by latent proximity: we derive a latent sharing radius that informs when an SGD update on one user strictly reduces the loss on another user, with influence decaying as the latent Wasserstein distance increases. We further study the induced geometry: with clean inputs, VAE-based CF primarily exploits \emph{local} collaboration between input-similar users and under-utilizes global collaboration between far-but-related users. We compare two mechanisms that encourage \emph{global} mixing and characterize their trade-offs: (1) $β$-KL regularization directly tightens the information bottleneck, promoting posterior overlap but risking representational collapse if too large; (2) input masking induces stochastic geometric contractions and expansions, which can bring distant users onto the same latent neighborhood but also introduce neighborhood drift. To preserve user identity while enabling global consistency, we propose an anchor regularizer that aligns user posteriors with item embeddings, stabilizing users under masking and facilitating signal sharing across related items. Our analyses are validated on the Netflix, MovieLens-20M, and Million Song datasets. We also successfully deployed our proposed algorithm on an Amazon streaming platform following a successful online experiment.

</details>


### [277] [Resource Efficient Sleep Staging via Multi-Level Masking and Prompt Learning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06785)
*Lejun Ai,Yulong Li,Haodong Yi,Jixuan Xie,Yue Wang,Jia Liu,Min Chen,Rui Wang*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: MASS enables resource-efficient sleep staging by masking partial EEG observations and using hierarchical prompt learning to maintain performance, achieving state-of-the-art results on four datasets, especially with limited data.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To reduce data collection requirements for sleep staging in resource-constrained settings (wearables, home monitoring) without sacrificing accuracy.

Method: A multi-level masking strategy to handle partial/irregular data and a hierarchical prompt learning mechanism that forms a global prompt from unmasked data to guide patch- and epoch-level feature modeling within the Mask-Aware Sleep Staging (MASS) framework.

Result: Achieves state-of-the-art sleep staging performance on four datasets, with notable robustness when data is very limited.

Conclusion: MASS offers a practical, scalable solution for low-resource sleep monitoring by combining masking with prompt-based guidance to retain contextual information under partial observations.

Abstract: Automatic sleep staging plays a vital role in assessing sleep quality and diagnosing sleep disorders. Most existing methods rely heavily on long and continuous EEG recordings, which poses significant challenges for data acquisition in resource-constrained systems, such as wearable or home-based monitoring systems. In this paper, we propose the task of resource-efficient sleep staging, which aims to reduce the amount of signal collected per sleep epoch while maintaining reliable classification performance. To solve this task, we adopt the masking and prompt learning strategy and propose a novel framework called Mask-Aware Sleep Staging (MASS). Specifically, we design a multi-level masking strategy to promote effective feature modeling under partial and irregular observations. To mitigate the loss of contextual information introduced by masking, we further propose a hierarchical prompt learning mechanism that aggregates unmasked data into a global prompt, serving as a semantic anchor for guiding both patch-level and epoch-level feature modeling. MASS is evaluated on four datasets, demonstrating state-of-the-art performance, especially when the amount of data is very limited. This result highlights its potential for efficient and scalable deployment in real-world low-resource sleep monitoring environments.

</details>


### [278] [Robust Causal Discovery under Imperfect Structural Constraints](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06790)
*Zidong Wang,Xi Lin,Chuchao He,Xiaoguang Gao*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A robust causal discovery framework that aligns imperfect priors with data through a credibility-guided penalty and a multi-task learning setup to resolve conflicts, effective for both linear and nonlinear SEMs.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Imperfect or unknown priors degrade performance; existing methods often assume perfect priors or handle only specific error types, and rely on brittle thresholding that conflicts with data distribution.

Method: 1) Use a surrogate model to assess the credibility of structural constraints; 2) introduce a sparse penalization term that measures the loss between the learned adjacency and the constrained adjacency; 3) prove that the knowledge-driven objective aligns with the data-driven objective under ideal conditions; 4) when violations occur, adopt a multi-task learning framework optimized via multi-gradient descent to jointly minimize both objectives; 5) applicable to both linear and nonlinear settings.

Result: The approach demonstrates robustness and efficiency across diverse noise conditions and SEM types, with extensive experiments showing effectiveness under imperfect structural constraints.

Conclusion: The paper presents a principled knowledge-data harmonization strategy: assess constraint credibility, enforce a compatibility penalty, prove alignment under ideal conditions, and resolve conflicts via multi-task learning, yielding robust causal discovery for linear and nonlinear SEMs.

Abstract: Robust causal discovery from observational data under imperfect prior knowledge remains a significant and largely unresolved challenge. Existing methods typically presuppose perfect priors or can only handle specific, pre-identified error types. And their performance degrades substantially when confronted with flawed constraints of unknown location and type. This decline arises because most of them rely on inflexible and biased thresholding strategies that may conflict with the data distribution. To overcome these limitations, we propose to harmonizes knowledge and data through prior alignment and conflict resolution. First, we assess the credibility of imperfect structural constraints through a surrogate model, which then guides a sparse penalization term measuring the loss between the learned and constrained adjacency matrices. We theoretically prove that, under ideal assumption, the knowledge-driven objective aligns with the data-driven objective. Furthermore, to resolve conflicts when this assumption is violated, we introduce a multi-task learning framework optimized via multi-gradient descent, jointly minimizing both objectives. Our proposed method is robust to both linear and nonlinear settings. Extensive experiments, conducted under diverse noise conditions and structural equation model types, demonstrate the effectiveness and efficiency of our method under imperfect structural constraints.

</details>


### [279] [Cross-Modal Unlearning via Influential Neuron Path Editing in Multimodal Large Language Models](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06793)
*Kunhao Li,Wenhao Li,Di Wu,Lei Yang,Jun Bai,Ju Jia,Jason Xue*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Proposes MIP-Editor, a multimodal influential neuron path editor for targeted forgetting in multimodal large language models (MLLMs) that uses modality-specific attributions to edit influential neuron paths, enabling coordinated, cross-modal unlearning while preserving general knowledge; shows strong forgetting with good retention and provides code.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: MLLMs raise privacy, toxicity, and IP concerns due to broad knowledge; existing neuron-editing MU methods struggle with cross-modal consistency and degrade generalization when sensitive neurons are pruned. A multimodal, pathway-aware approach is needed to forget targeted knowledge without harming overall capability.

Method: Introduce Multimodal Influential Neuron Path Editor (MIP-Editor). Compute modality-specific attribution scores to identify influential neuron paths encoding forget-set knowledge, then perform influential-path-aware neuron editing via representation misdirection. The method coordinates forgetting across text and vision components while preserving general reasoning paths.

Result: Empirical results show strong unlearning: up to 87.75% forgetting rate and up to 54.26% improvement in general knowledge retention. For textual tasks: up to 80.65% forgetting with 77.9% retention of general performance. Code available at the provided GitHub link.

Conclusion: MIP-Editor offers superior multimodal unlearning by targeting influential neuron paths with modality-aware attributions, enabling coordinated forgetting across modalities with minimal degradation to general capabilities.

Abstract: Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs) extend foundation models to real-world applications by integrating inputs such as text and vision. However, their broad knowledge capacity raises growing concerns about privacy leakage, toxicity mitigation, and intellectual property violations. Machine Unlearning (MU) offers a practical solution by selectively forgetting targeted knowledge while preserving overall model utility. When applied to MLLMs, existing neuron-editing-based MU approaches face two fundamental challenges: (1) forgetting becomes inconsistent across modalities because existing point-wise attribution methods fail to capture the structured, layer-by-layer information flow that connects different modalities; and (2) general knowledge performance declines when sensitive neurons that also support important reasoning paths are pruned, as this disrupts the model's ability to generalize. To alleviate these limitations, we propose a multimodal influential neuron path editor (MIP-Editor) for MU. Our approach introduces modality-specific attribution scores to identify influential neuron paths responsible for encoding forget-set knowledge and applies influential-path-aware neuron-editing via representation misdirection. This strategy also enables effective and coordinated forgetting across modalities while preserving the model's general capabilities. Experimental results demonstrate that MIP-Editor achieves a superior unlearning performance on multimodal tasks, with a maximum forgetting rate of 87.75% and up to 54.26% improvement in general knowledge retention. On textual tasks, MIP-Editor achieves up to 80.65% forgetting and preserves 77.9% of general performance. Codes are available at https://github.com/PreckLi/MIP-Editor.

</details>


### [280] [Recursive Dynamics in Fast-Weights Homeostatic Reentry Networks: Toward Reflective Intelligence](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06798)
*B. G. Chae*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: FH-RL is a fast-weight, homeostatic, reentrant neuron mechanism enabling internal recurrence in transformer-like nets. By sweeping reentry gain γ, the study introduces metrics IRR, ESRI, and RDP, and finds a stable reflective band around γ≈0.10–0.20 where internal feedback is highly expressive yet spectrally stable, suggesting thought-like recursive processing emerges from a balance of amplification and regulation.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Bridge fast-weight associative memory with recursive cognition theories by enabling internal recurrence in primarily feedforward networks. Quantify emergent internal dynamics and relate them to cortical reentry concepts.

Method: Propose FH-RL architecture combining fast weights, homeostatic regularization, and learned reentrant feedback. Conduct controlled experiments sweeping reentry gain γ. Define three metrics: Information Reentry Ratio (IRR), Eigen-Spectrum Recursion Index (ESRI), Representational Drift Periodicity (RDP). Analyze reentry quantity, learned feedback matrix Wr, and spectral/dynamic properties across γ.

Result: Reentry quantity grows with γ; the learned feedback matrix Wr remains bounded and becomes more structured at moderate gains. A stable reflective band emerges near γ≈0.10–0.20 where internal feedback is maximally expressive yet spectrally stable: IRR rises smoothly, ESRI stays near zero, and RDP shows low-frequency cycles. This indicates reflective, thought-like internal processing arises from balancing feedback amplification with homeostatic regulation.

Conclusion: The work links fast-weight architectures to theories of cortical reentry and recursive cognition by showing that a principled balance between amplification and homeostatic control yields expressive, stable internal processing within transformer-like models.

Abstract: This study introduces the Fast-Weights Homeostatic Reentry Layer (FH-RL), a neural mechanism that integrates fast-weight associative memory, homeostatic regularization, and learned reentrant feedback to approximate self-referential computation in neural networks. Unlike standard transformer architectures that operate in a purely feedforward manner during inference, FH-RL enables internal recurrence without external looping, allowing prior latent states to be dynamically re-entered into the ongoing computation stream. We conduct controlled experiments sweeping the reentry gain $γ$ and evaluate emergent internal dynamics using three novel metrics: the Information Reentry Ratio (IRR), Eigen-Spectrum Recursion Index (ESRI), and Representational Drift Periodicity (RDP). Results show that reentry quantity increases proportionally with~$γ$, while the learned feedback matrix $W_r$ remains bounded and becomes more structured at moderate gains. Critically, a stable reflective band emerges around $γ\approx 0.10-0.20$, where internal feedback is maximally expressive yet spectrally stable: IRR rises smoothly, ESRI remains near zero, and RDP exhibits consistent low-frequency cycles. These findings provide quantitative evidence that reflective, thought-like internal processing can arise from a principled balance between feedback amplification and homeostatic regulation, linking modern fast-weight architectures to theories of cortical reentry and recursive cognition.

</details>


### [281] [Controllable Flow Matching for Online Reinforcement Learning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06816)
*Bin Wang,Boxiang Tao,Haifeng Jing,Hongbo Dou,Zijian Wang*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: CtrlFlow is a trajectory-level synthetic data approach for model-based RL that uses conditional flow matching to generate trajectories from initial states to high-return terminals without modeling environment dynamics, and optimizes sampling via control energy tied to the non-linear Controllability Gramian, leading to robust and generalizable policies with improved sample efficiency on MuJoCo benchmarks.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Addresses instability and error accumulation in long-horizon model-based rollouts by avoiding explicit dynamics modeling and instead directly modeling trajectory distributions. Aims to produce diverse, high-quality trajectory data to enhance policy learning and cross-task generalization.

Method: Proposes CtrlFlow, which uses conditional flow matching (CFM) to synthesize trajectory distributions from initial states to high-return terminal states without learning the environment transition function. It enforces optimal trajectory sampling by minimizing control energy computed from the non-linear Controllability Gramian Matrix, promoting diverse and efficient trajectories for training.

Result: In online experiments on MuJoCo benchmarks, CtrlFlow achieves better performance than dynamics-model-based approaches and demonstrates superior sample efficiency compared to standard MBRL methods, with improved robustness and cross-task generalization due to the diverse trajectory data.

Conclusion: Trajectory-level synthetic data via CFM and controllability-energy minimization can stabilize and improve policy learning in MBRL, offering a promising direction to mitigate model error accumulation and to enable cross-task generalization.

Abstract: Model-based reinforcement learning (MBRL) typically relies on modeling environment dynamics for data efficiency. However, due to the accumulation of model errors over long-horizon rollouts, such methods often face challenges in maintaining modeling stability. To address this, we propose CtrlFlow, a trajectory-level synthetic method using conditional flow matching (CFM), which directly modeling the distribution of trajectories from initial states to high-return terminal states without explicitly modeling the environment transition function. Our method ensures optimal trajectory sampling by minimizing the control energy governed by the non-linear Controllability Gramian Matrix, while the generated diverse trajectory data significantly enhances the robustness and cross-task generalization of policy learning. In online settings, CtrlFlow demonstrates the better performance on common MuJoCo benchmark tasks than dynamics models and achieves superior sample efficiency compared to standard MBRL methods.

</details>


### [282] [DeepRWCap: Neural-Guided Random-Walk Capacitance Solver for IC Design](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06831)
*Hector R. Rodriguez,Jiechen Huang,Wenjian Yu*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A ML-guided Monte Carlo solver for capacitance extraction (DeepRWCap) predicts transition quantities to guide each walk step, achieving high accuracy and substantial speedups.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Modern densely packed semiconductor geometries create challenges for unbiased sampling in random-walk steps across multiple high-contrast dielectric materials. There is a need to accelerate capacitance extraction while preserving accuracy beyond existing stochastic methods.

Method: A two-stage neural architecture that decomposes outputs into face-wise distributions and spatial kernels on cube faces. It uses 3D CNNs to capture volumetric dielectric interactions and 2D depthwise separable convolutions for localized kernel behavior. Grid-based positional encodings and cube-symmetry-informed design reduce redundancy. Trains on 100,000 procedurally generated dielectric configurations to predict Poisson kernels, gradient kernels, and the signs/magnitudes of weights guiding each walk step.

Result: Mean relative error of 1.24% ± 0.53% on self-capacitance benchmarking against the Raphael solver across 10 industrial designs spanning node scales from 12 to 55 nm. Approximately 23% speedup over Microwalk, with about 49% acceleration on designs where runtimes exceed 10 seconds.

Conclusion: ML-guided random-walk solvers can deliver accurate capacitance extraction with substantial speedups, demonstrating generalization across complex, high-contrast dielectric configurations and potential for integration into design flows; symmetry- and encoding-aware architecture design enhances generalization and reduces learning redundancy.

Abstract: Monte Carlo random walk methods are widely used in capacitance extraction for their mesh-free formulation and inherent parallelism. However, modern semiconductor technologies with densely packed structures present significant challenges in unbiasedly sampling transition domains in walk steps with multiple high-contrast dielectric materials. We present DeepRWCap, a machine learning-guided random walk solver that predicts the transition quantities required to guide each step of the walk. These include Poisson kernels, gradient kernels, signs and magnitudes of weights. DeepRWCap employs a two-stage neural architecture that decomposes structured outputs into face-wise distributions and spatial kernels on cube faces. It uses 3D convolutional networks to capture volumetric dielectric interactions and 2D depthwise separable convolutions to model localized kernel behavior. The design incorporates grid-based positional encodings and structural design choices informed by cube symmetries to reduce learning redundancy and improve generalization. Trained on 100,000 procedurally generated dielectric configurations, DeepRWCap achieves a mean relative error of $1.24\pm0.53$\% when benchmarked against the commercial Raphael solver on the self-capacitance estimation of 10 industrial designs spanning 12 to 55 nm nodes. Compared to the state-of-the-art stochastic difference method Microwalk, DeepRWCap achieves an average 23\% speedup. On complex designs with runtimes over 10 s, it reaches an average 49\% acceleration.

</details>


### [283] [TuckA: Hierarchical Compact Tensor Experts for Efficient Fine-Tuning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06859)
*Qifeng Lei,Zhiyong Yang,Qianqian Xu,Cong Hua,Peisong Wen,Qingming Huang*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: TuckA introduces Tucker-based, multi-expert adaptation for PEFT to better capture diverse task data while remaining parameter-efficient. It creates a compact 3D tensor of experts via Tucker decomposition, organizes experts hierarchically, uses batch-level routing to reduce router parameters, and employs data-aware initialization for balanced load. Empirical results across NLP, vision, and reasoning tasks show strong performance with efficient parameter growth.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Standard PEFT methods rely on a single low-rank adaptation matrix per layer, which struggles to model the diversity of samples in complex tasks. There is a need for multiple, efficiently parameterized experts that can be routed to by data-driven mechanisms without exploding parameter counts.

Method: Apply Tucker decomposition to form a compact 3D tensor where each slice is an expert. Use a hierarchical grouping of experts across granularities to capture local and global patterns. Employ batch-level routing to decide which experts to use, reducing router parameter size by a factor L (number of adapted layers). Initialize experts with data-aware schemes to balance load without loss.

Result: Extensive experiments on natural language understanding, image classification, and mathematical reasoning benchmarks demonstrate the effectiveness of TuckA, showing improved efficiency and competitive or superior performance compared to traditional PEFT approaches across tasks and modalities.

Conclusion: TuckA provides a scalable, data-aware, multi-expert PEFT framework that efficiently captures diverse data patterns via Tucker-based compact expert tensors, hierarchical routing, and balanced initialization, yielding strong cross-domain performance with limited parameter growth.

Abstract: Efficiently fine-tuning pre-trained models for downstream tasks is a key challenge in the era of foundation models. Parameter-efficient fine-tuning (PEFT) presents a promising solution, achieving performance comparable to full fine-tuning by updating only a small number of adaptation weights per layer. Traditional PEFT methods typically rely on a single expert, where the adaptation weight is a low-rank matrix. However, for complex tasks, the data's inherent diversity poses a significant challenge for such models, as a single adaptation weight cannot adequately capture the features of all samples. To address this limitation, we explore how to integrate multiple small adaptation experts into a compact structure to defeat a large adapter. Specifically, we propose Tucker Adaptation (TuckA), a method with four key properties: (i) We use Tucker decomposition to create a compact 3D tensor where each slice naturally serves as an expert. The low-rank nature of this decomposition ensures that the number of parameters scales efficiently as more experts are added. (ii) We introduce a hierarchical strategy that organizes these experts into groups at different granularities, allowing the model to capture both local and global data patterns. (iii) We develop an efficient batch-level routing mechanism, which reduces the router's parameter size by a factor of $L$ compared to routing at every adapted layer (where $L$ is the number of adapted layers) (iv) We propose data-aware initialization to achieve loss-free expert load balancing based on theoretical analysis. Extensive experiments on benchmarks in natural language understanding, image classification, and mathematical reasoning speak to the efficacy of TuckA, offering a new and effective solution to the PEFT problem.

</details>


### [284] [DeepBooTS: Dual-Stream Residual Boosting for Drift-Resilient Time-Series Forecasting](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06893)
*Daojun Liang,Jing Chen,Xiao Wang,Yinglong Wang,Suo Li*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: DeepBooTS: a dual-stream residual-decreasing boosting method for non-stationary time-series forecasting that uses block-wise ensembles with auxiliary highway branches to progressively reconstruct the intrinsic signal. Grounded by a bias-variance analysis showing weighted ensembles reduce variance without increasing bias, it reports large gains (≈15.8% avg) and sets a new benchmark across large-scale datasets.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Time-series data often exhibit pronounced non-stationarity and concept drift, undermining forecast robustness. Existing methods rely on instance normalization and struggle to adapt without increasing bias or variance. The paper aims to quantify drift through a bias-variance lens and design a learning framework that enhances robustness and interpretability.

Method: First, a bias-variance analysis shows that weighted ensembles can reduce variance without increasing bias in the presence of drift. Based on this, the authors propose DeepBooTS, an end-to-end dual-stream residual-decreasing boosting method. Each deep-model block acts as an ensemble of learners with an auxiliary output branch forming a highway to the final prediction. Block outputs correct the residuals of prior blocks, enabling a learning-driven decomposition of inputs and targets to improve drift robustness and interpretability.

Result: Empirical evaluation on large-scale time-series datasets shows the method outperforms existing approaches by a large margin, with an average improvement of 15.8% across datasets, suggesting a new benchmark for TS forecasting.

Conclusion: DeepBooTS enhances versatility, interpretability, and robustness to concept drift in TS forecasting while delivering substantial performance gains, positioning it as a strong candidate for state-of-the-art forecasting on non-stationary data.

Abstract: Time-Series (TS) exhibits pronounced non-stationarity. Consequently, most forecasting methods display compromised robustness to concept drift, despite the prevalent application of instance normalization. We tackle this challenge by first analysing concept drift through a bias-variance lens and proving that weighted ensemble reduces variance without increasing bias. These insights motivate DeepBooTS, a novel end-to-end dual-stream residual-decreasing boosting method that progressively reconstructs the intrinsic signal. In our design, each block of a deep model becomes an ensemble of learners with an auxiliary output branch forming a highway to the final prediction. The block-wise outputs correct the residuals of previous blocks, leading to a learning-driven decomposition of both inputs and targets. This method enhances versatility and interpretability while substantially improving robustness to concept drift. Extensive experiments, including those on large-scale datasets, show that the proposed method outperforms existing methods by a large margin, yielding an average performance improvement of 15.8% across various datasets, establishing a new benchmark for TS forecasting.

</details>


### [285] [COGNOS: Universal Enhancement for Time Series Anomaly Detection via Constrained Gaussian-Noise Optimization and Smoothing](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06894)
*Wenlong Shang,Peng Chang*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: COGNOS improves reconstruction-based TSAD by regularizing residuals to Gaussian white noise during training and post-processing anomaly scores with a Kalman smoother, yielding large gains across models and datasets.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Reconstruction-based TSAD often relies on MSE, producing noisy residuals with poor signal-to-noise ratio. Aligning residuals with Gaussian white noise and denoising scores should improve anomaly detection reliability.

Method: 1) Gaussian-White Noise Regularization during training to constrain output residuals to Gaussian white noise; 2) Kalman Smoothing post-processor to denoise raw anomaly scores; 3) model-agnostic framework evaluated across 12 backbone models and multiple real-world benchmarks.

Result: Average F-score uplift of 57.9% across 12 backbone models on several real-world datasets, demonstrating robust separation of true anomaly signals from fluctuations.

Conclusion: Directly regularizing output statistics is a powerful and generalizable strategy for improving anomaly detection, with COGNOS providing a universal enhancement to existing reconstruction-based TSAD systems.

Abstract: Reconstruction-based methods are a dominant paradigm in time series anomaly detection (TSAD), however, their near-universal reliance on Mean Squared Error (MSE) loss results in statistically flawed reconstruction residuals. This fundamental weakness leads to noisy, unstable anomaly scores with a poor signal-to-noise ratio, hindering reliable detection. To address this, we propose Constrained Gaussian-Noise Optimization and Smoothing (COGNOS), a universal, model-agnostic enhancement framework that tackles this issue at its source. COGNOS introduces a novel Gaussian-White Noise Regularization strategy during training, which directly constrains the model's output residuals to conform to a Gaussian white noise distribution. This engineered statistical property creates the ideal precondition for our second contribution: a Kalman Smoothing Post-processor that provably operates as a statistically optimal estimator to denoise the raw anomaly scores. The synergy between these two components allows COGNOS to robustly separate the true anomaly signal from random fluctuations. Extensive experiments demonstrate that COGNOS is highly effective, delivering an average F-score uplift of 57.9% when applied to 12 diverse backbone models across multiple real-world benchmark datasets. Our work reveals that directly regularizing output statistics is a powerful and generalizable strategy for significantly improving anomaly detection systems.

</details>


### [286] [On The Presence of Double-Descent in Deep Reinforcement Learning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06895)
*Viktor Veselý,Aleksandar Todorov,Matthia Sabatelli*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Double descent exists in model-free DRL: larger actor-critic networks can generalize better past the interpolation point, with policy entropy dropping as capacity increases.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Extend the double-descent phenomenon to DRL in non-stationary settings and identify a mechanism.

Method: Systematically vary model capacity in Actor-Critic DRL; use Policy Entropy as an information-theoretic metric to track policy uncertainty during training; analyze the relation between capacity, entropy decay, and performance.

Result: Preliminary evidence of an epoch-wise double-descent curve in DRL; the second descent coincides with a sustained reduction in Policy Entropy, suggesting over-parameterization acts as an implicit regularizer.

Conclusion: DD is a factor in DRL; entropy decay provides an information-based mechanism for designing agents with better generalization, transferability, and robustness.

Abstract: The double descent (DD) paradox, where over-parameterized models see generalization improve past the interpolation point, remains largely unexplored in the non-stationary domain of Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL). We present preliminary evidence that DD exists in model-free DRL, investigating it systematically across varying model capacity using the Actor-Critic framework. We rely on an information-theoretic metric, Policy Entropy, to measure policy uncertainty throughout training. Preliminary results show a clear epoch-wise DD curve; the policy's entrance into the second descent region correlates with a sustained, significant reduction in Policy Entropy. This entropic decay suggests that over-parameterization acts as an implicit regularizer, guiding the policy towards robust, flatter minima in the loss landscape. These findings establish DD as a factor in DRL and provide an information-based mechanism for designing agents that are more general, transferable, and robust.

</details>


### [287] [A Hybrid Autoencoder-Transformer Model for Robust Day-Ahead Electricity Price Forecasting under Extreme Conditions](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06898)
*Boyan Tang,Xuanhao Ren,Peng Xiao,Shunbo Lei,Xiaorong Sun,Jianghua Wu*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A novel hybrid deep learning framework for day-ahead electricity price forecasting that combines Distilled Attention Transformer (DAT) and Autoencoder Self-regression Model (ASM) to handle extreme conditions and anomalies; achieves superior accuracy, robustness, and efficiency on CA and Shandong datasets.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Extreme conditions and market anomalies degrade forecast accuracy; there is a need for models that capture both long- and short-term patterns while detecting/removing anomalous patterns to maintain forecast quality and grid reliability.

Method: A hybrid architecture: Distilled Attention Transformer (DAT) uses self-attention to weigh critical historical segments, capturing long-term trends and short-term fluctuations. Autoencoder Self-regression Model (ASM) uses unsupervised learning to detect and isolate anomalous patterns induced by extreme conditions (e.g., heavy rain, heat waves, festivals). The two components are integrated for day-ahead price forecasting and evaluated on datasets from California and Shandong Province.

Result: The framework significantly outperforms state-of-the-art methods in prediction accuracy, robustness, and computational efficiency across the two regional datasets.

Conclusion: The proposed DAT+ASM hybrid framework shows promise for enhancing grid resilience and optimizing market operations in future power systems; further validation across more markets and analysis of robustness and deployment considerations would strengthen the claim.

Abstract: Accurate day-ahead electricity price forecasting (DAEPF) is critical for the efficient operation of power systems, but extreme condition and market anomalies pose significant challenges to existing forecasting methods. To overcome these challenges, this paper proposes a novel hybrid deep learning framework that integrates a Distilled Attention Transformer (DAT) model and an Autoencoder Self-regression Model (ASM). The DAT leverages a self-attention mechanism to dynamically assign higher weights to critical segments of historical data, effectively capturing both long-term trends and short-term fluctuations. Concurrently, the ASM employs unsupervised learning to detect and isolate anomalous patterns induced by extreme conditions, such as heavy rain, heat waves, or human festivals. Experiments on datasets sampled from California and Shandong Province demonstrate that our framework significantly outperforms state-of-the-art methods in prediction accuracy, robustness, and computational efficiency. Our framework thus holds promise for enhancing grid resilience and optimizing market operations in future power systems.

</details>


### [288] [Counterfactual Explanation for Multivariate Time Series Forecasting with Exogenous Variables](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06906)
*Keita Kinjo*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A framework for generating and evaluating counterfactual explanations for time-series forecasts that leverage exogenous variables, with analysis of variable influence and selective modification, supported by theory and experiments.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Interpretability of machine learning in time-series forecasting is important, especially for decisions driven by forecasts. Counterfactual explanations (CE) offer intuitive, actionable insights, and this work targets CE for time-series forecasting using exogenous variables.

Method: Propose a method to extract counterfactual explanations for time-series forecasts with exogenous variables; analyze the influence of each variable over the entire time horizon; generate CEs by altering only specific variables; evaluate CE quality using appropriate metrics; provide theoretical analysis and empirical validation.

Result: Theoretical analysis and empirical experiments indicate the approach yields accurate, practical CEs that are actionable and interpretable, demonstrating the method's viability for real-world decision-making in time-series contexts.

Conclusion: The work contributes to interpretability in time-series forecasting by enabling targeted, variable-specific counterfactuals using exogenous inputs, with demonstrated theoretical and empirical support for its usefulness.

Abstract: Currently, machine learning is widely used across various domains, including time series data analysis. However, some machine learning models function as black boxes, making interpretability a critical concern. One approach to address this issue is counterfactual explanation (CE), which aims to provide insights into model predictions. This study focuses on the relatively underexplored problem of generating counterfactual explanations for time series forecasting. We propose a method for extracting CEs in time series forecasting using exogenous variables, which are frequently encountered in fields such as business and marketing. In addition, we present methods for analyzing the influence of each variable over an entire time series, generating CEs by altering only specific variables, and evaluating the quality of the resulting CEs. We validate the proposed method through theoretical analysis and empirical experiments, showcasing its accuracy and practical applicability. These contributions are expected to support real-world decision-making based on time series data analysis.

</details>


### [289] [Sampling and Loss Weights in Multi-Domain Training](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06913)
*Mahdi Salmani,Pratik Worah,Meisam Razaviyayn,Vahab Mirrokni*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Two-domain weighting (sampling and loss) for multi-domain data in large-scale training can complement each other to reduce SGD gradient variance and narrow the generalization gap; theory in linear regression supported by experiments; joint dynamics study guides combining weights.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: When training with data from heterogeneous domains, deciding how much each domain contributes is crucial; this work investigates how sampling and loss weighting interact and their effects on variance and generalization.

Method: Theoretical analysis via linear regression to characterize how sampling and loss weights affect gradient variance and generalization; empirical experiments validate findings; analysis of the joint dynamics and potential combination strategies.

Result: Sampling and loss weights are complementary: they reduce gradient variance and improve generalization; joint dynamics show how to combine them to capture contributions from each domain; both theory and experiments support claims.

Conclusion: A principled framework for data mixing across domains; using both types of weights can improve training efficiency and generalization; guidance on jointly optimizing sampling and loss weighting.

Abstract: In the training of large deep neural networks, there is a need for vast amounts of training data. To meet this need, data is collected from multiple domains, such as Wikipedia and GitHub. These domains are heterogeneous in both data quality and the diversity of information they provide. This raises the question of how much we should rely on each domain. Several methods have attempted to address this issue by assigning sampling weights to each data domain using heuristics or approximations. As a first step toward a deeper understanding of the role of data mixing, this work revisits the problem by studying two kinds of weights: sampling weights, which control how much each domain contributes in a batch, and loss weights, which scale the loss from each domain during training. Through a rigorous study of linear regression, we show that these two weights play complementary roles. First, they can reduce the variance of gradient estimates in iterative methods such as stochastic gradient descent (SGD). Second, they can improve generalization performance by reducing the generalization gap. We provide both theoretical and empirical support for these claims. We further study the joint dynamics of sampling weights and loss weights, examining how they can be combined to capture both contributions.

</details>


### [290] [Learning to Focus: Prioritizing Informative Histories with Structured Attention Mechanisms in Partially Observable Reinforcement Learning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2511.06946)
*Daniel De Dios Allegue,Jinke He,Frans A. Oliehoek*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Structured temporal priors in a Transformer-based world model improve data efficiency in partial-observable RL, with Gaussian Attention delivering major gains; per-head memory-length priors are less beneficial and can hurt.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: In partially observable reinforcement learning, trajectories are sparse and reward-driven. Standard self-attention distributes weight across all past tokens, making it hard to focus on the few transitions critical for control. Structured priors aim to bias attention toward informative history.

Method: Introduce per-head memory-length priors to constrain attention windows and distributional priors that learn smooth Gaussian weightings over past state-action pairs, integrated into UniZero's Transformer-based dynamics head for planning under partial observability; evaluated on Atari 100k.
